614. en·trance 入口 ## 6

[’entrəns]n.入口；进入；登场；进入权vt.使入迷；使狂喜

  • The leader of the party was examining the soil near the entrance to the cave when the machine showed that there was gold under the ground. 党的队长正在检查附近的洞口土壤时，机器显示有地下金。
  • The same policeman was just walking slowly past the entrance, when Patrick asked the same question. 昨天的那位警察慢慢走过门口，当帕特里克问同样的问题。
  • The site chosen was an island at the entrance of New York Harbour. 场地选在了纽约港入口处的一个岛上。

SEE> gate 大门, door·way , en·try 进入

ODE> An opening, such as a door, passage, or gate, that allows access to a place. – entry, way in, means of access, means of entry, ingress, access, approach.

615. en·try 进入 ## 2

[’entri]n.进入；进入权；入口；条目

  • It was as clear as daylight then that burglars had forced an entry during her absence. 那么窃贼曾闯进她缺席期间的条目这是昭然若揭。
  • So their entry into this flat was apparently not the burglars’ first job that day and they must have been disturbed. 所以他们进入这个单位是显然不是窃贼第一份工作的那一天，他们必须感到不安。

SEE> en·ter 进入, ad·di·tion 加, fur·ther·more

ODE> An act of going or coming in. – appearance, arrival, entrance, ingress, coming, coming in, going in, approach, introduction, materialization.

616. en·ve·lope 信封 ## 2

[’ɑnvəˌloʊp]n.信封；壳层；封袋

  • I want some envelopes, please. 我想要一些信封，请。
  • A girl came in and put an envelope on his desk. 一个女孩走了进来，把一个信封放在他的办公桌上。

SEE> check 检查, sort 种类, in·stance 例子

ODE> A flat paper container with a sealable flap, used to enclose a letter or document. – wrapper, wrapping, wrap, sleeve, cover, covering.

617. en·vi·ron·ment 环境 ## 5

[ɪn’vaɪrənmənt]n.环境；外界

  • It was Hart who created the basic formula of the Western film, and devised the protagonist he played in every film he made, the good-bad man, the accidental-noble outlaw, or the honest-but-framed cowboy, or the sheriff made suspect by vicious gossip; in short, the individual in conflict with himself and his frontier environment. 这是哈特谁创造了西部电影的基本公式，并设计了他，他拍的电影几乎扮演主角，好的坏的男人，意外贵金属逃犯，诚实的，但是，遭陷害的牛仔或司法官。因流言蜚语怀疑;总之，在与他自己和他的拓荒环境相矛盾的人物。
  • It is not a simple competition for a fixed amount of food determined by the physical environment, because the environment that determines our evolution is no longer essentially physical. 它不是由物质环境所决定的食物固定量的简单竞争，因为决定我们进化的环境不再是物理本质。
  • Our environment is chiefly conditioned by the things we believe. 我们的环境主要是由我们相信的东西条件。

SEE> en·vi·ron·men·tal 环境的, more·o·ver 此外, fur·ther·more

ODE> The surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates. – habitat, territory, domain, home, abode.

618. e·qual 等于 ## 6

[’iːkwəl]adj.相等的；平等的vt.比得上；等于n.同辈；平等；(同等的)人或事物

  • I accept that we are equals, and I will argue with him, as an equal, if I think he is wrong. 我承认，我们是平等的，我会和他辩论，作为一个平等的，如果我认为他是错的。
  • If one group of people were disturbed from their eye-movement sleep for several nights on end, and another group were disturbed for an equal period of time but when they were not exhibiting eye-movements, the first group began to show some personality disorders while the others seemed more or less unaffected. 如果人一组从他们的眼动睡眠不安就结束了好几个晚上，另一组被打乱了相等的时间段，但是当他们并没有表现出眼睛运动，第一组人开始出现，而一些人格障碍其他人似乎没受什么影响。
  • Carlyle was entirely ignorant of what the bottle in his pocket contained, of the nature of the illness from which his friend was suffering, and of what had previously been wrong with his wife, but a medicine that had worked so well in one form of illness would surely be of equal benefit in another, and comforted by the thought of the help he was bringing to his friend, he hastened to Henry Taylor’s house. 卡莱尔不知道什么样的瓶子在他的口袋里所含知道他的朋友得的是什么病的性质，以及什么以前一直错误与他的妻子，但已在疾病的一种形式运作得非常好药品肯定是对另利益，并通过帮助下，他把他的朋友的想法安慰，于是急急忙忙来到了亨利的房子。

SEE> more·o·ver 此外, fur·ther·more , re·gard·less

ODE> Being the same in quantity, size, degree, or value. – identical, uniform, alike, like, the same, one and the same, equivalent, indistinguishable.

619. e·qual·ly 同样地 ## 8

[’iːkwəli]adv.相等地；同样地；平等地

  • Robert was delighted to see me and equally pleased with my little gift. 罗伯特很高兴地看到我，同样感到高兴与我的小礼物。
  • If, however, you were holding an open air garden party or a fete it would be equally possible to insure yourself in the event of bad weather. 但是，如果你要举办一次露天游园会或游艺会，它也同样可以保证自己在天气恶劣的情况下。
  • Though we may enjoy reading about the lives of others, it is extremely doubtful whether we would equally enjoy reading about ourselves. 我们都喜欢看关于别人的生活，这是非常令人怀疑，我们是否同样喜欢看关于自己。

SEE> sim·i·lar·ly 同样, in·deed 确实, quite 相当

ODE> In the same manner or to the same extent. – justly, equitably, impartially, without bias, without prejudice, without fear or favour, with an open mind, open-mindedly, even-handedly, objectively, neutrally, disinterestedly.

620. e·quip·ment 设备 ## 4

[ɪ’kwɪpmənt]n.设备；装备；器材

  • It was rather like an exhibition of prehistoric electronic equipment. 这是很像古老的电子设备的展览。
  • Economy is one powerful motive for camping, since after the initial outlay upon equipment, or through hiring it, the total expense can be far less than the cost of hotels. 经济是露营的一个主要动机。因为在设备的初始费用后，或是租借，总费用可能比经济型酒店的成本远不如。
  • That the equipment of modern camping becomes yearly more sophisticated is an entertaining paradox for the cynic, a brighter promise for the hopeful traveller who has sworn to get away from it all. 现代露营装备一年比一年更复杂的是愤世嫉俗，对谁发誓从一切烦恼的希望了更光明的承诺，一个有趣的悖论。

SEE> ma·chin·er·y 机械, facilities , hard·ware

ODE> The necessary items for a particular purpose. – apparatus, paraphernalia, articles, appliances, impedimenta.

621. er·ror 差错 ## 5

[’erər]n.错误；过失；误差；谬误

  • We also make the fundamental error of announcing our resolutions to everybody so that we look even more foolish when we slip back into our bad old ways. 我们也做宣布我们决心向大家一个根本性的错误，使我们，当我们重新陷入我们的那些老习惯看起来更加愚蠢。
  • Why do small errors make it impossible to predict the weather system with a high degree of accuracy? 为什么小错误使人们无法预测天气系统，具有高精确度的？
  • Errors and uncertainties multiply, cascading upward through a chain of turbulent features, from dust devils and squalls up to continent-size eddies that only satellites can see. 错误和不可靠性，通过链条的动荡特性，从尘暴级联向上和暴风发展到大陆，大小漩涡，只有卫星上可以看到。

SEE> mis·take 错误, in·stance 例子, cor·rect 正确

ODE> A mistake. – mistake, fallacy, misconception, delusion.

622. es·cape 逃跑 ## 10

[ɪ’skeɪp]v.逃跑；逃脱；逃避；被忘掉；泄露；去度假n.逃跑；逃脱；逃避；泄露；度假；[计算机]退出键

  • It threatened to surround him completely, but Tazieff managed to escape just in time. 它威胁要完全包围了他，但塔捷耶夫设法逃离了。
  • Lights were blazing and men were running here and there: they had just discovered that a prisoner had escaped. 灯光通明，人们都运行在这里和那里：他们刚刚发现有一个俘虏跑了。
  • As no pumas had been reported missing from any zoo in the country, this one must have been in the possession of a private collector and somehow managed to escape. 由于没有美洲狮被报道曾从全国动物园失踪，这一次一定是属于一位私人收藏家的，不知怎么设法逃出来了。

SEE> flee , pre·sum·a·bly 想必, ap·par·ent·ly 显然地

ODE> Break free from confinement or control. – get away, get out, run away, run off, break out, break free, get free, break loose, make a break for it, bolt, clear out, flee, fly, take flight, make off, take off, decamp, abscond, take to one’s heels, make a escape, make one’s escape, make good one’s escape, make a getaway, make one’s getaway, beat a retreat, beat a hasty retreat, show a clean pair of heels, run for it, make a run for it.

623. es·pe·cial·ly 特别 ## 12

[ɪ’speʃəli]adv.特别；尤其

  • The temptation to steal is greater than ever before – especially in large shops. 偷窃的诱惑力比以往任何时候都更强烈 - 特别在大的商店。
  • The actual figure was made of copper supported by a metal framework which had been especially constructed by Eiffel. 实际数字是由通过已经由艾菲尔特制的金属框架支撑铜。
  • I felt especially pleased with my wonderful bargain – until I got back to the ship. 我感到特别高兴与我的绝妙的讨价还价 - 直到我回到船上。

SEE> par·tic·u·lar·ly 尤其, well 好, most 最

ODE> Used to single out one person or thing over all others. – mainly, mostly, chiefly, principally, for the most part, in the main, on the whole, largely, by and large, to a large extent, to a great degree, predominantly, above all, first and foremost, basically, substantially, overall, in general, particularly, in particular, primarily, generally, usually, typically, commonly, as a rule.

624. es·sen·tial 必要 ## 3

[ɪ’senʃl]adj.本质的；必要的；重要的n.要素；必需品

  • As they grow old, people also accumulate belongings for two other reasons, lack of physical and mental energy, both of which are essential in turning out and throwing away, and sentiment. 当他们老去，人们也积累财物其他两个原因，缺乏体力，精力的，这两者都是在清理和扔掉，而情绪是至关重要的。
  • The first essential in elephant training is to assign to the animal a single mahout who will be entirely responsible for the job. 驯象中至关重要的是分配给动物一个象夫谁将会是全面负责这项工作。
  • Yet to both classes, the need of an alternative outlook, of a change of atmosphere, of a diversion of effort, is essential. 然而，这两个班，需要气氛的变化的另一种面貌，尝试做点不同的，是必不可少的。

SEE> vi·tal 重要, nec·es·sar·y 必要, in·dis·pen·sa·ble

ODE> Absolutely necessary; extremely important. – crucial, necessary, key, vital, indispensable, needed, required, called for, requisite, important, all-important, vitally important, of the utmost importance, of great consequence, of the essence, critical, life-and-death, imperative, mandatory, compulsory, obligatory, compelling, urgent, pressing, burning, acute, paramount, pre-eminent, high-priority, significant, consequential.

625. es·sen·tial·ly 本质上 ## 2

[ɪ’senʃəli]adv.本质上；本来

  • If a nation is essentially disunited, it is left to the government to hold it together. 如果一个国家实际上处于分裂状态，这是留给政府一起举行。
  • It is not a simple competition for a fixed amount of food determined by the physical environment, because the environment that determines our evolution is no longer essentially physical. 它不是由物质环境所决定的食物固定量的简单竞争，因为决定我们进化的环境不再是物理本质。

SEE> ba·si·cal·ly 基本上, sim·ply 只是, en·tire·ly 完全地

ODE> Used to emphasize the basic, fundamental, or intrinsic nature of a person or thing. – fundamentally, primarily, principally, chiefly, essentially, elementally, firstly, predominantly.

626. es·tab·lish 建立 ## 3

[ɪ’stæblɪʃ]v.建立；确立；创办；安顿

  • It can take as long as eight days to rig up rope ladders and to establish supply bases before a descent can be made into a very deep cave. 它可能需要长达8天时间来搭起绳梯，建立供应基地的下降可以做成一个很深的洞穴里。
  • Shortly after this the famous H.M.S.Challenger expedition established the study of the sea-floor as a subject worthy of the most qualified physicists and geologists. 此后不久，著名H.M.S.Challenger远征建立了海底作为一个值得一流物理学家和地质学家课题的研究。
  • You should then establish your own individual aims. 然后，您应该建立自己的个人目标。

SEE> aim 瞄准, main·tain 维持, es·tab·lish·ment

ODE> Set up on a firm or permanent basis. – set up, start, begin, get going, put in place, initiate, institute, form, found, create, bring into being, inaugurate, organize, lay the foundations of, build, construct, install, plant.

627. es·tate 地产 ## 2

[ɪ’steɪt]n.财产；遗产；房地产；状态；庄园

  • A French physician decided to get rid of the wild rabbits on his own estate and introduced myxomatosis. 决定一个法国医生得到他自己的庄园，并介绍粘液瘤病摆脱了野兔。
  • It did not, however, remain within the confines of his estate. 它没有，但是，在他的庄园的范围内。

SEE> prop·er·ty 财产, re·al 真实的, de·vel·op·er

ODE> An extensive area of land in the country, usually with a large house, owned by one person, family, or organization. – grounds, ground, fields, open space, open area.

628. es·ti·mate 估计 ## 5

[’estɪmət]n.估价；估计v.估计；估价；评价

  • It has been estimated that if the bridge were packed with cars, it would still only be carrying a third of its total capacity. 据估计，若桥上摆满了汽车，也只不过携带三分之一的总容量。
  • Though it may be possible to measure the value of material goods in terms of money, it is extremely difficult to estimate the true value of the services which people perform for us. 虽然有可能来衡量物质产品的在金钱方面的价值，这是非常难以估算别人为我们所提供的服务的真正价值。
  • One authority on spiders made a census of the spiders in a grass field in the south of England, and he estimated that there were more than 2,250,000 in one acre; that is something like 6,000,000 spiders of different kinds on a football pitch. 研究蜘蛛的权威提出在英国南部一块草坪上的蜘蛛作了一次调查，他估计，目前每英亩均超过2,250,000;这就是说，在一个足球场上不同种类6,000,000蜘蛛。

SEE> es·ti·mat·ed , fore·cast 预测, more·o·ver 此外

ODE> Roughly calculate or judge the value, number, quantity, or extent of. – roughly calculate, approximate, make an estimate of, guess, evaluate, judge, gauge, reckon, rate, appraise, form an opinion of, form an impression of, get the measure of, determine, weigh up.

629. e·ven 甚至 ## 100

[’iːvn]adj.平坦的；平和的；偶数的；相等的adv.甚至；正当；更；恰好v.使平坦；相等

  • I am even less lucky. 我甚至没有这么幸运。
  • I never catch anything – not even old boots. 我从来不乘任何东西 - 甚至没有旧靴子。
  • Because of this, he has not been able to get his own car into his garage even once. 正因为如此，他一直没能得到自己的车开进他的车库，甚至一次。

SEE> though 虽然, but 但是, so 所以

ODE> Flat and smooth. – flat, smooth, uniform, featureless, unbroken, undamaged, unwrinkled.

630. eve·ning 晚间 ## 28

[’iːvnɪŋ]n.晚上；傍晚；晚会

  • In the evening, the children come home from school. 到了晚上，孩子们放学回家。
  • In the evening, the children usually do their homework, but this evening, they are not doing their homework. 到了晚上，孩子们通常是做作业，而今天晚上，他们没做功课。
  • Where’s Mr. Williams this evening? 哪里是Williams先生今天晚上？

SEE> af·ter·noon 下午, morn·ing 早上, night 晚

ODE> The period of time at the end of the day, usually from about 6 p.m. to bedtime. – night, late afternoon, end of day, close of day.

631. e·vent 事件 ## 5

[ɪ’vent]n.大事；事件；项目

  • It is as if a single unimportant event set up a chain of reactions. 这是因为如果单不重要事件成立反应的链。
  • If, however, you were holding an open air garden party or a fete it would be equally possible to insure yourself in the event of bad weather. 但是，如果你要举办一次露天游园会或游艺会，它也同样可以保证自己在天气恶劣的情况下。
  • Stories about people often attract far more public attention than political events. 常人轶事往往比政治事件更能引起公众注意。

SEE> this 这个, oc·ca·sion 场合, ven·ue

ODE> A thing that happens or takes place, especially one of importance. – event, incident, occurrence, happening, development, phenomenon, thing, situation, circumstance, case, contingency, chance, likelihood, possibility, probability.

632. e·ven·tu·al·ly 终于 ## 10

[ɪ’ventʃuəli]adv.最后；终于

  • When it was eventually brought to shore, it was found to be over thirteen feet long. 当终于把它弄上岸，发现是超过了13英尺长。
  • Gesticulating wildly, the man acted as if he found my offer outrageous, but he eventually reduced the price to ￡10. 激动地打着手势，该男子的举动就好像他发现我的报价离谱，但他终于把价钱降低到£10英镑。
  • As it was extremely narrow, the man was unable to move, but the fire fighters were eventually able to free him by cutting a huge hole in the wall. 由于这是极窄，那人无法动弹，但消防员们终于在墙上切割大洞，把他解救出来。

SEE> fi·nal·ly 终于, soon 不久, ul·ti·mate·ly 最终

ODE> In the end, especially after a long delay, dispute, or series of problems. – in the end, in due course, by and by, in time, after some time, after a period of time, after a long time, after a bit, finally, at last, at long last.

633. ev·er 曾经 ## 35

[’evər]adv.曾经；在任何时候；究竟；一直；永远

  • Does it ever snow in Greece? 下过雪在希腊？
  • Have you ever been there, Ken? 你有没有去过那里，肯？
  • If anyone ever asks her how old she is, she always answers, ‘Darling, it must be terrible to be grown up!’ 如果有人问起她有多大年纪，她总是回答：“亲爱的，真可怕长大了！”

SEE> nev·er 从不, e·ven 甚至, yet 还

ODE> At any time. – at any time, at any point, on any occasion, under any circumstances, on any account.

634. eve·ry 每个 ## 44

[’evri]adj.每个；一切的；所有可能的；每隔；最大的

  • The sun shines every day. 太阳每天照射。
  • Their father takes them to school every day. 他们的父亲每天送他们上学。
  • Mrs. Sawyer stays at home every day. 索耶夫人每天呆在家里。

SEE> one 一, each 每, same 相同

ODE> Used before a singular noun to refer to all the individual members of a set without exception. – each, each and every, every single.

635. eve·ry·bod·y 每个人 ## 18

[’evribɑːdi]pron.每人；人人；各人

  • Everybody wants to have lunch in the garden. 每个人都想拥有的午餐在花园里。
  • Everybody knows him. 每个人都知道他。
  • Nearly everybody enters for ‘The Nicest Garden Competition’ each year, but Joe wins every time. 几乎每个人都在每年举办的“最佳花园竞赛”，但每次都是乔获胜。

SEE> eve·ry·one 大家, no·bod·y 没有人, else 其他

ODE> Every person. – everyone, every person, each person, each one, each and every one, all, one and all, all and sundry, the whole world, the world at large, the public, the general public, people everywhere.

636. eve·ry·one 大家 ## 12

[’evriwʌn]pron.每人；人人

  • Everyone’s in the garden. 每个人都在花园里。
  • ‘Everyone’s losing money these days,’ he said. “每个人都在丢钱，”他说。
  • The race gave everyone a great deal of pleasure. 这场比赛给了大家一个快乐的很大。

SEE> eve·ry·bod·y 每个人, else 其他, sure 当然

ODE> Every person. – everybody, every person, each person, each one, each and every one, all, one and all, all and sundry, the whole world, the world at large, the public, the general public, people everywhere.

637. eve·ry·thing 一切 ## 19

[’evriθɪŋ]pron.一切；所有事物；形势；情况；最重要的东西

  • Everything’s very quiet. 一切都非常安静。
  • In the end, we stay at home and look after everything! 最后，我们呆在家里来照看一切！
  • It’s a pleasant dream but everything depends on ‘if’! 这是一个美好的梦，但一切都取决于“如果”！

SEE> eve·ry·one 大家, else 其他, sure 当然

ODE> All things. – each item, each thing, every article, every single thing, the lot, the whole lot, the entirety, the total, the aggregate.

638. eve·ry·where 到处 ## 6

[’evriwer]adv.到处，处处；无论何处

  • There were coins everywhere. 到处都是硬币。
  • Litter baskets have been placed under the trees, but people still throw their rubbish everywhere. 废物筐已放置在树下，但人们仍到处扔垃圾。
  • She looked everywhere for him but could not find him. 她四处寻找，但没有找到他。

SEE> wher·ev·er 哪里, eve·ry·one 大家, no·where 无处

ODE> In or to all places. – all over, all around, in all places, in every place, in every spot, in every part, in every nook and cranny, in each place, far and wide, near and far, high and low, here and there, here, there, and everywhere, throughout the land, the world over, worldwide.

639. ev·i·dence 证据 ## 8

[’evɪdəns]n.证据；证词；根据；迹象v.证明；证实

  • What evidence is there of a ghost? 有什么证据鬼？
  • However, as the evidence began to accumulate, experts from the Zoo felt obliged to investigate, for the descriptions given by people who claimed to have seen the puma were extraordinarily similar. 然而，随着证据越来越多，动物园的专家们感到有必要调查，通过谁声称见到过美洲狮的人们所描述的情况竟是出奇地相似。
  • They will hardly know which facts to select from the great mass of evidence that steadily accumulates. 他们几乎不知道对于逐渐积累起来的庞大选取哪些。

SEE> sug·gest 建议, proof 证明, prove 证明

ODE> The available body of facts or information indicating whether a belief or proposition is true or valid. – proof, confirmation, verification, substantiation, corroboration, affirmation, authentication, attestation, documentation.

640. e·vil 邪恶 ## 3

[’iːvl]adj.邪恶的；有害的；讨厌的n.邪恶；罪恶；灾祸

  • The tree was planted near the church fifty years ago, but it is only in recent years that it has gained an evil reputation. 该树是50年前栽在教堂附近的，但它只是在最近几年才得到了一个坏名声。
  • As is so often pointed out, knowledge is a two-edged weapon which can be used equally for good or evil. 正像人们常常指出的，知识是一柄武器，同样可以为善或恶来使用。
  • But, if this world is not merely a bad joke, life a vulgar flare amid the cool radiance of the stars, and existence an empty laugh braying across the mysteries; if these intimations of a something behind and beyond are not evil humour born of indigestion, or whimsies sent by the devil to mock and madden us, if, in a word, beauty means something, yet we must not seek to interpret the meaning. 但是，如果这个世界不只是一个拙劣的恶作剧，生活庸俗火炬惨淡的星光里的清凉四射，并且存在一个空虚的笑声奥秘马叫;如果后面的东西的暗示和超越都没有邪念的，或者不是一种魔鬼送来嘲笑我们并使我们发狂，如果在一个字，美指什么，但我们千万不要去阐明它的意义邪念。

SEE> wick·ed , in·deed 确实, sup·pos·ed·ly

ODE> Profoundly immoral and wicked. – wicked, bad, wrong, morally wrong, wrongful, immoral, sinful, ungodly, unholy, foul, vile, base, ignoble, dishonourable, corrupt, iniquitous, depraved, degenerate, villainous, nefarious, sinister, vicious, malicious, malevolent, demonic, devilish, diabolic, diabolical, fiendish, dark, black-hearted.

641. ex·act 精确的 ## 4

[ɪɡ’zækt]adj.精密严谨的；确切的

  • The editor at once sent the journalist a fax instructing him to find out the exact number of steps and the height of the wall. 立即给那位记者发去传真，要求他的编辑器来找出台阶的确切数字和围墙的高度。
  • Precautions of this sort are necessary, for it is impossible to foretell the exact nature of the difficulties which will confront the pot-holer. 作出这样的准备是必要的，因为它是无法预见到将面临锅holer困难的确切性质。
  • I have heard of writers who read nothing but their own books; like adolescents they stand before the mirror, and still cannot fathom the exact outline of the vision before them. 我听说谁读什么，但自己的书作家;像少年，站在镜前，仍然无法捉摸他们之前的视野的准确轮廓。

SEE> pre·cise 精确, un·clear , ex·act·ly 确切地

ODE> Not approximated in any way; precise. – definite, fixed, settled, decided, established, confirmed, agreed, exact, clear-cut, concrete, hard and fast.

642. ex·act·ly 确切地 ## 5

[ɪɡ’zæktli]adv.精确地；确切地；完全地；严密地；正是

  • At exactly that moment, the telephone rang. 恰恰在此时，电话铃响了。
  • The day after, Patrick went to the house once more and asked exactly the same question. 之后的日子，帕特里克来到了房子一次，并确切地问同样的问题。
  • This race, which went on for exactly four months, was the last of its kind. 这场比赛，持续了整整4个月，是最后的同类。

SEE> pre·cise·ly 恰好地, what 什么, know 知道

ODE> Used to emphasize the accuracy of a figure or description. – precisely, entirely, absolutely, completely, totally, just, quite, in every way, in every respect, one hundred per cent, every inch, to the hilt.

643. ex·am 考试 ## 2

[ɪɡ’zæm]n.考试

  • How long did the exam last? 有多久没考试最后？
  • How was the exam, Richard? 考试考得怎样，理查德？

SEE> ex·am·i·na·tion 检查, grad·u·a·tion , math

ODE> A medical test of a specified kind. – test, examination, paper, question paper, oral, practical, assessment.

644. ex·am·ine 检查 ## 8

[ɪɡ’zæmɪn]vt.检查；调查；考试；仔细观察vi.检查；调查

  • Yesterday the firemen examined the ground carefully, but were not able to find any broken glass. 昨天，消防队员仔细查看了地面，但未能找到任何碎玻璃。
  • The leader of the party was examining the soil near the entrance to the cave when the machine showed that there was gold under the ground. 党的队长正在检查附近的洞口土壤时，机器显示有地下金。
  • The fish, which has since been sent to a museum where it is being examined by a scientist, is called an oarfish. 鱼，这已经被送到那里正被科学家检查了博物馆，被称为皇带鱼。

SEE> e·val·u·ate , an·a·lyze , as·sess

ODE> Inspect (someone or something) thoroughly in order to determine their nature or condition. – inspect, survey, scrutinize, look at, look into, inquire into, study, investigate, scan, sift, delve into, dig into, explore, probe, check out, consider, appraise, weigh, weigh up, analyse, review, vet.

645. ex·am·ple 例子 ## 9

[ɪɡ’zæmpl]n.例子；榜样；举例；警告vt.作为 … 的示范

  • Even people who take no interest in art cannot have failed to notice examples of modern sculpture on display in public places. 即使谁对艺术不感兴趣的人也不会在公共场所都未能现代雕塑的通知例子展出。
  • The following example of ‘sick humour’ will enable you to judge for yourself. “病态幽默”的下面的例子将让你自己判断。
  • Who could have imagined, in the mid 1970s, for example, that by the end of the 20th century, computers would be as common in people’s homes as TV sets? 谁能够想到，20世纪70年代中期开始，例如，由20世纪末，计算机会在人们的家中为电视机常见？

SEE> in·stance 例子, par·tic·u·lar 特定的, in·deed 确实

ODE> A thing characteristic of its kind or illustrating a general rule. – specimen, sample, exemplar, exemplification, instance, case, representative case, typical case, case in point, illustration.

646. ex·cel·lent 极好的 ## 4

[’eksələnt]adj.杰出的；优秀的；极好的

  • I reflected that there must be a great many people besides myself who wished to take advantage of this excellent service. 我反映，必须有自己之外了许多人谁希望借此优良的服务优势。
  • Such things provide an excellent outlet for pent up creative energy, but unfortunately not all of us are born handymen. 这些东西为人们潜在的创造力极好的出口，但不幸的是我们，不是所有的都是能工巧匠。
  • Sweden has evolved an excellent system for protecting the individual citizen from high-handed or incompetent public officers. 瑞典，已逐渐一种完善的制度以保护每个公民不受专横或无能的政府官员。

SEE> good 好, ter·rif·ic , su·perb

ODE> Extremely good; outstanding. – very good, superb, outstanding, magnificent, of high quality, of the highest quality, of the highest standard, exceptional, marvellous, wonderful, sublime, perfect, eminent, pre-eminent, matchless, peerless, supreme, first-rate, first-class, superior, superlative, splendid, admirable, worthy, sterling, fine.

647. ex·cept 除了 ## 8

[ɪk’sept]prep.除了 … 之外conj.除非；除了 … 之外；若不是vt.除；除外

  • Except us. 除美国之外。
  • Harrison had thought of everything except the weather. 哈里森曾认为，除了天气的一切。
  • The party then searched the whole cave thoroughly but did not find anything except an empty tin trunk. 然后，将彻底搜寻了整个洞穴，但没有发现除了一个空铁皮箱外什么。

SEE> ex·cep·tion 例外, though 虽然, un·like 不像

ODE> Not including; other than. – excluding, not including, excepting, omitting, leaving out, not counting, but, besides, barring, bar, other than, exclusive of, saving, save, apart from, aside from.

648. ex·change 交换 ## 3

[ɪks’tʃeɪndʒ]v.交换；兑换n.交换；交易所；兑换；交战

  • When he was alone, he telephoned the hospital exchange and asked for Doctor Millington. 当他独自一人，他打电话给医院的交换台，要求与米灵顿医生。
  • If fifty pence pieces are not exchanged for sweets, they rattle for months inside money boxes. 如果50个便士不拿来换糖吃，他们滔滔不绝的内部钱箱个月。
  • One wants to meet like-minded collectors, to get advice, to compare notes, to exchange articles, to show off the latest find. 收藏者要会见志同道合的收藏家，以获取教益，比较笔记，交换收藏品，炫耀自己的最新发现。

SEE> stock 股票, close 关闭, com·mod·i·ty

ODE> An act of giving one thing and receiving another (especially of the same kind) in return. – interchange, trade, trading, trade-off, swapping, barter, giving and taking, traffic, trafficking, bandying, reciprocity.

649. ex·cite 激动 ## 3

[ɪk’saɪt]vt.使兴奋；使激动；刺激；激起

  • Very excited, the party dug a hole two feet deep. 很激动，就地挖了一个洞深更生。
  • She was too excited to do any housework that morning, for in the evening she would be going to a fancy-dress party with her husband. 她兴奋得那天早上做任何家务，在晚上她会去一个化装派对与她的丈夫。
  • Rays from the sun excite and energize the atmosphere of the earth, awakening it to flow, to movement, to rhythm, to life. 来自太阳的光线激发波长和激励地球的大气层，唤醒它流动，迁徙，产生节奏，获得生命。

ODE> Cause (someone) to feel very enthusiastic and eager. – thrill, exhilarate, animate, enliven, rouse, stir, move, stimulate, galvanize, electrify, fire the imagination of, fire the enthusiasm of.

650. ex·cit·ed 兴奋 ## 2

[ɪk’saɪtɪd]adj.感到兴奋的；激动的

  • Sally was very excited because she had never travelled on a train before. 萨莉非常激动，因为她从未之前火车旅行。
  • We are all very excited and are looking forward to the Olympic Games because they have never been held before in this country. 我们都非常兴奋，因为他们从来没有在这个国家举行前都期待着奥运会。

SEE> thrilled , de·light·ed 欣喜的, ob·vi·ous·ly 显然

ODE> Very enthusiastic and eager. – thrilled, exhilarated, elevated, animated, enlivened, electrified, stirred, moved.

651. ex·cite·ment 激动 ## 5

[ɪk’saɪtmənt]n.激动；兴奋

  • A lot of cars entered for this race last year and there was a great deal of excitement just before it began. 很多小汽车参加了这种比赛，去年和有兴奋的大量之前就开始了。
  • The sea bed was scoured with powerful nets and there was tremendous excitement on board when a chest was raised from the bottom. 海床用结实的网冲刷并有巨大的兴奋在船上当一只箱子从海底升起。
  • Frank could hardly conceal his excitement, for he knew that he had made a real discovery. 弗兰克几乎无法掩饰自己兴奋的心情，因为他明白，他已经发现了一件珍品。

SEE> en·thu·si·asm 热情, an·tic·i·pa·tion , de·light 喜悦

ODE> A feeling of great enthusiasm and eagerness. – exhilaration, elation, animation, enthusiasm, eagerness, anticipation, feverishness, fever, delirium, agitation, emotion, fire, fieriness, intensity, zeal, zest.

652. ex·cit·ing 令人兴奋的 ## 9

[ɪk’saɪtɪŋ]adj.令人兴奋的；使人激动的

  • It was an exciting finish. 这是一个令人兴奋的光洁度。
  • Why is Tim finding this trip exciting? 为什么蒂姆觉得这次旅行精彩？
  • My brother has never been abroad before, so he is finding this trip very exciting. 我弟弟以前从未出过国，因此，他觉得这次旅行非常激动人心。

SEE> in·ter·est·ing 有趣, in·tri·guing , fas·ci·nat·ing

ODE> Causing great enthusiasm and eagerness. – thrilling, exhilarating, stirring, rousing, stimulating, intoxicating, electrifying, invigorating, moving, inspiring.

653. ex·cuse 借口 ## 5

[ɪk’skjuːs]vt.原谅；辩解n.理由；辩解；借口

  • Excuse me! 劳驾!
  • ‘Excuse me,’ she said. “对不起，”她说。
  • Excuse the mess, Sam. 请问残局，山姆。

SEE> rea·son 理由, jus·ti·fy 辩解, mere·ly 仅仅

ODE> Seek to lessen the blame attaching to (a fault or offence); try to justify. – justify, defend, make excuses for, make a case for, explain, explain away, rationalize, condone, vindicate, warrant.

654. ex·er·cise 锻炼 ## 6

[’eksərsaɪz]n.运动；练习；作业vt.运用vi.锻炼

  • I limited myself to two modest ambitions: to do physical exercises every morning and to read more of an evening. 只给自己定下两项适中的任务：每天早上锻炼身体，多读一个晚上。
  • The daily exercises lasted only eleven minutes and I proposed to do them early in the morning before anyone had got up. 早锻炼一共只有11分钟，我建议早做他们早上别人起床之前。
  • The time I spent at exercises gradually diminished. 花在锻炼上的时间，我逐渐减少。

SEE> rou·tine 常规, in·volve 包含, more·o·ver 此外

ODE> Activity requiring physical effort, carried out to sustain or improve health and fitness. – physical activity, movement, exertion, effort, work.

655. ex·hib·it 展览 ## 3

[ɪɡ’zɪbɪt]v.展览；陈列；展示；表现n.展品；展览

  • How might some of the exhibits have been dangerous? 怎么可能会部分展品已经很危险吗？
  • The first thing I saw when I entered the art gallery was a notice which said: ’Do not touch the exhibits. 当我走进展厅的第一件事，我看到的是一张告示，上面说：“不要触摸展品。
  • If one group of people were disturbed from their eye-movement sleep for several nights on end, and another group were disturbed for an equal period of time but when they were not exhibiting eye-movements, the first group began to show some personality disorders while the others seemed more or less unaffected. 如果人一组从他们的眼动睡眠不安就结束了好几个晚上，另一组被打乱了相等的时间段，但是当他们并没有表现出眼睛运动，第一组人开始出现，而一些人格障碍其他人似乎没受什么影响。

SEE> ex·hi·bi·tion 展出, dis·play 展示, mu·se·um 博物馆

ODE> Publicly display (a work of art or item of interest) in an art gallery or museum or at a trade fair. – exhibit, show, put on show, put on view, expose to view, present, unveil, set forth.

656. ex·hi·bi·tion 展出 ## 8

[ˌeksɪ’bɪʃn]n.展览；展示

  • How many people visited the Great Exhibition of 1851? 有多少人参观了1851年的世界博览会？
  • Perhaps the most extraordinary building of the nineteenth century was the Crystal Palace, which was built in Hyde Park for the Great Exhibition of 1851. 也许是十九世纪最不寻常的建筑水晶宫，这是建在海德公园的1851年世界博览会。
  • A great many goods were sent to the exhibition from various parts of the world. 大量的商品从世界各地运送到了展览。

SEE> ex·hib·it 展览, gal·ler·y , art 艺术

ODE> A public display of works of art or items of interest, held in an art gallery or museum or at a trade fair. – display, public display, show, showing, presentation, demonstration, showcase, mounting, spectacle.

657. ex·ist 存在 ## 9

[ɪɡ’zɪst]v.存在；生存；活着

  • Though these large machines still exist, many of their functions have been taken over by small powerful personal computers, commonly known as PCs. 虽然这种大计算机仍然存在，但它们的许多功能已被体积小功能强大的个人电脑，俗称电脑。
  • Harry used to consider it a great joke to go into expensive cosmetic shops and make outrageous requests for goods that do not exist. 哈里曾认为这是一个很大的玩笑进入昂贵的化妆品商店，对于不存在的商品离谱的请求。
  • The village no longer existed because it had been submerged, and all the valley too. 该村庄已不复存在，因为它已被淹没，山谷也。

SEE> fur·ther·more , more·o·ver 此外, these 这些

ODE> Have objective reality or being. – live, be alive, be living, have life, breathe, draw breath.

658. ex·ist·ence 存在 ## 9

[ɪɡ’zɪstəns]n.存在；生存

  • When he denied the train’s existence, I borrowed his copy of the timetable. 当他否认了火车的存在，我借用了他的时间表的副本。
  • At present, there is no telescope in existence that is capable of detecting the presence of life. 目前，有存在，其能够检测生命的存在没有望远镜。
  • An individual human existence should be like a river – small at first, narrowly contained within its banks, and rushing passionately past boulders and over waterfalls. 一个人的一生应该像一条河 - 开始很小，狭窄的两岸之间，尔后奔腾咆哮，翻过危岩，飞越瀑布。

SEE> fact 事实, in·deed 确实, ex·ist 存在

ODE> The fact or state of living or having objective reality. – alive, existing, extant, existent.

659. ex·pect 期望 ## 16

[ɪk’spekt]v.预期；期待；盼望

  • They were expecting a valuable parcel of diamonds from South Africa. 他们正期待从南非钻石贵重包裹。
  • He was amused too, because he never expected the bicycle to be found. 但又感到非常好笑，因为他从未指望那辆自行车还能找到。
  • I went on an excursion recently, but my trip took me longer than I expected. 我作了一次短途旅行最近，但这次旅行花了我的时间比我的预期。

SEE> cer·tain·ly 当然, come 来, expected 预期

ODE> Regard (something) as likely to happen. – anticipate, await, look for, hope for, watch for, look forward to, look ahead to, have in prospect.

660. ex·pense 花费 ## 5

[ɪk’spens]n.费用；花费；代价

  • They could be saved so much misery and expense if they chose to live in the city where they rightly belong. 它们可以保存这么多的痛苦和费用，如果他们愿意住在城市本来属于他们。
  • This increases the expense of government, and reduces correspondingly the amount of economic resources that could be used for developing the country. 这增加了政府的开支，从而相应地减少了可以用来发展国家经济的资源量。
  • An enterprise has to incur certain costs and expenses in order to stay in business. 一家企业必须担负起一定的费用和开支，以维持经营。

SEE> more·o·ver 此外, expenses , ben·e·fit 益处

ODE> The cost incurred in or required for something. – cost, price.

661. ex·pen·sive 昂贵的 ## 18

[ɪk’spensɪv]adj.昂贵的；高价的

  • It’s the most expensive model in the shop. 这是店里最贵的型号。
  • That’s too expensive for us. 这对我们来说太昂贵了。
  • This model’s less expensive than that one. 这种模式比那种要便宜些。

SEE> cost 价钱为, in·ex·pen·sive , less 减

ODE> Costing a lot of money. – costly, dear, high-priced, high-cost, big-budget, exorbitant, extortionate, overpriced.

662. ex·pe·ri·ence 经验 ## 23

[ɪk’spɪriəns]n.经验；经历v.经历；体验；感受

  • I had an amusing experience last year. 去年我有过一次有趣的经历。
  • Yesterday afternoon Frank Hawkins was telling me about his experiences as a young man. 昨天下午弗兰克霍金斯向我讲述了他年轻时的经历的人。
  • A flight attendant would take charge of me and I never had an unpleasant experience. 一位空中乘务员照顾我，我从未有过不愉快的经历。

SEE> ex·pe·ri·enced 有经验的, in·deed 确实, kind 种类

ODE> Practical contact with and observation of facts or events. – involvement in, participation in.

663. ex·per·i·ment 实验 ## 8

[ɪk’sperɪmənt]n.试验；实验；尝试vi.尝试；做实验

  • Experiments have proved that children can be instructed in swimming at a very early age. 实验证明，孩子们可以在游泳在很小的时候就被指示。
  • This brief experiment would dispel any further doubts you might have. 这个简单的试验会消除任何疑虑进一步，你可能有。
  • I immediately embarked on an experiment which, even though it failed to get rid of the ants, kept me fascinated for twenty-four hours. 我当即动手作了一项试验，这项试验尽管没有使我摆脱这些蚂蚁，却使我着迷了24小时。

SEE> in·stance 例子, ex·per·i·men·tal , in·deed 确实

ODE> A scientific procedure undertaken to make a discovery, test a hypothesis, or demonstrate a known fact. – test, investigation, trial, inquiry, demonstration.

664. ex·pert 专家 ## 7

[’ekspɜːrt]n.专家；能手adj.熟练的；内行的

  • Rex soon became an expert at opening the gate. 雷克斯很快成了开门的专家。
  • All the students are expert drivers, but before they drive any of the buses, they will have to pass a special test. 所有的学生都是开车的能手，但在驾驶公共汽车之前，他们必须通过一项专门测验。
  • At a special swimming pool in Los Angeles, children become expert at holding their breath under water even before they can walk. 在一个特别的游泳池在洛杉矶，孩子成为下他们能走甚至在水下屏住呼吸了专家。

SEE> spe·cial·ist 专家, con·sult·ant , re·search·er

ODE> A person who is very knowledgeable about or skilful in a particular area. – specialist, authority, pundit, oracle, resource person.

665. ex·plain 解释 ## 15

[ɪk’spleɪn]v.说明；解释

  • Nearly a week passed before the girl was able to explain what had happened to her. 近一周的女孩前通过能够讲述自己的遭遇。
  • He explained that his diet was so strict that he had to reward himself occasionally. 他解释说，他的饮食控制得太严格了，以致不得不偶尔奖赏自己。
  • He informed the station at once, but no one there was able to explain the mystery. 他立刻通知了车站，但没有一个人能解释其中的奥秘。

SEE> why 为什么, un·der·stand 懂, fact 事实

ODE> Make (an idea or situation) clear to someone by describing it in more detail or revealing relevant facts. – describe, give an explanation of, make clear, make intelligible, make plain, spell out, put into words, express in words.

666. ex·pla·na·tion 解释 ## 3

[ˌeksplə’neɪʃn]n.解释；说明

  • The explanation was simple but very unusual. 解释很简单，但非常不寻常的。
  • It is impossible to give a satisfactory explanation for a pot-holer’s motives. 这是不可能给出一个锅holer的动机作出满意的解释。
  • This explanation evidently conveyed something to the woman who searched shelf after shelf. 这种解释显然东西，谁后货架货架搜索的女人。

SEE> ex·plain 解释, rea·son 理由, plau·si·ble

ODE> A statement or account that makes something clear. – clarification, simplification.

667. ex·plore 探索 ## 5

[ɪk’splɔːr]v.探测；探险；考察；探究

  • An American team explored a temple which stands in an ancient city on the promontory of Ayia Irini. 一个美国考古队矗立在古城的阿依Irini酒店的海角寺庙。
  • The temple which the archaeologists explored was used as a place of worship from the fifteenth century B.C. 考古工作者考察的这座庙宇从第十五世纪公元前一个礼拜的地方
  • Exploring really deep caves is not a task for the Sunday afternoon rambler. 探测非常深的洞穴不是那些在星期日下午漫步的任务。

SEE> ex·am·ine 检查, de·vel·op 开发, col·lab·o·rate

ODE> Travel through (an unfamiliar area) in order to learn about it. – travel over, tour, traverse, range over.

668. ex·press 表达 ## 7

[ɪk’spres]n.快车；快递；专使adj.明确的；急速的；直接的adv.用快递vt.表达；表示；挤压出；快递

  • But so far, the public has expressed its gratitude to the students in letters to the Press. 但到目前为止，公众已经表达了感谢学生写信给出版社。
  • After consulting my railway timetable, I noted with satisfaction that there was an express train to Westhaven. 我查看了列车时刻表，满意地指出，有快车不可动摇的信念。
  • Even a mighty express train can be held up by signals. 即便是特别快车也可能被信号拦住。

SEE> like·wise , in·stance 例子, con·vey

ODE> Convey (a thought or feeling) in words or by gestures and conduct. – communicate, convey, indicate, show, demonstrate, reveal, intimate, manifest, make manifest, exhibit, evidence, put across, put over, get across, get over.

669. ex·tend 延伸 ## 4

[ɪk’stend]v.延伸；延长；伸展；扩展；提供；使竭尽全力

  • The platforms extend to a depth of over 100 feet under the sea. 该平台扩展到超过100英尺的海底深度。
  • We informed him that the fissure extended for fifty yards and was two feet wide and four feet deep. 我们告诉他那个大裂缝长50码，2英尺宽和深4英尺。
  • It extends to a depth of 3,723 feet. 它达3,723英尺的深度。

SEE> ex·ten·sion 延长, ex·pand 扩大, be·yond 超出

ODE> Cause to cover a wider area; make larger. – expand, enlarge, increase, make larger, make bigger, make greater.

670. ex·tent 程度 ## 5

[ɪk’stent]n. 广度； 宽度； 长度； 大小； 范围； 程度n. [律]扣押； 临时所有权令

  • This will relieve pressure on the trains to some extent. 这将减轻对火车一定程度上的压力。
  • It is a harmless habit, but it litters up her desk to such an extent that every time she opens it, loose bits of paper fall out in every direction. 它是一种无害的习惯，但她的办公桌上最多乱丢到这样的程度，每次她打开它时，纸张的松位在每一个方向脱落。
  • Sometimes the secrecy goes to such an extent that the whole nature of the research cannot be mentioned. 有时，保密竟到了研究工作的整个性质都不准提及的程度。

SEE> more·o·ver 此外, in·deed 确实, fact 事实

ODE> The area covered by something. – area, size, expanse, length, stretch, range, scope, compass.

671. ex·tra 额外的 ## 4

[’ekstrə]adj.额外的n.额外之物；临时演员adv.特别地

  • I said I would be at your house at six o’clock, but the boss wants me to do some extra work. 我说，我会在你的房子在六点钟，但老板要我做一些额外的工作。
  • Then he smiled and told me I would receive an extra thousand pounds a year! 然后，他笑着告诉我一个我每年将得到1,000英镑的额外！
  • Mum or dad, of course, provide a regular supply of pocket money, but uncles and aunts are always a source of extra income. 爸爸妈妈，当然，提供的零花钱正常供应，但叔叔和婶婶总是额外收入来源。

SEE> ad·di·tion·al 额外, ad·di·tion 加, put 放

ODE> Added to an existing or usual amount or number. – additional, more, added, supplementary, supplemental, further, auxiliary, ancillary, subsidiary, secondary, attendant, accessory.

672. ex·traor·di·nar·y 非凡的 ## 7

[ɪk’strɔːrdəneri]adj.非凡的；特别的；特派的

  • Perhaps the most extraordinary building of the nineteenth century was the Crystal Palace, which was built in Hyde Park for the Great Exhibition of 1851. 也许是十九世纪最不寻常的建筑水晶宫，这是建在海德公园的1851年世界博览会。
  • They disregard social conventions without being conscious that they are doing anything extraordinary. 他们不顾社会习俗，意识不到自己所作所为有什么特殊之处。
  • If the landscape is hidden from view, you can enjoy the extraordinary sight of unbroken cloud plains that stretch out for miles before you, while the sun shines brilliantly in a clear sky. 如果景色被遮住了，你可以观赏一下展现在伸出你之前英里完整的云平原，而太阳在晴朗的天空灿烂。

SEE> ex·cep·tion·al , re·mark·a·ble 显著的, un·prec·e·dent·ed

ODE> Very unusual or remarkable. – remarkable, exceptional, amazing, astonishing, astounding, marvellous, wonderful, sensational, stunning, incredible, unbelievable, miraculous, phenomenal, prodigious, spectacular.

673. ex·treme 极端 ## 5

[ɪk’striːm]adj.极度的；极端的n.极端；极限

  • Editors of newspapers and magazines often go to extremes to provide their readers with unimportant facts and statistics. 报纸和杂志的编辑常常走极端为了向读者提供一些无关紧要的事实和统计数字。
  • This is a rare occurrence as our climate seldom goes to extremes. 这是一种罕见的发生为我们的气候很少去极端。
  • One wonders also why Nature, with some snakes, concocted poison of such extreme potency. 人们不禁要问，也大自然为什么在某些蛇身上，这样高效的炮制毒。

SEE> in·stance 例子, un·u·su·al 异常, par·tic·u·lar 特定的

ODE> Reaching a high or the highest degree; very great. – utmost, uttermost, very great, greatest, greatest possible, maximum, maximal, highest, ultimate, supreme, paramount, great, acute, major, intense, enormous, severe, high, superlative, exceptional, extraordinary.

674. ex·treme·ly 非常地 ## 9

[ɪk’striːmli]adv.非常；极其

  • No one could account for the fact that one of the boxes was extremely heavy. 没有人可以解释这个事实，即一个箱子特别重。
  • It is not only of immense size, but is extremely accurate as well. 它不仅规模巨大，而且是非常准确。
  • Everybody around me was smoking and I felt extremely uncomfortable. 我周围的每个人都在吸烟，我感到极不舒服。

SEE> ver·y 非常, in·cred·i·bly , quite 相当

ODE> To a very great degree; very. – very, exceedingly, exceptionally, especially, extraordinarily, to a fault, in the extreme, extra, tremendously, immensely, vastly, hugely, abundantly, intensely, acutely, singularly, significantly, distinctly, outstandingly, uncommonly, unusually, decidedly, particularly, eminently, supremely, highly, remarkably, really, truly, mightily, thoroughly.

675. eye 眼睛 ## 11

[aɪ]n.眼睛；目光；视力；观点；鉴赏力v.看；注视；审视

  • Her eyes were fixed on her plate and in a short time, she was busy eating. 她的眼睛盯着自己的盘子，并在很短的时间，她就忙着吃起来。
  • By the time you read this, the Hubble’s eagle eye will have sent us thousands and thousands of wonderful pictures. 当你读到这篇文章时，哈勃的鹰之眼已经为我们送来了成千上万张精彩的照片。
  • He was rather elderly with grey hair and clear blue eyes. 他上了年纪，灰白的头发和明亮的蓝眼睛。

SEE> sight 视力, look 看, mind 心神

ODE> Each of a pair of globular organs of sight in the head of humans and vertebrate animals. – organ of sight, eyeball.

676. face 脸 ## 15

[feɪs]n.表面；脸；表情v.面对；面向；朝

  • She then began to make up her face. 然后她开始打扮起来。
  • It is one of the ugliest faces I have ever seen. 这是我见过的最丑陋的面孔之一。
  • One man stayed at the wheel while two others with black stockings over their faces jumped out and smashed the window of the shop with iron bars. 一人留在驾驶座上，另外两个用黑色长筒丝袜他们的脸跳了出来，砸坏用铁棒在商店的橱窗。

SEE> e·ven 甚至, come 来, both 两者

ODE> The front part of a person’s head from the forehead to the chin, or the corresponding part in an animal. – countenance, physiognomy, profile, features.

677. fact 事实 ## 34

[fækt]n.事实；真相；实际

  • No one could account for the fact that one of the boxes was extremely heavy. 没有人可以解释这个事实，即一个箱子特别重。
  • What was the consequence of the editor’s insistence on facts and statistics? 什么是编辑对事实和统计数字坚持的后果是什么？
  • Editors of newspapers and magazines often go to extremes to provide their readers with unimportant facts and statistics. 报纸和杂志的编辑常常走极端为了向读者提供一些无关紧要的事实和统计数字。

SEE> in·deed 确实, though 虽然, ac·tu·al·ly 其实

ODE> A thing that is known or proved to be true. – reality, actuality, certainty, factuality, certitude.

678. fac·tor 因素 ## 8

[’fæktər]n.因素；因数；因子vt.把 … 因素包括进去vi.作为因素

  • Three factors have caused these fish to grow so large: the warm water round the hot oil pipes under the sea; the plentiful supply of food thrown overboard by the crews on the rigs; the total absence of fishing boats around the oil rigs. 3个因素造成这些鱼能长得这么大：温水轮海下热油管道;由钻井平台工作人员抛到海里食品的供应充足;完全没有钻井平台周围的渔船。
  • Two factors weigh heavily against the effectiveness of scientific research in industry. 有两个因素严重地妨碍工业中科学研究的效率。
  • What factor helped to spread the disease of myxomatosis? 什么因素帮助传播粘液瘤的病？

SEE> rea·son 理由, thus 如此, hence 因此

ODE> A circumstance, fact, or influence that contributes to a result. – element, part, component, ingredient, strand, constituent, point, detail, item, feature, facet, aspect, characteristic, consideration, influence, circumstance, thing, determinant.

679. fac·to·ry 工厂 ## 9

[’fæktri]n.工厂；制造厂

  • In a few years the small workshop had become a large factory which employed seven hundred and twenty-eight people. 在几年之后，小铺子已经发展成了一个大工厂雇用728人。
  • Mrs. Brabante is talking to the manager of the local factory where the crop is processed. 布拉班特太太正在和当地工厂，其中作物加工的经理。
  • During a radio programme, a company of biscuit manufacturers once asked listeners to bake biscuits and send them to their factory. 在一个电台节目中，一个生产饼干请听众公司烘制饼干送到他们的工厂。

SEE> man·u·fac·tur·ing 制造业, man·u·fac·tur·er 制造商, shop 店

ODE> A building or group of buildings where goods are manufactured or assembled chiefly by machine. – works, plant, manufacturing complex, manufacturing facility, yard, mill, industrial unit, business unit.

680. fail 失败 ## 21

[feɪl]vi.失败；没做成某事；表现欠佳；用完；衰退vt.辜负；放弃；缺少；不及格n.不及格；没做成

  • I hope I haven’t failed. 我希望我没有失败。
  • I think I failed the French paper. 我想我的法语及不了。
  • If you receive a request like this, you cannot fail to obey it! 如果你收到这样的恳求，你是不会不遵照执行的！

SEE> fail·ure 失败, can·not 不能, must 必须

ODE> Be unsuccessful in achieving one’s goal. – be unsuccessful in, not pass.

681. fail·ure 失败 ## 3

[’feɪljər]n.失败；失败者；不及格；疏忽；失灵；未能；悲惨的事

  • The salvage operation had been a complete failure. 打捞工作彻底失败了。
  • If we remain inveterate smokers, it is only because we have so often experienced the frustration that results from failure. 如果我们仍然烟瘾大的人，那是因为我们经常遇到的挫折，从失败的结果。
  • As the time and cost of making a chip drop to a few days and a few hundred dollars, engineers may soon be free to let their imaginations soar without being penalized by expensive failures. 随着时间和制造一块芯片几天和几百美元的成本，工程师们可能很快可以任他们的想象驰骋而不会被昂贵的失败所惩罚。

SEE> fail 失败, in·a·bil·i·ty 无力, re·sult 结果

ODE> Lack of success. – lack of success, non-success, non-fulfilment, abortion, miscarriage, defeat, frustration, collapse, foundering, misfiring, coming to nothing, falling through.

682. fair 公平 ## 3

[fer]adj.公平的；晴朗的；美丽的; 相当的；（皮肤、毛发等）浅色的；白皙的n.展览会；市集adv.公平地，直接地

  • At a village fair, I decided to visit a fortune-teller called Madam Bellinsky. 在一个乡村集市上，我决定去拜访一位算命先生叫别林斯夫人。
  • As she walked away, I followed her out of the fair. 当她走开时，我也跟着她出了集市。
  • It had been purchased by a local authority so that an enormous pie could be baked for an annual fair. 它是由一个地方当局买下，这样一个巨大的馅饼可以烘焙的年度展览会。

SEE> in·deed 确实, rea·son·a·ble 合理的, more·o·ver 此外

ODE> Treating people equally without favouritism or discrimination. – just, equitable, fair-minded, open-minded, honest, upright, honourable, trustworthy.

683. fair·ly 相当地 ## 3

[’ferli]adv.公正地；相当地

  • In spite of this, many people are confident that ‘The Revealer’ may reveal something of value fairly soon. 尽管如此，很多人仍然相信“探宝器”很快就会探出值钱的东西。
  • On motorways you can, at least, travel fairly safely at high speeds, but more often than not, the greater part of the journey is spent on roads with few service stations and too much traffic. 在高速公路上就可以了，至少，行程相当安全的高速，但更多的，往往不是旅程的大部分时间都花在与几个服务站和交通也很拥挤。
  • It is fairly clear that the sleeping period must have some function, and because there is so much of it the function would seem to be important. 这是相当清楚的是，睡眠必然具有某种功能，因为有这么多的功能吧，似乎是很重要的。

SEE> quite 相当, relatively 相对地, rea·son·a·bly 相当地

ODE> With justice. – justly, equitably, impartially, without bias, without prejudice, without fear or favour, with an open mind, open-mindedly, even-handedly, objectively, neutrally, disinterestedly.

684. faith 信仰 ## 5

[feɪθ]n.信仰；信念；信任

  • After years of conditioning, most of us have developed an unshakable faith in railway timetables. 经过多年的适应，我们大多数人对火车时刻表产生了不可动摇的信念。
  • This is a sceptical age, but although our faith in many of the things in which our forefathers fervently believed has weakened, our confidence in the curative properties of the bottle of medicine remains the same as theirs. 这是一个怀疑一切的时代，可是虽然我们中的许多，使我们的祖先笃信的事情的信心有所减弱，我们对瓶装药品疗效的信心仍与祖先一样。
  • This modern faith in medicines is proved by the fact that the annual drug bill of the Health Services is mounting to astronomical figures and shows no signs at present of ceasing to rise. 这现代人对药物是由卫生部门的年度药费在停止上涨的目前安装到天文数字，且没有迹象事实证明。

SEE> be·lief 信仰, re·li·gion 宗教, be·lieve 相信

ODE> Complete trust or confidence in someone or something. – trust, belief, confidence, conviction, credence, reliance, dependence.

685. fall 下落 ## 25

[fɔːl]v.落下；倒下；来临n.秋天；落下；瀑布

  • I slipped and fell downstairs. 我滑倒了楼下。
  • The ball struck him so hard that he nearly fell into the water. 球击中了他，使他差点儿落入水中。
  • They feared that the mummy would fall to pieces when they cut it open, but fortunately this has not happened. 他们担心的是，木乃伊会变成碎片时，他们剖开，幸好这种情况并未发生。

SEE> be·gin·ning 开始, drop 掉落, rise 上升

ODE> Move from a higher to a lower level, typically rapidly and without control. – drop, drop down, plummet, descend, come down, go down, plunge, sink, dive, nosedive, tumble, pitch.

686. false 假 ## 2

[fɔːls]adj.假的；人造的；不真实的；错误的；虚伪的adv.欺骗地

  • What false impression does an ocean wave convey to the observer? 什么假象不海浪传达给观察者？
  • Even in his philosophical probings he cannot go behind these stereotypes; his very concepts of the true and the false will still have reference to his particular traditional customs. 甚至在哲学领域的探索中，人们也无法超越这些定型的框框。他的真与伪的概念依然参照特定的传统风俗。

SEE> mis·lead·ing , fake , mis·tak·en 错误

ODE> Not according with truth or fact; incorrect. – incorrect, untrue, wrong, erroneous, fallacious, faulty, flawed, distorted, inaccurate, inexact, imprecise, invalid, unfounded.

687. fame 名声 ## 5

[feɪm]n.名声；名望vt.使出名

  • Mendoza rose to fame swiftly after a boxing match when he was only fourteen years old. 门多萨成名拳击比赛后迅速时年仅十四岁。
  • The story of a poor family that acquired fame and fortune overnight, dramatically illustrates the power of the press. 一个贫穷的家庭是获得名利一夜的故事戏剧性地说明了新闻报道的威力。
  • The rise to fame was swift. 的声名鹊起是迅速的。

SEE> hall 大厅, suc·cess 成功, star·dom

ODE> The state of being known or talked about by many people, especially on account of notable achievements. – renown, celebrity, stardom, popularity, notability, note, distinction, prominence, esteem, importance, account, consequence, greatness, eminence, pre-eminence, glory, honour, illustriousness, prestige, stature, standing, reputation, repute.

688. fa·mil·i·ar 熟悉的 ## 3

[fə’mɪliər]adj.熟悉的；不拘礼节的；熟知的n.熟人；精灵

  • Oddly shaped forms that are suspended from the ceiling and move in response to a gust of wind are quite familiar to everybody. 被从天花板和移动响应于一阵风悬浮异形形式是大家十分熟悉。
  • But my father had described over and over again what we should see at every milestone, after leaving the nearest town, so that I was positive I should recognize it as familiar territory. 但是我的父亲描述了一遍又一遍，我们应该在每一个里程碑看到，离开最近的镇子后，让我很积极，我应该是很熟悉的领域。
  • We are so familiar with the fact that man ages, that people have for years assumed that the process of losing vigour with time, of becoming more likely to die the older we get, was something self-evident, like the cooling of a hot kettle or the wearing-out of a pair of shoes. 我们非常熟悉的事实，人的年龄，人们拥有多年假设失去活力随着时间的推移，成为更容易死亡，我们得到了较老的过程，是一件不言自明的，像一个滚烫的水壶的冷却或磨损出一双鞋的。

SEE> in·deed 确实, un·fa·mil·iar , in·stance 例子

ODE> Well known from long or close association. – familiar, known about, well known.

689. fam·i·ly 家庭 ## 20

[’fæməli]n.家庭；亲属；家族；子女；[生]科；语族；[化]族adj.家庭的；家族的；适合于全家的

  • Where is the Jones family? 哪里是琼斯的家人吗？
  • Mr. Jones is with his family. 琼斯先生同他的家人。
  • It has belonged to our family for a long time. 它已经属于我们的家庭很长一段时间。

SEE> fa·ther 父亲, moth·er 母亲, cou·ple 两人

ODE> A group of one or more parents and their children living together as a unit. – household, ménage.

690. fa·mous 著名的 ## 17

[’feɪməs]adj.著名的；有名的

  • She was a famous actress when I was still at school. 她是一个著名的演员，当我还在学校。
  • It is a famous beauty spot. 这是一个著名的风景胜地。
  • Topsail is a famous little boat. 桅帆是有名的小艇。

SEE> re·nowned , leg·end·ar·y , no·ta·ble

ODE> Known about by many people. – well known, celebrated, prominent, famed, popular, having made a name for oneself.

691. fan·cy 想要 ## 2

[’fænsi]adj.华丽装饰的；复杂的；引人注目的；时髦的；昂贵的；好的n.喜爱；幻想；想像力vt.想象；希望；迷恋

  • ‘Fancy meeting you here!’ “真想不到你在这里！”
  • I did not fancy the idea and I reluctantly followed Robert out of the room. 我不喜欢这个主意，所以我勉强跟着罗伯特走出了房间。

SEE> styl·ish , an·y·way 无论如何, el·e·gant 优雅

ODE> Elaborate in structure or decoration. – ornate, decorated, embellished, adorned, ornamented, fancy, over-elaborate, fussy, busy, ostentatious, extravagant, showy, baroque, rococo, florid, wedding-cake, gingerbread.

692. far 远 ## 27

[fɑːr]adv.远；(时间)久远；很；非常；远远；进展程度adj.较远的；最远的；远方的n.远方

  • He is finding his new work far more exciting. 他发觉自己的新工作令人兴奋得多。
  • ‘This is as far as we go.’ “这是据我们走。”
  • The vicar has been asked to have the tree cut down, but so far he has refused. 牧师一直问到有没有把树砍掉，但到目前为止，他已经拒绝了。

SEE> e·ven 甚至, though 虽然, but 但是

ODE> At, to, or by a great distance (used to indicate the extent to which one thing is distant from another) – a long way, a great distance, a good way, afar.

693. farm 农场 ## 18

[fɑːrm]n.农场；农田v.务农

  • In times of peace, when business was bad, Hawkwood and his men would march into a city-state and, after burning down a few farms, would offer to go away if protection money was paid to them. 在和平时期，当生意萧条时，霍克伍德和他的手下将步入一个城邦，纵火烧毁一两个农场后，将提供走开，如果保护金，支付给他们。
  • For years, villagers believed that Endley Farm was haunted. 多年来，村民们一直认为恩得利农场在闹鬼。
  • The farm was owned by two brothers, Joe and Bob Cox. 该农场是由两个兄弟，乔和鲍勃·考克斯拥有。

SEE> farm·er 农民, farm·ing 农业, dair·y

ODE> An area of land and its buildings, used for growing crops and rearing animals. – smallholding, holding, farmstead, steading, grange, plantation, estate.

694. fash·ion 时尚 ## 6

[’fæʃn]n.时尚；风格；样子vt.形成；塑造

  • They were in fashion last year and the year before last. 他们在时装去年和前年。
  • But they’re not in fashion this year. 但他们不是今年流行。
  • These shoes are in fashion now. 这些鞋现在很流行。

SEE> de·sign·er , glamour , styl·ish

ODE> A popular or the latest style of clothing, hair, decoration, or behaviour. – vogue, trend, craze, rage, mania, mode, fad, fancy, passing fancy.

695. fast 快速 ## 7

[fæst]adj.快的；迅速的；紧的；牢固的；放荡的adv.快速地；紧紧地；放荡地；深深地n.斋戒；禁食；系泊用具v.斋戒；禁食

  • How fast did the winning car go? 获胜的车也有多快？
  • Now you get out of here fast!’ 现在你离开这里快！”
  • Only one or two people have objected that the students will drive too fast! 只有一两个人提出反对意见，说学生们会把车开得太快！

SEE> slow 慢, quick 快, pa·ce 步伐

ODE> Moving or capable of moving at high speed. – speedy, quick, swift, rapid.

696. fat 胖的 ## 4

[fæt]adj.肥胖的；多脂肪的；丰满的n.脂肪；肥肉vt.使变胖

  • My friend, Hugh, has always been fat, but things got so bad recently that he decided to go on a diet. 我的朋友休一直很胖，但情况变得越发糟糕最近，他决定节食。
  • I rang the bell and was not surprised to see that Hugh was still as fat as ever. 我按响了门铃，并不感到惊讶地看到，休仍象以前一样胖。
  • On the other hand, your stomach would turn at the idea of frying potatoes in animal fat – the normally accepted practice in many northern countries. 在另一方面，你的胃会变成在动物脂肪油炸土豆的想法 - 在北方许多国家常接受的做法。

SEE> cho·les·ter·ol , eat 吃, where·as 而

ODE> A natural oily substance occurring in animal bodies, especially when deposited as a layer under the skin or around certain organs. – fatty tissue, fat cells, blubber, adipose tissue.

697. fa·ther 父亲 ## 20

[’fɑːðər]n.父亲；神父；祖先；创始人v.创造；当 … 的父亲

  • Their father takes them to school every day. 他们的父亲每天送他们上学。
  • My father was shocked. 我父亲大为吃惊。
  • It is being repaired by a friend of my father’s. 它是由我父亲的一个朋友修理。

SEE> son 儿子, grand·fa·ther 祖父, broth·er 哥哥

ODE> A man in relation to his child or children. – male parent, begetter, patriarch, paterfamilias.

698. fa·vour 赞同 ## 3

[’feɪvər]n.恩惠；支持；喜爱；偏爱v.支持；偏袒；有利于；长得像=favor（美）.

  • The man said that the pen was worth ￡50, but as a special favour, he would let me have it for ￡30. 那人说那支笔价值£50，但作为特别优惠，他愿意让我出30£。
  • When anyone opens a current account at a bank, he is lending the bank money, repayment of which he may demand at any time, either in cash or by drawing a cheque in favour of another person. 任何人在银行开一个活期账户，他在借钱给银行，还款，而他可以在任何时间要求，以现金或通过绘制有利于他人的支票。
  • It is one of the most unpleasant discoveries which we all make that we must decline in this way, that if we escape wars, accidents and diseases we shall eventually ‘die of old age’, and that this happens at a rate which differs little from person to person, so that there are heavy odds in favour of our dying between the ages of sixty-five and eighty. 这是最令人不快的发现之一，我们都使我们必须以这种方式下降，如果我们能避开战争，意外事故和疾病，我们最终也会“老死”，而这发生在一个速度，从不同的小人与人之间，以便有利于我们的65和八十岁之间死亡的重几率。

ODE> Approval, support, or liking for someone or something. – approval, approbation, commendation, esteem, goodwill, kindness, benevolence, friendliness.

699. fa·vour·ite 最喜爱的 ## 11

  • What is Susan’s favourite colour? 什么是苏珊最喜欢的颜色？
  • Pink’s her favourite colour. 粉红色是她最喜欢的颜色。
  • What is the favourite subject of conversation in England? 什么是谈话的英格兰最喜欢的科目？

ODE> Preferred to all others of the same kind. – best-loved, most-liked, favoured, dearest, treasured, pet, special, closest to one’s heart.

700. fear 恐惧 ## 15

[fɪr]n.担心；害怕；恐惧；【中药学】相畏v.害怕；担心；恐惧

  • If, at the time, the British had not feared invasion, it would have been completed. 如果，当时，英国并没有害怕入侵，就已经完成。
  • They feared that the mummy would fall to pieces when they cut it open, but fortunately this has not happened. 他们担心的是，木乃伊会变成碎片时，他们剖开，幸好这种情况并未发生。
  • At first, she decided to go to the police, but fearing that she would never see Rastus again – the letter had made that quite clear – she changed her mind. 起初，她决定去找警察，但又害怕再也见不到拉斯特斯 - 信上说得十分清楚 - 她改变了主意。

SEE> wor·ry 担心, a·fraid 害怕, fear·ful

ODE> An unpleasant emotion caused by the threat of danger, pain, or harm. – terror, fright, fearfulness, horror, alarm, panic, agitation, trepidation, dread, consternation, dismay, distress.

701. fea·ture 特征 ## 5

[’fiːtʃər]n.特征；特色；容貌；特写；故事片vt.以 … 为特色vi.起重要作用

  • Errors and uncertainties multiply, cascading upward through a chain of turbulent features, from dust devils and squalls up to continent-size eddies that only satellites can see. 错误和不可靠性，通过链条的动荡特性，从尘暴级联向上和暴风发展到大陆，大小漩涡，只有卫星上可以看到。
  • A burst of activity associated with the laying of submarine cables soon confirmed the Challenger’s observation that many parts of the ocean were two to three miles deep, and the existence of underwater features of considerable magnitude. 海底电缆的铺设相关活动的热潮很快证实了挑战者的观察结果：海洋中很多地方两到三英里深，和幅度相当水下的存在特征。
  • Since the sea covers the greater part of the earth’s surface, it is quite reasonable to regard the sea floor as the basic form of the crust of the earth, with, superimposed upon it, the continents, together with the islands and other features of the oceans. 既然海洋覆盖了地球表面的大部分时间里，这是很合理的与岛屿和其他功能把海床看作地壳的基本形式，叠加，那么，大陆，一起海洋。

SEE> ad·di·tion 加, no·ta·ble , in·stance 例子

ODE> A distinctive attribute or aspect of something. – characteristic, attribute, quality, property, trait, mark, hallmark, trademark.

702. fee 费用 ## 2

[fiː]n.费用；酬金

  • There are times when we would willingly give everything we possess to save our lives, yet we might grudge paying a surgeon a high fee for offering us precisely this service. 有些时候，我们愿意付出我们拥有一切，拯救我们的生命，但我们可能会吝惜付外科医生高的费用而为我们提供这种服务。
  • Municipalities naturally want to secure the campers’ site fees and other custom. 市政当局当然希望获得露营者的场地费和其他自定义。

703. feed 喂养 ## 6

[fiːd]vt.喂养；饲养；靠 … 为生；向 … 提供vi.吃饲料；进餐n.一餐；饲料；饲养

  • Fortunately for them, the Bank of England has a team called Mutilated Ladies which deals with claims from people who fed their money to a machine or to their dog. 幸运的是，英国央行有一个队叫残钞鉴别其与谁把钱塞进机器或塞给狗的人提出的索赔要求。
  • It has been found that certain bats emit squeaks and by receiving the echoes, they can locate and steer clear of obstacles – or locate flying insects on which they feed. 人们已经发现，某些蝙蝠发出尖叫声并靠接受回响来锁定和避免障碍物 - 或者找到它们赖以飞虫。
  • It tires not, nor does it boast of its power; but belongs to the air, travelling it may be six thousand miles to and from its northern nesting home, feeding its flown young as it flies, and slipping through a medium that seems to help its passage even when the wind is adverse. 它的轮胎没有，也不会夸耀它的力量;但属于空气，旅行也可能是6,000英里，距离北方做窝的家，喂养它的飞行年轻，因为它苍蝇，并通过似乎帮助其通过，即使风是不利的介质打滑。

SEE> hun·gry 饥饿, eat 吃, con·sume

ODE> Give food to. – give food to, provide food for, provide for, cater for, prepare food for, cook for, make a meal for, wine and dine.

704. feel 感觉 ## 33

  • I feel awful. 我感觉糟透了。
  • I feel very tired. 我感觉很累。

SEE> feel·ing 感觉, re·al·ly 真的, think 想

ODE> Be aware of (a person or object) through touching or being touched. – perceive, sense, detect, discern, make out, notice, observe, identify.

705. feel·ing 感觉 ## 3

[’fiːlɪŋ]n.感觉；知觉；气氛；鉴赏力；反感adj.有感情的；富于同情心的；含情脉脉的（复）feelings：感情.

  • The hardened professional smuggler, on the other hand, is never troubled by such feelings, even if he has five hundred gold watches hidden in his suitcase. 而老练的职业走私犯另一方面，从未被这样的感情困扰，就算他有500个金表藏在他的手提箱。
  • On the village green, where you pick up sides and no feeling of local patriotism is involved, it is possible to play simply for the fun and exercise: but as soon as a the question of prestige arises, as soon as you feel that you and some larger unit will be disgraced if you lose, the most savage combative instincts are aroused. 在乡间的草坪上，当你拿起两侧，没有当地的爱国主义情绪受影响，则可以简单地为了娱乐和锻炼：你觉得，但只要威信的问题是，一旦你和如果你失去了一些大的单位将被蒙羞，最野蛮的好斗本能就会激发出来。
  • In the young there is a justification for this feeling. 年轻人有这种感觉的理由。

SEE> feel 感觉, sense 感, ob·vi·ous·ly 显然

ODE> An emotional state or reaction. – love, care, affection, fondness, tenderness, warmth, warmness, emotion, sentiment.

  • The gaoler looked on eagerly, anxious to see if his fellow actor had at last learnt his lines. 热切地看着狱卒，急于想了解他的同事是否男主角终于了解到他的台词。

  • Men accustomed to struggling for survival against the elements and Indians were bewildered by politicians, bankers and businessmen, and unhorsed by fences, laws and alien taboos. 习惯作斗争以求和印第安人生存的拓荒者被政客，银行家和商人搞得晕头转向，最后被圈地，法律和外来的清规戒律unhorsed。

  • A Festival for the Dead is held once a year in Japan. 一种死节在日本举行一年一次。
  • This festival is a cheerful occasion, for on this day, the dead are said to return to their homes and they are welcomed by the living. 这个节日是个欢乐的日子，因为在这一天，据说死去的人返回他们的家园，他们被生活的欢迎。

  • However, it was his turn to be surprised, for the woman’s eyes immediately lit up and she fetched several bottles which she placed on the counter for Harry to inspect. 然而，轮到他自己吃惊，对于女人的眼睛立刻亮了起来，拿出几瓶东西放在柜台上让哈里挑选。
  • Her first impulse was to go round all the rooms looking for the thieves, but then she decided that at her age it might be more prudent to have someone with her, so she went to fetch the porter from his basement. 她的第一个冲动就是去各个房间搜寻一下窃贼，但后来一想，像她这个年龄可能更谨慎地找个人一起去，让她来从他的地下室看门。

  • Late in the afternoon, the boys put up their tent in the middle of a field. 傍晚时分，孩子们搭起了帐篷在野外的中间。
  • It was raining heavily and they found that a stream had formed in the field. 雨下得很大，他们发现，甲流已在该领域形成。
  • The stream wound its way across the field and then flowed right under their tent! 那小溪弯弯曲曲穿过田野，然后右键他们的帐篷底下流！

712. fif·teen 十五 ## 9

  • It’s only eight fifteen. 这只是8点15分。
  • Fifteen minutes passed and then, at five to twelve, the clock stopped. 十五分钟过去了，而就在11点55分时，大钟停了下来。

ODE> Equivalent to the product of three and five; one more than fourteen, or five more than ten; 15. –

713. fif·teenth 第十五 ## 2

[ˌfɪf’tiːnθ]num.第十五

  • The temple which the archaeologists explored was used as a place of worship from the fifteenth century B.C. 考古工作者考察的这座庙宇从第十五世纪公元前一个礼拜的地方
  • The body of one statue was found among remains dating from the fifteenth century B.C. 一尊雕像，她的躯体是在公元前15世纪的历史文物中发现公元前

715. fif·ty 五十 ## 15

[’fɪfti]num.五十

  • Three pounds fifty pence, please. 3英镑50便士，请。
  • The tree was planted near the church fifty years ago, but it is only in recent years that it has gained an evil reputation. 该树是50年前栽在教堂附近的，但它只是在最近几年才得到了一个坏名声。
  • Did George get anything for his fifty pence? 乔治没有得到他的50便士什么？

ODE> The number equivalent to the product of five and ten; half of one hundred; 50. –

716. fight 战斗 ## 7

[faɪt]n.战斗；打架；斗志vt.打架；对抗vi.奋斗；斗争；争吵

  • Firemen had been fighting the forest fire for nearly three weeks before they could get it under control. 消防员已经场森林大火搏斗了将近3个星期才可以把火势控制住。
  • In those days, boxers fought with bare fists for prize money. 在那些日子里，拳击手，为争夺奖金赤手空拳的战斗。
  • The two men quarrelled bitterly and it was clear that the argument could only be settled by a fight. 这两人争吵不休，它很清楚，论据只能通过战斗来解决。

SEE> fight·ing 战斗, strug·gle 斗争, bat·tle 战斗

ODE> Take part in a violent struggle involving the exchange of physical blows or the use of weapons. – violent, combative, aggressive, pugnacious, truculent, belligerent, bellicose, disputatious, antagonistic, argumentative, hawkish.

717. fig·ure 身影 ## 13

[’fɪɡjər]n.图形；数字；外形；体型；形状；人物；塑像；图表；（冰上表演动作的）花样v.是重要部分；认为；演算；领会到

  • They also found something which the X-ray plates did not show: a small wax figure of the god Duamutef. 他们还发现了X光片所没有显示：神多姆泰夫的小蜡像。
  • The actual figure was made of copper supported by a metal framework which had been especially constructed by Eiffel. 实际数字是由通过已经由艾菲尔特制的金属框架支撑铜。
  • In the torchlight, he caught sight of a figure whom he immediately recognized as Bill Wilkins, our local grocer. 借着电筒光，他看见一个人，马上认出比尔·威尔金斯，我们当地的杂货店主的。

SEE> same 相同, though 虽然, ac·tu·al·ly 其实

ODE> A number, especially one which forms part of official statistics or relates to the financial performance of a company. – statistic, number, integer, quantity, amount, level, total, sum.

718. file 文件 ## 2

[faɪl]n.档案；卷宗；文件；锉刀，指甲锉vt.把 … 归档；提出(申请书、议案等)

  • What could not be reported in the official files? 什么不能在官方文件中报告？
  • The fact that the policeman was prejudiced against foreigners could not be recorded in the official files. 那警察在遭歧视外国人的事实不能被记录在官方文件中。
