869. hide 隐藏 ## 16

[haɪd]v.藏；隐瞒；遮避vt.鞭打n.兽皮

  • After he was arrested, the man admitted hiding in the box before the plane left London. 他被逮捕后，男子承认躲在盒子在飞机离开伦敦前。
  • He led me into his room and hurriedly hid a large parcel under his desk. 他把我带进了他的房间，慌忙把桌子下面把一个大包藏。
  • The machine was used in a cave near the seashore where – it is said – pirates used to hide gold. 据说 - - 用来隐藏黄金海盗的机器是在海边附近的一个山洞里使用。

SEE> con·ceal , dis·guise , hid·den

ODE> Put or keep out of sight. – conceal, secrete, put in a hiding place, put out of sight, camouflage.

870. high 高 ## 23

[haɪ]adj.高的；高尚的；高级的；高度的；全盛的adv.高；奢侈地；音调高n.高水平；高气压；（麻醉品带来的）快感

  • She knew she was near the shore because the light was high up on the cliffs. 她知道自己已经接近岸边了，因为那灯光是在高高的峭壁上。
  • The city at one time must have been prosperous, for it enjoyed a high level of civilization. 在这座古城肯定一度很繁荣，因为它曾享有的文明高度。
  • Houses – often three storeys high – were built of stone. 房子 - 这些通常有三层高 - 用石块修建的。

SEE> low 低, well 好, school 学校

ODE> Of great vertical extent. – tall, lofty, towering, soaring, elevated, giant, big.

871. high·ly 高度 ## 7

[’haɪli]adv.高度地；很；非常；赞许地

  • Meanwhile, he founded a highly successful Academy and even Lord Byron became one of his pupils. 同时，他建立了一个非常成功，连拜伦勋爵也成了他的学生之一。
  • A famous actor in a highly successful play was once cast in the role of an aristocrat who had been imprisoned in the Bastille for twenty years. 在一个非常成功的演出中，一位著名演员有一次被选派在谁曾在巴士底狱被关押了20年的贵族的角色。
  • The parquet floors shone like mirrors; highly polished silver was displayed in gleaming glass cabinets; even my uncle’s huge collection of books was kept miraculously free from dust. 洁如镜的镶木地板;高度抛光的银陈列在明亮的玻璃橱柜;连姑夫的大量藏书保持奇迹般地一尘不染。

SEE> ex·treme·ly 非常地, most 最, ver·y 非常

ODE> At or to a high degree or level. – very, most, really, thoroughly, extremely, exceedingly, particularly, tremendously, hugely, greatly, decidedly, distinctly, exceptionally, immensely, eminently, supremely, inordinately, singularly, extraordinarily, vastly, overly.

872. hill 小山 ## 5

[hɪl]n.小山；丘陵；山冈；斜坡vt.堆起；培土

  • It is between two hills. 这是两座小山之间。
  • Now, smoke still rose up from the warm ground over the desolate hills. 现在，浓烟仍从发热的地面上荒凉的山丘上。
  • Winter was coming on and the hills threatened the surrounding villages with destruction, for heavy rain would not only wash away the soil but would cause serious floods as well. 冬季即将来临，这些山丘威胁周围村庄具有毁灭性的，因为大雨不仅会冲走土壤，而且还会引起严重的水灾。

SEE> near·by 附近, once 一次, where 哪里

ODE> A naturally raised area of land, not as high or craggy as a mountain. – high ground, rising ground, prominence, eminence, elevation, rise, hillock, mound, mount, knoll, hummock, tor, tump, fell, pike, mesa.

873. him·self 他自己 ## 23

[hɪm’self]pron.他自己

  • As I soon learnt, he was English himself! 我很快了解到，他自己就是个英国人！
  • He explained that his diet was so strict that he had to reward himself occasionally. 他解释说，他的饮食控制得太严格了，以致不得不偶尔奖赏自己。
  • As the neighbours complained of the noise, my husband spent weeks training him to press his paw on the latch to let himself in. 由于邻居们的噪音，我的丈夫花了几个星期的训练他按他的门闩爪子让自己英寸

SEE> him 他, he 他, her·self 她自己

ODE> Used as the object of a verb or preposition to refer to a male person or animal previously mentioned as the subject of the clause. –

874. hire 租用 ## 3

[’haɪər]v.雇用；出租n.租金；雇用；租用

  • Whenever the Italian city-states were at war with each other, Hawkwood used to hire his soldiers to princes who were willing to pay the high price he demanded. 每当意大利城邦在战争与对方，霍克沃德用于雇佣他的士兵诸侯谁愿意付出高昂的代价，他的要求。
  • I hired a car the day after landing and bought a comprehensive book of maps, which I found most helpful on the cross-country journey, but which I did not think I should need on the last stage. 我该租了一辆车着陆后，买了地图，这是我发现的越野之旅最有帮助的全面的书，但我不认为我应该需要在最后阶段。
  • Economy is one powerful motive for camping, since after the initial outlay upon equipment, or through hiring it, the total expense can be far less than the cost of hotels. 经济是露营的一个主要动机。因为在设备的初始费用后，或是租借，总费用可能比经济型酒店的成本远不如。

SEE> em·ploy 雇用, re·cruit , ask 问

ODE> Obtain the temporary use of (something) for an agreed payment. – rent, lease, charter, pay for the use of.

875. his·to·ry 历史 ## 11

[’hɪstri]n.历史；历史学；对过去事情的记载；过去的事

  • One of the most colourful figures in boxing history was Daniel Mendoza, who was born in 1764. 一个拳击史上最引人注目的人物之一是丹尼尔门多萨，谁是出生于1764年。
  • Future historians will be in a unique position when they come to record the history of our own times. 未来的历史学家会在一个独特的位置，当他们来写我们时代的历史。
  • Even seemingly insignificant remains can shed interesting light on the history of early man. 即使看起来微不足道的遗物，也可能人类早期历史的一些有趣的内容。

SEE> his·tor·i·cal 历史的, ev·er 曾经, ex·am·ple 例子

ODE> The study of past events, particularly in human affairs. – the past, former times, historical events, days of old, the old days, the good old days, time gone by, bygone days, yesterday, antiquity.

876. hit 击中 ## 3

[hɪt]vi.打（击）；袭击；达到vt.要求；打（击）；碰撞；偶然发现；符合n.讽刺；打（击）；冲撞；成功

  • This increases their air-resistance and reduces the shock of impact when they hit the ground. 这样就加大了空气阻力，并减少冲击的冲击，当他们击中了地面。
  • An electric razor that meets the European Union’s safety standards must be approved by American testers before it can be sold in the United States, and an American-made dialysis machine needs the EU’s okay before it hits the market in Europe. 符合欧盟安全标准的电动剃须刀必须得到美国检测人员的认可，方可在美国销售，和一个美国制造的透析仪也要得到欧盟的还好它击中欧洲市场之前。
  • He no sooner recovers his equilibrium than the next porpoise comes along and hits him another crack. 他刚一恢复他的平衡比下江豚走来，并击中他另一个打击。

SEE> off 离开, just 刚刚, when 什么时候

ODE> Bring one’s hand or a tool or weapon into contact with (someone or something) quickly and forcefully. – strike, slap, smack, cuff, punch, beat, thrash, thump, batter, belabour, drub, hook, pound, smash, slam, welt, pummel, hammer, bang, knock, swat, whip, flog, cane, sucker-punch, rain blows on, give someone a beating, give someone a drubbing, give someone a good beating, give someone a good drubbing, box someone’s ears.

877. hob·by 爱好 ## 7

[’hɑːbi]n.业余爱好

  • For him, this will be an entirely new hobby. 对他来说，这将是一种全新的爱好。
  • Collecting as a serious hobby is quite different and has many advantages. 收集作为一个严肃的业余爱好是一回事，它具有许多优点。
  • This hobby educates one not only in the chosen subject, but also in general matters which have some bearing on it. 这种爱好灌输一个不仅在所选择的主题，而且在其中有一些关于它的轴承一般事项。

SEE> pas·time , be·sides , ob·ses·sion

ODE> An activity done regularly in one’s leisure time for pleasure. – pastime, leisure activity, leisure pursuit, leisure interest, amateur interest, sideline, diversion, avocation, divertissement, enthusiasm.

878. hold 拿着 ## 26

[hoʊld]v.拿着；控制；容纳；握住；持有；保持；掌握；认为；举行n.握住；控制；把握；立足点；延误；影响

  • The Olympic Games will be held in our country in four years’ time. 奥运会将在我们国家在四年时间内持有。
  • The Games will be held just outside the capital and the whole area will be called ‘Olympic City’. 该游戏将在城外举行的首都，整个地区将被称作“奥林匹克城”。
  • We are all very excited and are looking forward to the Olympic Games because they have never been held before in this country. 我们都非常兴奋，因为他们从来没有在这个国家举行前都期待着奥运会。

SEE> take 拿取, put 放, give 给

ODE> Grasp, carry, or support with one’s arms or hands. – clasp, hold on to, clutch, grasp, grip, clench, cling to, have in one’s hand.

879. hole 孔洞 ## 11

[hoʊl]n.洞；孔；穴；漏洞；困境v.挖洞；掘坑；进洞

  • I sat down on one of those modern chairs with holes in it and waited. 我坐下来的新式椅子一个有孔和等待。
  • Meanwhile, my tongue was busy searching out the hole where the tooth had been. 与此同时，我的舌头正在忙着寻找我拔掉牙的那个洞。
  • Very excited, the party dug a hole two feet deep. 很激动，就地挖了一个洞深更生。

SEE> woods , stretch 伸展, ac·tu·al·ly 其实

ODE> A hollow place in a solid body or surface. – pit, ditch, trench, cavity, crater, depression, hollow.

881. home 家 ## 70

[hoʊm]n.家；家庭；收容所；栖息地；发源地adv.在家；回家；在国内；回国；正中目标adj.家用的；国内的；总部的；（比赛）主场的v.提供住处；朝向

  • Mrs. Sawyer stays at home every day. 索耶夫人每天呆在家里。
  • In the evening, the children come home from school. 到了晚上，孩子们放学回家。
  • They arrive home early. 他们到家很早。

ODE> The place where one lives permanently, especially as a member of a family or household. – place of residence, accommodation, property, a roof over one’s head.

882. home·work 家庭作业 ## 4

[’hoʊmwɜːrk]n.家庭作业

  • When do the children do their homework? 什么时候孩子们做功课？
  • At night, the children always do their homework. 晚上，孩子们总是做作业。
  • In the evening, the children usually do their homework, but this evening, they are not doing their homework. 到了晚上，孩子们通常是做作业，而今天晚上，他们没做功课。

883. hon·est 诚实 ## 3

[’ɑːnɪst]adj.诚实的；正直的；坦率的

  • People are not so honest as they once were. 人们不再像以前那样诚实他们曾经是。
  • The last note said: ‘I am 100 per cent honest now!’ 最后的那张字条上写道：“我是100％的诚信了！”
  • Even really honest people are often made to feel guilty. 甚至是最诚实的人也常弄得觉得有罪似的。

SEE> straight·for·ward , im·por·tant·ly 重要的, trust·wor·thy

ODE> Free of deceit; truthful and sincere. – truthful, sincere, candid, frank, direct, open, forthright, straight, straightforward, genuine, blunt, plain-spoken, plain-speaking, matter-of-fact, outspoken, as straight as a die, straight from the shoulder.

884. honour 荣誉 ## 2

[’ɑːnər]n.荣誉；头衔；荣幸vt.尊敬；信守承诺；方形舞中鞠躬致敬

  • Dressed up as Father Christmas and accompanied by a ‘guard of honour’ of six pretty girls, he set off down the main street of the city riding a baby elephant called Jumbo. 他打扮成圣诞老人，在由6个漂亮姑娘组成的“仪仗队”，他掀起，沿着城里骑着名叫Jumbo的小象的主要街道。
  • A great many former pupils will be attending a farewell dinner in his honour next Thursday. 很多老学生将参加在他的荣誉下周四的告别宴会。

885. hope 希望 ## 23

886. hor·i·zon·tal 横 ## 2

[ˌhɔːrə’zɑːntl]adj.水平的；横的n.水平线；水平面

  • The basic features include a crest (the highest point of the wave), a trough (the lowest point), a height (the vertical distance from the trough to the crest), a wave length (the horizontal distance between two wave crests), and a period (which is the time it takes a wave crest to travel one wave length). 的基本特征包括浪峰（波的最高点），波谷（最低点），高度（从波谷到波峰的垂直距离），波长（两个波峰之间的水平距离），和周期（这是它需要一个波峰到旅行一个波长的时间）。
  • The apparatus thus described, however, records only the horizontal component of the wave movement, which is, in fact, much more complicated. 该装置如此描述的，然而，只记录波运动，这是，在实际上，更复杂的水平分量。

SEE> ver·ti·cal 垂直, par·al·lel 平行, hence 因此

ODE> Parallel to the plane of the horizon; at right angles to the vertical. – parallel, level, even, straight, plane, flush.

887. hor·ror 恐惧 ## 3

[’hɔːrər]n.恐怖；战栗；厌恶；震惊adj.恐怖的

  • Below, the captain realized to his horror that the Titanic was sinking rapidly, for five of her sixteen watertight compartments had already been flooded! 下面，实现了他惊恐的队长是泰坦尼克号正在急速下沉，16个密封舱已有5个进水。
  • No matter how much we like honey, or how much we have read about the uncanny sense of direction which bees possess, we have a horror of being stung. 无论多少，我们似蜜，或有多少我们如何阅读方向的不可思议感，这蜜蜂具有，我们有害怕被蜂蜇。
  • To her horror he said that she was two hours too soon. 为了她的惊恐，他说，她在两小时太快。

SEE> mov·ie 电影, fan·ta·sy , thrill·er

ODE> An intense feeling of fear, shock, or disgust. – terror, fear, fear and trembling, fearfulness, fright, alarm, panic, dread, trepidation.

888. horse 马 ## 3

[hɔːrs]n.马vt.骑马adj.马的

  • It had a head like a horse, big blue eyes, shining silver skin, and a bright red tail. 它有一个头似马，蓝色的大眼睛，闪闪发光的银色皮肤，还有一条鲜红色的尾巴。
  • They never become submissive like dogs and horses. 他们从来没有变得顺从不像狗和马。
  • Next came a horse, swimming bravely, but we were afraid that the strength of the current would prevent its landing anywhere before it became exhausted. 接下来是一匹马，勇敢地游着，但我们担心的是，当前的力量将使它在任何地方降落前就筋疲力尽了。

  • While John Gilbert was in hospital, he asked his doctor to tell him whether his operation had been successful, but the doctor refused to do so. 当约翰吉尔伯特住院的时候，他问医生告诉他，他的手术是否成功，但医生拒绝这样做。

890. hot 热 ## 8

  • It’s always hot in June, July and August. 它总是热的六月，七月和八月。
  • Because the weather was very hot, he carried the bed on to the roof of his house. 由于天气很热，他便把床搬到了他的屋顶上。
  • Three factors have caused these fish to grow so large: the warm water round the hot oil pipes under the sea; the plentiful supply of food thrown overboard by the crews on the rigs; the total absence of fishing boats around the oil rigs. 3个因素造成这些鱼能长得这么大：温水轮海下热油管道;由钻井平台工作人员抛到海里食品的供应充足;完全没有钻井平台周围的渔船。

896. huge 巨大 ## 15

[hjuːdʒ]adj.巨大的；庞大的；极大的

  • The seed was sprayed over the ground in huge quantities by aeroplanes. 种子是由飞机撒在地面巨大的数量。
  • Four days after setting out, while the Titanic was sailing across the icy waters of the North Atlantic, a huge iceberg was suddenly spotted by a lookout. 列明，而泰坦尼克号在北大西洋冰冷的海域航行四天后，一个巨大的冰山突然，了望员发现。
  • Two great towers support four huge cables. 两座巨塔支撑着四个巨大的电缆。

ODE> Extremely large; enormous. – enormous, vast, immense, very large, very big, great, massive, cosmic, colossal, prodigious, gigantic, gargantuan, mammoth, monumental, tremendous, stupendous.

[’hjuːmən]adj.人的；人类的；有人性的；人本性的n.人；人类

  • It immediately ran away when she saw it, and experts confirmed that a puma will not attack a human being unless it is cornered. 它就立刻逃走了，当她看见了，专家证实，除非被逼得走投无路，美洲狮不会攻击人类。
  • Such is human nature, that a great many people are often willing to sacrifice higher pay for the privilege of becoming white-collar workers. 这就是人的本性，一个伟大的很多人往往愿意放弃高薪，以便成为白领的特权。
  • Cats never fail to fascinate human beings. 猫总能引起人们的极大兴趣。

898. hu·mour 幽默 ## 7

  • Everybody admires him for his great sense of humour – everybody, that is, except his six-year-old daughter, Jenny. 人人都钦佩他那绝妙的幽默感 - 人人，就是说，除他6岁的女儿珍妮。
  • What is the basis of ‘sick’ humour? 什么是“病态”幽默的基础是什么？
  • The sense of humour is mysteriously bound up with national characteristics. 幽默感是神秘莫测的具有民族特色。

ODE> The quality of being amusing or comic, especially as expressed in literature or speech. – comical aspect, comic side, funny side, comedy, funniness, hilarity, jocularity.

  • It costs five hundred pounds. 它的售价是500英镑。
  • It’s only three hundred pounds. 这只是三百斤。

SEE> thou·sand 千, fif·ty 五十, twen·ty 二十

ODE> The number equivalent to the product of ten and ten; ten more than ninety; 100. – century.

900. hun·gry 饥饿 ## 3

[’hʌŋɡri]adj.饥饿的；渴望的

  • They were all hungry and the food smelled good. 他们都饿了，饭菜散发出阵阵香味。
  • As they are expected to be hungry after their long journey, food is laid out for them. 因为预料到是他们经过长途跋涉后感到饥饿，因此给他们准备了。
  • It is impossible to make more than the wildest guess at how many they kill, but they are hungry creatures, not content with only three meals a day. 这是不可能做出比最大胆的猜测更在他们杀了多少，但它们是吃不饱的动物，而不是满足于一日三餐。

SEE> thirst·y 口渴, starv·ing , des·per·ate·ly 拼命

ODE> Feeling or showing the need for food. – ravenous, empty, hollow, faint from hunger.

901. hunt 狩猎 ## 3

[hʌnt]v.狩猎；打猎；搜索n.狩猎；追捕；搜寻

  • The hunt for the puma began in a small village where a woman picking blackberries saw ‘a large cat’ only five yards away from her. 美洲狮狩猎开始在一个小村庄，一位妇女在采摘黑莓时的看见“一只大猫”，离她仅5码远。
  • The hunt went on for several weeks, but the puma was not caught. 搜寻工作进行了好几个星期，但始终未能逮住那只美洲狮。
  • He may hunt, beg, or steal occasionally to keep himself alive; he may even, in times of real need, do a little work; but he will never sacrifice his freedom. 他可能会去打猎，乞讨，偶尔偷来保持自己活着;他甚至可能在确实需要的时候，做了一点工作;但他决不会牺牲自由。

SEE> hunt·ing 狩猎, chase 追, pre·sum·a·bly 想必

ODE> Pursue and kill (a wild animal) for sport or food. – chase, give chase to, pursue, stalk, course, hunt down, run down.

902. hunt·ing 狩猎 ## 2

[’hʌntɪŋ]n.打猎；搜寻[电子学]速度偏差.

  • The nomads who made these markings lived by hunting and fishing during the last Ice Age which began about 35,000 B.C. 谁做这些标记的游牧民族开始约35,000公元前最后一个冰河时期生活以狩猎，捕鱼
  • It has long been known that the hunting scenes depicted on walls were not simply a form of artistic expression. 人们早就知道，画在墙上的狩猎图景并不是单纯的艺术表现形式。

SEE> hunt 狩猎, pre·sum·a·bly 想必, deer

ODE> The activity of hunting wild animals or game. – blood sports, field sports, stalking, trapping, coursing, fox hunting, the chase.

903. hur·ry 匆忙 ## 8

[’hɜːri]v.匆忙；催促；赶紧n.匆忙；仓促；急忙

  • Hurry up, Sam! 快点，萨姆！
  • I hurried to the ticket office. 我匆匆赶到售票处。
  • Just then, a man hurried to the ticket office. 就在这时，一个男子匆匆奔向售票处。

SEE> an·y·way 无论如何, when·ev·er 每当, sure·ly 一定

ODE> Move or act with great haste. – be quick, hurry up, move quickly, go fast, hasten, make haste, speed, speed up, lose no time, press on, push on, run, dash, rush, hurtle, dart, race, fly, flash, shoot, streak, bolt, bound, blast, charge, chase, career, scurry, scramble, scamper, scuttle, sprint, gallop, go hell for leather, go like lightning.

904. hurt 使受伤 ## 3

[hɜːrt]vt.损害；伤害；使疼痛vi.疼痛；造成损失n.创伤；伤害；打击

  • Have you hurt yourself? 你有没有伤到自己？
  • I think that I’ve hurt my back. 我认为我已经伤害了我的背。
  • If parents were prepared for this adolescent reaction, and realized that it was a sign that the child was growing up and developing valuable powers of observation and independent judgment, they would not be so hurt, and therefore would not drive the child into opposition by resenting and resisting it. 如果家长对青少年的这种反应准备，并且意识到这是一个迹象，表明孩子正在成长和发展的观察和独立判断有价值的权力，他们就不会感到如此伤心，所以也就不会由于怨恨而把孩子推到对立面和抵御它。

SEE> se·ri·ous·ly 严肃地, wor·ried 担心的, bad·ly 惨

ODE> Cause pain or injury to. – injure, wound, damage, disable, incapacitate, impair, maim, mutilate, cause injury to, cause pain to.

905. hus·band 丈夫 ## 26

[’hʌzbənd]n.丈夫

  • I like lamb, but my husband doesn’t. 我喜欢羔羊肉，但我丈夫不喜欢。
  • My husband likes steak, but he doesn’t like chicken. 我丈夫喜欢牛排，但他不喜欢鸡。
  • When my husband was going into the dining room this morning, he dropped some coins on the floor. 当我的丈夫走进饭厅今天上午，他掉在地上一些硬币。

SEE> wife 妻子, fa·ther 父亲, moth·er 母亲

ODE> A married man considered in relation to his spouse. – spouse, partner, mate, consort, man.

906. ice 冰 ## 10

[aɪs]n.冰；糖霜；冰淇淋；冷淡；钻石v.用冰裹；冰镇；结冰；制冷；涂糖霜

  • There’s an ice cream man. 有个卖冰淇淋的。
  • Two ice creams please. 请拿两份冰淇淋。
  • These ice creams are nice. 这些冰淇淋真好吃。

SEE> hock·ey , fro·zen 冻结的, snow 雪

ODE> Frozen water, a brittle transparent crystalline solid. – frozen water.

907. i·de·a 想法 ## 27

[aɪ’diːə]n.主意；想法；印象；意见；看法；观念；感觉；目标

  • That’s a good idea, Charlotte. 这是个好主意，夏洛特。
  • Then she had an idea. 后来她有了一个主意。
  • Apparently, there is a good deal of truth in this idea. 显然，有真理的这个想法很划算。

SEE> no·tion , thought 想法, con·cept 概念

ODE> A thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action. – plan, design, scheme, project, proposal, proposition, suggestion, recommendation, aim, intention, objective, object, purpose, end, goal, target.

908. i·de·al 理想的 ## 8

[aɪ’diːəl]adj.理想的；完美的；空想的；观念的n.理想；典范；目标

  • Of course, New York is the ideal place for such an interesting study, because there is no shortage of tall buildings. 当然，纽约是进行这种有趣的试验的理想场所，因为有高大建筑物的不乏其人。
  • Even if you travel in ideal weather, sea journeys take a long time. 即使你旅行的天气理想，海上旅行所花费很长的时间。
  • While she always criticized the fickleness of human nature, she carried on an unrelenting search for the ideal servant to the end of her days, even after she had been sadly disillusioned by Bessie. 她一方面总是批评人的本性的变化无常，她却在为理想的仆人，她的日子结束了不懈搜索，即使她贝茜已黯然破灭。

SEE> suit·a·ble 适当, per·fect 完美, hence 因此

ODE> Satisfying one’s conception of what is perfect; most suitable. – perfect, best possible, consummate, supreme, absolute, complete, copybook, flawless, faultless, without fault, exemplary, classic, archetypal, model, ultimate, quintessential.

909. i·den·ti·fy 确认 ## 2

[aɪ’dentɪfaɪ]vt.鉴定；识别，辨认出，认出；认明；把…看成一样vi.认同；感同身受

  • ‘So long as there’s something to identify, we will give people their money back,’ said a spokeswoman for the Bank. “只要有东西可供识别，我们会给人回他们的钱，”银行的一位女发言人说。
  • He mentally visualizes a complex form from all round itself; he knows while he looks at one side what the other side is like; he identifies himself with its centre of gravity, its mass, its weight; he realizes its volume, as the space that the shape displaces in the air. 他的大脑从全面本身就是一个复杂的形式;他知道当他看着一面是什么对方等;他把自己与形体的重心，它的质量，它的重量;他意识到物体的体积，其形状在空气中所占的空间。

SEE> lo·cate 定位, dis·tin·guish 区分, find 找到

ODE> Establish or indicate who or what (someone or something) is. – recognize, single out, pick out, spot, point out, pinpoint, pin down, put one’s finger on, put a name to, name, place, know, know again, know by sight, discern, distinguish, discover, find, locate.

910. i·den·ti·ty 身份 ## 2

[aɪ’dentəti]n.一致；身份；特征

  • Despite her great age, she was very graceful indeed, but, so far, the archaeologists have been unable to discover her identity. 尽管上了年纪，她很优雅确实，但是，到目前为止，考古学家一直未能发现她的身份。
  • For one thing, being a problem gives you a certain identity, and that is one of the things the young are busily engaged in seeking. 一方面，是一个问题给你一定的身份，那就是事物的年轻人所热衷追求的。

SEE> i·den·ti·fi·ca·tion , re·veal 揭示, true 真正的

ODE> The fact of being who or what a person or thing is. – name.

911. if 如果 ## 155

[ɪf]conj.是否；如果；即使；每当n.条件；设想

  • What would Julie like to do, if she had the money? 将朱莉想要做什么，如果以后有钱？
  • What will you do if you win a lot of money? 你会怎么做，如果你赢了很多钱？
  • If I win a lot of money I’ll buy you a mink coat. 要是我赢了许多钱，我给你买件貂皮大衣。

SEE> not 不, should 应该, could 可以

ODE> (introducing a conditional clause) on the condition or supposition that; in the event that. – on condition that, provided, provided that, providing, providing that, presuming, presuming that, supposing, supposing that, assuming, assuming that, on the assumption that, allowing, allowing that, as long as, given that, with the provision that, with the proviso that, on the understanding that, with the understanding that, if and only if, contingent on, in the event that, allowing that.

912. ill 生病 ## 4

[ɪl]adj.坏的；有病的；恶意的；引起痛苦的adv.恶劣地；勉强地n.邪恶；不幸；祸害；坏话

  • He feels ill. 他生病的感觉。
  • He looks ill. We must call the doctor. 他觉得不舒服。我们得去请医生。
  • He became mortally ill a few months before we had planned to go and, when he knew that he was dying, he made me promise to go on my own. 他临死病倒在几个月前，我们曾计划去，当他知道自己已奄奄一息，他让我答应去我自己。

SEE> sick 生病, sim·i·lar·ly 同样, un·for·tu·nate·ly 不幸的是

ODE> Suffering from an illness or disease or feeling unwell. – unwell, sick, not well, not very well, ailing, poorly, sickly, peaky, afflicted, indisposed, infirm, liverish.

913. ill·ness 疾病 ## 8

[’ɪlnəs]n.病；疾病

  • Bagrit foresaw a time when computers would be small enough to hold in the hand, when they would be capable of providing information about traffic jams and suggesting alternative routes, when they would be used in hospitals to help doctors to diagnose illnesses, when they would relieve office workers and accountants of dull, repetitive clerical work. 巴格瑞特预示有一天计算机可以小到拿在手上，当他们将能够提供有关交通阻塞的信息，并建议替代路线，当他们将在医院使用，以帮助医生诊断疾病，当他们将减轻上班族的平淡会计师，重复的文职工作。
  • One allegation often made is that noise produces mental illness. 常见的一种指责是，噪音能引起精神病。
  • Was the noise a cause of the illness, or were the complaints about noise merely a symptom? 是噪音的疾病的原因，或者是投诉约噪声仅仅是一种症状？

SEE> suf·fer·ing 痛苦, dis·ease 疾病, sick·ness

ODE> A disease or period of sickness affecting the body or mind. – sickness, disease, ailment, disorder, complaint, malady, affliction, attack, infection, contagion, disability, indisposition.

914. il·lus·trate 加插图 ## 2

[’ɪləstreɪt]vt.说明；（为书）作插图；图解vi.举例说明；发亮

  • The story of a poor family that acquired fame and fortune overnight, dramatically illustrates the power of the press. 一个贫穷的家庭是获得名利一夜的故事戏剧性地说明了新闻报道的威力。
  • This may be illustrated by comparing the position of a nation with that of a private business enterprise. 这可能是由一个国家的立场与私有企业的比较来说明。

SEE> de·pict , ex·plain 解释, high·light 突出

ODE> Provide (a book, newspaper, etc.) with pictures. – with illustrations, with pictures, with drawings, with sketches, pictorial.

915. im·age 形象 ## 2

[’ɪmɪdʒ]n.印象；形象；影像；图像；肖像vt.反映；想像；描绘

  • A blurred image appears; he adds a brushstroke and another, and it is gone; but something was there, and he will not rest till he has captured it. 出现一个模糊图像;他增添了一笔，另外，它是走了;但事情在那里，他不会休息，直到把它捕捉。
  • This temptation to cover the distance between himself and the reader, to study his image in the sight of those who do not know him, can be his undoing: he has begun to write to please. 这种企图消除自己和读者之间的距离，来研究他的形象在眼前那些谁不认识他，对可他的毁灭：他已经开始写讨好。

SEE> pic·ture 图画, con·trast 对比, pho·to·graph 照片

ODE> A representation of the external form of a person or thing in art. – likeness, resemblance.

916. im·ag·i·na·tion 想象力 ## 2

[ɪˌmædʒɪ’neɪʃn]n.想象；想象力；空想；幻想

  • As the time and cost of making a chip drop to a few days and a few hundred dollars, engineers may soon be free to let their imaginations soar without being penalized by expensive failures. 随着时间和制造一块芯片几天和几百美元的成本，工程师们可能很快可以任他们的想象驰骋而不会被昂贵的失败所惩罚。
  • The high stern castle was a riot of carved gods, demons, knights, kings, warriors, mermaids, cherubs; and zoomorphic animal shapes ablaze with red and gold and blue, symbols of courage, power, and cruelty, were portrayed to stir the imaginations of the superstitious sailors of the day. 高耸的船是雕刻的神仙，妖魔，骑士，国王，勇士，美人鱼，小天使，492;和兽形动物形状的红色和金黄色，蓝色的勇气，力量和残酷的符号闪亮，以激起一天迷信的水手们的想像。

SEE> cre·a·tiv·i·ty , mind 心神, in·spi·ra·tion

ODE> The faculty or action of forming new ideas, or images or concepts of external objects not present to the senses. – imaginative faculty, creative power, fancy.

917. im·ag·ine 想像 ## 10

[ɪ’mædʒɪn]vt.想像；设想；料想；猜想；认为vi.想像

  • Imagine their surprise and delight when they broke open the packing cases and found that the fourth engine was sweet as honey – still in perfect condition. 想象一下，他们惊讶和高兴，当他们拆开包装箱的情况下，发现第4台发动机就像蜂蜜一样甜 - 完好无损。
  • Imagine their dismay when they found a beautifully-cooked wallet and notes turned to ash! 想象一下，他们的沮丧时，他们发现了一个精美的煮熟的钱包，钞票已化成灰！
  • We sometimes imagine a desert island to be a sort of paradise where the sun always shines. 我们有时想象荒岛是一个乐园，那里终日阳光普照。

SEE> may·be 也许, else 其他, some·thing 某物

ODE> Form a mental image or concept of. – visualize, envisage, envision, picture, form a picture of, see in the mind’s eye, conjure up, conceptualize.

918. im·me·di·ate·ly 立即 ## 24

[ɪ’miːdiətli]adv.立即；直接地conj.一 … (就)

  • To my surprise, he gave me the money immediately. 令我惊讶的是，他马上就给我钱。
  • The landlord smiled and immediately went out. 老板笑了笑，马上走了出去。
  • Almost immediately he began to complain about the weather, for even though it was still summer, it rained continually and it was often bitterly cold. 但紧接着他就开始抱怨那里的天气了。因为即使那时仍为夏季，它不断地下雨，而且常常冷得厉害。

SEE> soon 不久, prompt·ly 立即, quick·ly 很快

919. im·pa·tient 不耐烦 ## 2

[ɪm’peɪʃnt]adj.不耐烦的；急躁的

  • Meanwhile, the editor was getting impatient, for the magazine would soon go to press. 同时，编辑等得不耐烦了，因为杂志马上要付印。
  • She intended to dress up as a ghost and as she had made her costume the night before, she was impatient to try it on. 她打算装扮成鬼和她前一天晚上做了她的服装，她急于想试试。
