1162. mo·tion 运动 ## 2

[’moʊʃn]n.移动；动作；打手势；示意；提议；大便v.示意；运动；向 … 打手势

  • What is a hovercraft riding on when it is in motion? 什么是当它在运动气垫船骑？
  • In vain they rush frantically round from place to place, trying to escape from avenging boredom by mere clatter and motion. 徒然他们狂乱地从一个地方到另一个地方，试图通过闲聊和运动从复仇无聊逃脱。

SEE> ac·tion 行动, in·stance 例子, in·stead 代替

ODE> The action or process of moving or being moved. – movement, moving, locomotion, rise and fall, shifting, stirring, to and fro, toing and froing, coming and going.

1163. mount 安装 ## 4

[maʊnt]v.登上；爬上；装上；上升n.底板；爬上；支架；乘用马n.山；峰

  • Triple gun-decks mounted sixty-four bronze cannon. 三层的火炮甲板上装着64门青铜加农炮。
  • This modern faith in medicines is proved by the fact that the annual drug bill of the Health Services is mounting to astronomical figures and shows no signs at present of ceasing to rise. 这现代人对药物是由卫生部门的年度药费在停止上涨的目前安装到天文数字，且没有迹象事实证明。
  • The hovercraft travelled first over the water, then mounted the beach, climbed up the dunes, and sat down on a road. 气垫船先是在水面上行驶，后又登上海岸，爬上沙丘，最后停在路上。

SEE> moun·tain 山脉, hill 小山, vi·cin·i·ty

ODE> Climb up (stairs, a hill, or other rising surface) – go up, ascend, climb, climb up, scale, clamber up, make one’s way up, move up.

1164. moun·tain 山脉 ## 18

[’maʊntən]n.大量；山；山脉；高山

  • Captain Fawcett’s first passenger was a doctor who flew from Birmingham to a lonely village in the Welsh mountains. 弗西特机长的第一名乘客是位医生谁从伯明翰飞往威尔士山区一个偏僻的村庄。
  • How was the plane able to clear the mountains? 如何为飞机能够清除山上？
  • Though, at first, Byrd and his men were able to take a great many photographs of the mountains that lay below, they soon ran into serious trouble. 虽然开始时伯德和他的助手们拍下了飞机下面连绵群山的大量照片，但他们很快就陷入了困境。

SEE> rock·y , hill 小山, mount 安装

ODE> A large natural elevation of the earth’s surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level; a large steep hill. – peak, height, elevation, eminence, prominence, summit, pinnacle, mountaintop, alp, horn.

1165. mouse 鼠 ## 2

[maʊs]n.老鼠；胆小如鼠的人；鼠标v.捕鼠；仔细搜寻；移动鼠标至…之上

  • Snakes did not acquire their poison for use against man but for use against prey such as rats and mice, and the effects on these of viperine poison is almost immediate. 蛇没有获得他们的毒药用来对付人的，而是对付的猎物，如大鼠和小鼠，并在这些毒蛇毒药的效果几乎是立竿见影的。
  • When you think of the innumerable birds that one sees flying about, not to mention the equally numerous small animals like field mice and voles which you do not see, it is very rarely that one comes across a dead body, except, of course, on the roads. 当你想到，数不清的鸟有看得见的飞来飞去，更不用提的无数小动物一样的老鼠和田鼠，你看不出来，这是很少有人遇到一具尸体，当然除了上道路。

SEE> rat , rab·bit , mon·key

ODE> A small rodent that typically has a pointed snout, relatively large ears and eyes, and a long tail. –

1166. mouth 口 ## 7

[maʊθ]n.嘴；口；开口；河口v.不出声说；装腔作势地说；喃喃地说

  • Open your mouth, Jimmy. 把嘴张开，吉米。
  • He put them both into his mouth. 他把它们都放进嘴里。
  • I tried to say something, but my mouth was full of cotton wool. 我想说点什么，但我嘴里塞满了药棉。

SEE> tongue 舌头, nose 鼻子, throat 喉咙

ODE> The opening and cavity in the lower part of the human face, surrounded by the lips, through which food is taken in and vocal sounds are emitted. – lips, jaws.

1167. move 移动 ## 40

[muːv]n.移动；步骤；迁居；动作vt.推动；使移动；使 … 感动；提议vi.移动；搬家；采取行动

  • Has he moved to his new house yet? 他已经迁进新居了吗？
  • He’s going to move tomorrow. 他打算明天搬家。
  • When will the new people move into this house? 当将新人们搬进这所房子？

SEE> mov·ing 移动, push 推, would 将

ODE> Go in a specified direction or manner; change position. – go, walk, proceed, progress, advance, pass.

1168. move·ment 运动 ## 13

[’muːvmənt]n.活动；运动；动作；[音]乐章

  • It rose out of the basket and began to follow the movements of the pipe. 它上升筐而出，并开始跟随管的运动。
  • The sudden movement of the door made it sway slightly and it gave me the impression that it was about to leap out at me. 门的突然运动使它稍微摇摆，它给我的印象是，它是关于我扑过来。
  • In fact a basic amount of movement occurs during sleep which is specifically concerned with preventing muscle inactivity. 实际上移动的基本的量，其具体涉及防止肌肉活动停止睡眠期间发生。

SEE> rad·i·cal , strug·gle 斗争, which 哪一个

ODE> An act of moving. – motion, move, manoeuvre.

1169. much 许多 ## 53

[mʌtʃ]adj.许多的adv.很；非常；几乎n.许多

  • Thank you very much. 非常感谢你。
  • Thank you very much. 非常感谢你。
  • Thank you very much. 非常感谢你。

SEE> e·ven 甚至, though 虽然, than 比

ODE> A great amount or quantity of. – a lot of, a good deal of, a great deal of, a great amount of, a large amount of, plenty of, ample, copious, abundant, plentiful, considerable, substantial.

1170. mud 泥 ## 7

[mʌd]n.泥；泥浆；诽谤vt.弄脏；抹泥

  • Even under a clear blue sky, the village looked forbidding, as all the houses were built of grey mud bricks. 即使在晴朗的蓝天，村庄看上去可怕的，因为所有的房子建造的泥灰色的砖块。
  • If you were to ask Harry what was in the bottle, he would tell you that it contained perfumed mud. 如果你问哈里什么是瓶子，他会告诉你是香泥。
  • The bottle really does contain perfumed mud. 瓶子确实含有香水泥。

SEE> mud·dy , sand 沙子, dirt 污垢

ODE> Soft, sticky matter resulting from the mixing of earth and water. – mire, sludge, slush, ooze, silt, clay, gumbo, dirt, soil.

1171. mul·ti·ply 相乘 ## 3

[’mʌltɪplaɪ]vt.乘；增加vi.做乘法；繁衍adv.多样地；多重地

  • Errors and uncertainties multiply, cascading upward through a chain of turbulent features, from dust devils and squalls up to continent-size eddies that only satellites can see. 错误和不可靠性，通过链条的动荡特性，从尘暴级联向上和暴风发展到大陆，大小漩涡，只有卫星上可以看到。
  • Soon the errors will have multiplied to the ten-foot scale, and so on up to the size of the globe. 很快这种偏差会增加到十英尺标，等等一直到全球的规模。
  • This rabbit had no natural enemies in the Antipodes, so that it multiplied with that promiscuous abandon characteristic of rabbits. 这种兔子在拓地没有天敌，所以它乘以该混杂放弃兔子的特征。

ODE> Obtain from (a number) another which contains the first number a specified number of times. – increase, increase exponentially, grow, become more numerous, accumulate, proliferate, mount up, mushroom, snowball, burgeon, spread, expand.

1172. mum 妈妈 ## 7

[mʌm]n.妈妈，母亲

  • We’re tired… …and thirsty, Mum. 我们累了……和渴，妈妈。
  • Thanks, Mum. 谢谢你，妈妈。
  • Thanks, Mum. 谢谢你，妈妈。

ODE> One’s mother. – silent, quiet, mute, dumb, tight-lipped, close-mouthed, uncommunicative, unforthcoming, reticent, secretive.

1173. mur·der 谋杀 ## 2

[’mɜːrdər]n.谋杀；谋杀案；要命的事vt.谋杀；糟蹋；损坏vi.谋杀

  • ‘At the time the murder was committed, I was travelling on the 8 o’clock train to London,’ said the man. “当时的凶杀案，我是在8点钟开往伦敦的火车，”那人说。
  • You see, on the morning of the murder, the 8 o’clock train did not run at all. 你看，在凶杀发生的那天早晨，8点钟的火车根本不运行。

SEE> rape , rob·ber·y , kill·ing 谋杀

ODE> The unlawful premeditated killing of one human being by another. – killing, homicide, assassination, liquidation, extermination, execution, slaughter, butchery, massacre.

1174. mus·cle 肌肉 ## 3

[’mʌsl]n.肌肉v.硬挤；变硬实

  • ‘Rest’, in terms of muscle relaxation and so on, can be achieved by a brief period lying, or even sitting down. “休息”，使肌肉得到放松的条件等，可以通过稍微躺一躺，甚至坐一坐来实现的。
  • In fact a basic amount of movement occurs during sleep which is specifically concerned with preventing muscle inactivity. 实际上移动的基本的量，其具体涉及防止肌肉活动停止睡眠期间发生。
  • Duck, and like them the pigeons, are endowed with steel-like muscles, that are a good part of the weight of the bird, and these will ply the short wings with such irresistible power that they can bore for long distances through an opposing gale before exhaustion follows. 野鸭以及与它们相似的鸽子，都长着钢铁般般的肌肉，那是鸟的体重的很大一部分，而这些将扇动短小的翅膀与以巨大的力量，他们可以通过顶着大风很长的距离之前耗尽如下。

SEE> calf , thigh , stom·ach 胃

ODE> A band or bundle of fibrous tissue in a human or animal body that has the ability to contract, producing movement in or maintaining the position of parts of the body. – thew.

1175. mu·se·um 博物馆 ## 6

[mju’ziːəm]n.博物馆；展览馆

  • I visited museums and sat in public gardens. 我参观了博物馆，还去了公园。
  • There were six million visitors in all, and the profits from the exhibition were used to build museums and colleges. 有是600万人次，并从博览会的赢利用来建造博物馆和高等学校。
  • The fish, which has since been sent to a museum where it is being examined by a scientist, is called an oarfish. 鱼，这已经被送到那里正被科学家检查了博物馆，被称为皇带鱼。

SEE> ex·hib·it 展览, art 艺术, gal·ler·y

ODE> A building in which objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest are stored and exhibited. – record office, registry, repository, museum, chancery.

1176. must 必须 ## 105

[mʌst]aux.必须；应当；很可能n.必须做的事；未发酵的葡萄汁；发霉

  • How must Amy clean the floor? 艾米需要如何来清扫地面？
  • What must I do, Mrs. Jones? 我必须做什么，琼斯太太？
  • He looks ill. We must call the doctor. 他觉得不舒服。我们得去请医生。

SEE> should 应该, can·not 不能, need 需要

ODE> Be obliged to; should (expressing necessity) – ought to, should, have to, have got to, need to, be obliged to, be required to, be compelled to, be under an obligation to.

1177. my 我的 ## 200

[maɪ]adj.我的（I的所有格形式）int.哎呦（用于表示惊讶的感叹词）

  • My coat and my umbrella please. 我的大衣和伞拿给我。
  • Here is my ticket. 这是我的票。
  • This is not my umbrella. 这不是我的伞。

SEE> your 你的, I 我, me 我

ODE> Belonging to or associated with the speaker. –

1178. my·self 我自己 ## 13

[maɪ’self]pron.我自己

  • Well, I’ll have tea by myself. 好吧，我会通过自己的茶。
  • I’m not more than twenty-nine myself. 我不超过29自己。
  • ‘To make myself beautiful,’ the lady answered. 为了把自己打扮漂亮啊，“那位妇女答道。

SEE> your·self 你自己, our·selves 我们自己, re·al·ly 真的

ODE> Used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself as the object of a verb or preposition when he or she is the subject of the clause. –

1179. mys·te·ri·ous 神秘的 ## 2

[mɪ’stɪriəs]adj.神秘的；不可思议的

  • They can be friendly and affectionate towards humans, but they lead mysterious lives of their own as well. 它们可以是深情，柔情的人，但他们过自己的神秘生活为好。
  • The open sea was deep and mysterious, and anyone who gave more than a passing thought to the bottom confines of the oceans probably assumed that the sea bed was flat. 无边无际的海洋深邃而神秘，谁都不是谁路过了更多的心思，以人大概都会认为海底持平海洋的底部界限。

SEE> strange 奇怪, sup·pos·ed·ly , mys·ter·y 神秘

ODE> Difficult or impossible to understand, explain, or identify. – puzzling, strange, peculiar, curious, funny, queer, odd, weird, bizarre, mystifying, inexplicable, baffling, perplexing, bewildering, confusing, uncanny, dark, impenetrable, incomprehensible, unexplainable, unfathomable, Delphic, sibylline, unaccountable, insoluble, obscure.

1180. mys·ter·y 神秘 ## 5

[’mɪstri]n.谜，神秘；奥秘；秘密；神秘的人或事物；推理小说（戏剧）

  • In this way, he was able to solve the mystery. 就这样，他才能够解开这个谜。
  • He informed the station at once, but no one there was able to explain the mystery. 他立刻通知了车站，但没有一个人能解释其中的奥秘。
  • It has always been a mystery to me why city dwellers, who appreciate all these things, obstinately pretend that they would prefer to live in the country. 这一直是个谜我为什么城市居民，谁对这一切，硬是假装他们宁愿住在乡下。

SEE> mys·te·ri·ous 神秘的, sus·pense , in·deed 确实

ODE> Something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain. – puzzle, enigma, conundrum, riddle, secret, unsolved problem, problem, question, question mark, closed book.

1181. name 名字 ## 32

[neɪm]n.名称；姓名；名义；名誉；名人v.命名；取名；说出( … 的名字)adj.著名的

  • My name’s Robert. 我的名字叫罗伯特。
  • My name’s Sophie. 我的名字叫苏菲。
  • There’s a label on the handle with my name and address on it. 界面上有我的名字和地址手柄上的标签。

SEE> known , word 单词, re·fer 提到

ODE> A word or set of words by which a person or thing is known, addressed, or referred to. – title, denomination, designation, honorific, tag, epithet, label.

1182. nar·row 狭窄的 ## 6

[’næroʊ]adj.有限的；狭窄的；精密的；度量小的n.海峡；隘路；狭窄部份v.变窄

  • The city was even equipped with a drainage system, for a great many clay pipes were found beneath the narrow streets. 在这座城市甚至还敷设了排水系统，为一个伟大的许多陶土制的管道被发现在狭窄的街道下面。
  • The shop was an old converted house with many large, disused fireplaces and tall, narrow chimneys. 这家店的老改造的房子有许多废置不用的大壁炉和又高又窄的烟囱。
  • As it was extremely narrow, the man was unable to move, but the fire fighters were eventually able to free him by cutting a huge hole in the wall. 由于这是极窄，那人无法动弹，但消防员们终于在墙上切割大洞，把他解救出来。

SEE> broad 宽阔的, edge 边缘, ra·ther 相当

ODE> Of small width in relation to length. – small, tapered, tapering, narrowing, narrow-gauged.

1183. na·tion 国家 ## 10

[’neɪʃn]n.国家；民族

  • I am always amazed when I hear people saying that sport creates goodwill between the nations, and that if only the common peoples of the world could meet one another at football or cricket, they would have no inclination to meet on the battlefield. 当我听人们说体育运动可创造国家之间的友谊，我总是惊讶，如果只有世界的普通人能够满足在足球场或板球场上，他们就没有兴趣在战场上。
  • But the significant thing is not the behaviour of the players but the attitude of the spectators: and, behind the spectators, of the nations who work themselves into furies over these absurd contests, and seriously believe – at any rate for short periods – that running, jumping and kicking a ball are tests of national virtue. 但显著的事情是不是运动员的行为，而是观众的态度：和自己的工作谁这些荒唐的比赛泼妇，甚至煞有介事地相信各国的观众身后 - 至少在短期内如此 - 跑跑，跳跳，踢踢球是对一个民族品德素质的检验。
  • There are no ‘illiterates’ – if the term can be applied to peoples without a script – while our own compulsory school attendance became law in Germany in 1642, in France in 1806, and in England in 1876, and is still non-existent in a number of ‘civilized’ nations. 有没有“文盲” - 如果这个字眼儿可以适用于没有文字的人群 - 在1806年，而我们的义务教育在德国在1642年成为法律，在法国和英国于1876年，并且仍然是不存在的许多“文明”国家。

SEE> coun·try 国家, once 一次, con·ti·nent 大陆

ODE> A large body of people united by common descent, history, culture, or language, inhabiting a particular country or territory. – country, state, land, sovereign state, nation state, kingdom, empire, republic, confederation, federation, commonwealth, power, superpower, polity, domain.

1184. na·tion·al 国家的 ## 4

[’næʃnəl]adj.民族的；国家的；全国性的；国立的；国有的n.国民（复）nationals: 全国性比赛.

  • The sense of humour is mysteriously bound up with national characteristics. 幽默感是神秘莫测的具有民族特色。
  • In spite of national differences, certain funny situations have a universal appeal. 尽管民族不同，有些滑稽的情节却能产生普遍的效果。
  • But the significant thing is not the behaviour of the players but the attitude of the spectators: and, behind the spectators, of the nations who work themselves into furies over these absurd contests, and seriously believe – at any rate for short periods – that running, jumping and kicking a ball are tests of national virtue. 但显著的事情是不是运动员的行为，而是观众的态度：和自己的工作谁这些荒唐的比赛泼妇，甚至煞有介事地相信各国的观众身后 - 至少在短期内如此 - 跑跑，跳跳，踢踢球是对一个民族品德素质的检验。

SEE> the 该, pub·lic 公众, na·tion 国家

ODE> Relating to or characteristic of a nation; common to a whole nation. – state, public, federal, governmental.

1185. nat·u·ral 自然的 ## 9

[’nætʃrəl]adj.自然的；天然的；私生的

  • The lake was not a natural one, but a man-made reservoir. 该湖是不是自然，而是一个人造水库。
  • This rabbit had no natural enemies in the Antipodes, so that it multiplied with that promiscuous abandon characteristic of rabbits. 这种兔子在拓地没有天敌，所以它乘以该混杂放弃兔子的特征。
  • Porpoises and sharks are natural enemies. 海豚和鲨鱼是天敌。

SEE> ex·am·ple 例子, na·ture 性质, nat·u·ral·ly 自然

ODE> Existing in or derived from nature; not made or caused by humankind. – unprocessed, organic, pure, wholesome, unrefined, pesticide-free, chemical-free, additive-free, unbleached, unmixed, real, plain, virgin, crude, raw.

1186. nat·u·ral·ly 自然 ## 3

[’nætʃrəli]adv.自然地；天生地

  • In so far as any inquiry is a secret one, it naturally limits all those engaged in carrying it out from effective contact with their fellow scientists either in other countries or in universities, or even, often enough, in other departments of the same firm. 在迄今为止的任何调查都涉及到保密，自然受到了限制所有从事从有效接触与他们的同胞科学家们无论是在其他国家或大学，甚至往往不能在同一公司的其他部门实施它。
  • The degree of secrecy naturally varies considerably. 保密程度自然差别很大。
  • Municipalities naturally want to secure the campers’ site fees and other custom. 市政当局当然希望获得露营者的场地费和其他自定义。

SEE> in·deed 确实, like·wise , where·as 而

ODE> Without special intervention; in a natural manner. – normally, in a natural manner, in a natural way, unaffectedly, spontaneously, genuinely, artlessly, unpretentiously.

1187. na·ture 性质 ## 24

[’neɪtʃər]n.自然界；性质；自然；自然状态；本性；类型

  • Such is human nature, that a great many people are often willing to sacrifice higher pay for the privilege of becoming white-collar workers. 这就是人的本性，一个伟大的很多人往往愿意放弃高薪，以便成为白领的特权。
  • In their efforts to persuade us to buy this or that product, advertisers have made a close study of human nature and have classified all our little weaknesses. 在他们的努力劝说我们买这个或那个产品，广告商作出人性的仔细研究，并已列为我们所有的小弱点。
  • By having to sleep in the open, he gets far closer to the world of nature than most of us ever do. 由于不得不露宿，他得到远更接近自然的世界比我们曾经做的。

SEE> ra·ther 相当, in·deed 确实, fact 事实

ODE> The phenomena of the physical world collectively, including plants, animals, the landscape, and other features and products of the earth, as opposed to humans or human creations. – the natural world, the living world, Mother Nature, creation, the world, the environment, the earth, Mother Earth, the universe, the cosmos, natural forces.

1188. na·vy 海军 ## 2

[’neɪvi]n.海军；船队；海军蓝

  • Some time ago the United States Navy, for instance, examined a very large number of men working on aircraft carriers: the study was known as Project Anehin. 前段时间美国海军，比如，检查了非常多的人在航空母舰上工作：研究被称为安内欣计划。
  • It can be unpleasant to live even several miles from an aerodrome; if you think what it must be like to share the deck of a ship with several squadrons of jet aircraft, you will realize that a modern navy is a good place to study noise. 它可以是不愉快的生活甚至几英里的机场;如果你认为它必须是什么样的共享与喷气飞机的几个中队船的甲板上，你就会认识到现代海军是研究噪音的好地方。

SEE> na·val , ship 船, fleet

ODE> The branch of the armed services of a state which conducts military operations at sea. – fleet, flotilla, armada, naval force, naval task force, squadron.

1189. near 近 ## 36

[nɪr]adj.近的；近似的；亲近的；吝啬的adv.在附近；不久以后；几乎；[罕]吝啬地prep.附近；接近；临近；大约；(质量、大小等)相仿；濒临v.接近；靠近

  • The television is near the window. 电视机靠近窗子。
  • The armchairs are near the table. 该扶手椅靠近桌子。
  • The stereo is near the door. 立体声靠近门。

SEE> near·by 附近, vi·cin·i·ty , out·side 外面

ODE> At or to a short distance away; nearby. – close by, close, nearby, close at hand, near at hand, not far away, not far off, in the neighbourhood, in the vicinity, at hand, within reach, within close range, on the doorstep, within earshot, within sight, a stone’s throw away, at close quarters, alongside.

1190. near·by 附近 ## 5

[ˌnɪr’baɪ]adj.附近的adv.在附近

  • A pilot noticed a balloon which seemed to be making for a Royal Air Force Station nearby. 一位飞行员注意到似乎的一个皇家空军基地附近的气球。
  • The student hid in an archway nearby where he could watch and hear everything that went on. 学生躲进一个牌楼附近，在那里他可以看见，现场发生的听到的一切。
  • They invariably live nearby and are always available for an informal chat or an evening’s entertainment. 他们都住在附近，并随时可以聊天或在晚上一起娱乐。

SEE> near 近, vi·cin·i·ty , ad·ja·cent

ODE> Not far away; close. – not far away, not far off, close at hand, near at hand, close by, close, near, within reach, at hand, neighbouring, adjacent.

1191. near·ly 几乎 ## 22

[’nɪrli]adv.几乎；差不多；密切地

  • I’m nearly ready. 我马上就好。
  • It’s nearly ready. 这几乎是准备好了。
  • He’s only forty-one years old, and he has already been to nearly every country in the world. 他只有41岁，他已是几乎每一个国家在世界上。

SEE> al·most 几乎, a·go 前, than 比

ODE> Very close to; almost. – nearly, just about, about, more or less, practically, virtually, all but, as good as, next to, close to, near, nigh on, not far from, not far off, to all intents and purposes, approaching, bordering on, verging on, nearing.

1192. neat·ly 整洁 ## 2

[niːtli]adv.整洁地；熟练地

  • At the base of the gold cap, the words ‘made in the U.S.A.’ had been neatly inscribed. 在金笔帽的基础上，写着“在U.S.A.制造”整齐地刻有。
  • After her departure, Aunt Harriet discovered that there were piles of empty wine bottles of all shapes and sizes neatly stacked in what had once been Bessie’s wardrobe. 她走之后，哈丽特终于发现，有整齐堆放在什么贝西以前用过的衣柜各种形状和大小的空酒瓶成堆。

SEE> neat 整齐, nice·ly 很好, per·fect·ly 完美

ODE> In a neat way. – tidily, smartly, sprucely.

1193. nec·es·sar·y 必要 ## 12

[’nesəseri]adj.必要的；必然的n.必需品

  • A robot-arm from the Endeavour will grab the telescope and hold it while the astronauts make the necessary repairs. 从努力的一个机器人手臂将抓住望远镜并托住它当宇航员进行必要的修复。
  • At this, the police pointed out ironically that this would hardly be necessary as the men were already under arrest. 在此，警方指出，讽刺的是，这将大可不必，因为他俩已被逮捕。
  • Precautions of this sort are necessary, for it is impossible to foretell the exact nature of the difficulties which will confront the pot-holer. 作出这样的准备是必要的，因为它是无法预见到将面临锅holer困难的确切性质。

SEE> suf·fi·cient 足够的, need 需要, must 必须

ODE> Needed to be done, achieved, or present; essential. – obligatory, requisite, required, compulsory, mandatory, imperative, demanded, needed, called for, needful.

1194. need 需要 ## 43

[niːd]v.需要；必需n.需要；必要；缺乏aux.需要，必须（无时态、人称变化，后与不带 to 的动词不定式连用，多用于疑问句和否定句）

  • Why did the man need a phrasebook? 为什么男人需要一本常用语？
  • What do we need? 我们需要什么？
  • We need a lot of things this week. 我们需要很多的东西这个星期。

SEE> must 必须, should 应该, want 想要

ODE> Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable. – obligatory, requisite, required, compulsory, mandatory, imperative, demanded, needed, called for, needful.

1195. neigh·bour 邻居 ## 12

[’neɪbər]n.邻居；邻近之人或事；邻近值v.邻近；接壤

  • He has always been a good neighbour. 他一直是个好邻居。
  • Nigel is our new next-door neighbour. 奈杰尔是我们新的隔壁邻居。
  • Later a neighbour told me about him. 后来，一位邻居告诉了我他。

ODE> A person living next door to or very near to the speaker or person referred to. – adjacent, nearest, closest, next-door, next, adjoining, bordering, connecting, abutting, contiguous, proximate.

1196. neigh·bour·hood 邻里 ## 2

[’neɪbərhʊd]n.邻近；邻里关系

  • One Saturday morning, Frank visited an antique shop in my neighbourhood. 一个星期六的上午，弗兰克去了我家附近的一家古玩店。
  • Hans returned to his family home, but the house had been bombed and no one in the neighbourhood knew what had become of the inhabitants. 汉斯回到了自己的家，但房子已被炸毁，没有人在附近知道发生了什么成为居民。

ODE> A district or community within a town or city. – district, area, locality, locale, quarter, community, part, region, zone.

1197. nei·ther 两者都不 ## 7

[’niːðər]pron.两者都不adj.两者都不的adv.也不conj.也不；既不

  • Neither can I. I’m very sorry, sir. 也不能。我很抱歉，先生。
  • Neither of us spoke during the journey. 无论我们的旅程中发言。
  • he answered me, but he spoke neither slowly nor clearly. 他回答了，但他讲得既不慢也不清楚。

SEE> nor 也不, in·deed 确实, though 虽然

ODE> Used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives (the others being introduced by ‘nor’) to indicate that they are each untrue or each does not happen. –

1198. nerve 神经 ## 5

[nɜːrv]n.神经；勇气；敏感处；叶脉；厚脸皮v.鼓起勇气（复）nerves: 神经紧张.

  • After reading an article entitled ‘Cigarette Smoking and Your Health’ I lit a cigarette to calm my nerves. 阅读一篇文章，题为“吸烟与健康”后，我点了一支烟，镇静一下紧张情绪。
  • One poison acts on the nerves, the other on the blood. 一个毒作用于神经，另对血液。
  • The makers of the nerve poison include the mambas and the cobras and their venom is called neurotoxic. 神经毒液的是非洲树眼镜蛇和眼镜蛇，它们的毒液称为神经毒素。

SEE> nerves , nerv·ous 紧张, mus·cle 肌肉

ODE> A whitish fibre or bundle of fibres in the body that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs. – nerve fibre.

1199. nerv·ous 紧张 ## 2

[’nɜːrvəs]adj.神经的，神经细胞的，神经性的；焦虑的；神经质的，紧张的，不安的；易兴奋的

  • I felt very nervous when I went into his office. 当我走进他的办公室，感到非常紧张。
  • He was obviously very nervous and for some minutes stood awkwardly before the microphone. 他显然很紧张，有好几分钟麦克风前局促不安地站。

SEE> anx·ious 着急的, wor·ried 担心的, scared 恐惧的

ODE> Easily agitated or alarmed. – highly strung, easily frightened, easily agitated, anxious, edgy, tense, excitable, jumpy, skittish, brittle, neurotic, hysterical.

1200. nev·er 从不 ## 70

[’nevər]adv.永不；绝不；从不；未曾

  • I’ve never been there. 我从来没有去过那里。
  • You always say that, but we never win anything! 你总是这么说，但是我们从来没赢过！
  • Sally was very excited because she had never travelled on a train before. 萨莉非常激动，因为她从未之前火车旅行。

SEE> not 不, but 但是, e·ven 甚至

ODE> At no time in the past or future; not ever. – at no time, not at any time, not ever, not once, on no occasion.

1201. new 新的 ## 85

[nuː]adj.新的；崭新的；新鲜的；不熟悉的adv.新近地

  • Sophie is a new student. 苏菲是一个新学生。
  • I am a new student. 我是个新学生。
  • What colour’s your new dress? 什么颜色是你的新衣服吗？

SEE> same 相同, first 第一, ad·di·tion 加

ODE> Produced, introduced, or discovered recently or now for the first time; not existing before. – recently developed, newly discovered, brand new, up to the minute, up to date, latest, current, state-of-the-art, contemporary, present-day, advanced, recent, modern.

1202. news 新闻 ## 11

[nuːz]n.新闻；消息

  • What is good news for Jimmy? 吉米有什么好消息？
  • That’s good news for Jimmy. 这对吉米的好消息。
  • Good news? 好消息？

SEE> in·ter·view 面谈, say·ing , me·di·a 媒体

ODE> Newly received or noteworthy information, especially about recent events. – report, announcement, story, account.

1203. news·pa·per 报纸 ## 16

[’nuːzpeɪpər]n.报纸；新闻纸

  • There are some newspapers on the table. 有上表中的一些报纸。
  • Mr. Sawyer usually reads his newspaper, but sometimes he and his wife watch television. 索耶先生总是读报纸，但有时和他的妻子一起看电视。
  • Mr. Sawyer usually reads his newspaper at night. 索耶先生通常是在晚上看报。

SEE> dai·ly 日常的, pa·per 纸, pub·li·ca·tion 出版物

ODE> A printed publication (usually issued daily or weekly) consisting of folded unstapled sheets and containing news, articles, advertisements, and correspondence. – paper.

1204. next 下一个 ## 45

[nekst]adj.下一个的；其次的；隔壁的adv.其次；下次；然后n.下一个prep.靠近

  • She’s next door. 她是隔壁。
  • He will fly to New York next month. 他将飞往纽约下个月。
  • The month after next he’ll fly to Tokyo. 后年，他将飞往东京的月份。

SEE> be·fore 在之前, will 将, come 来

ODE> (of a time) coming immediately after the time of writing or speaking. – following, succeeding, to come, upcoming.

1205. nice 美好的 ## 17

[naɪs]adj.好的；美妙的；友好的；令人愉快的；精细的

  • Nice to meet you. 很高兴见到你。
  • Nice to meet you. 很高兴见到你。
  • Nice to meet you. 很高兴见到你。

SEE> won·der·ful 精彩的, love·ly 可爱, good 好

ODE> Giving pleasure or satisfaction; pleasant or attractive. – enjoyable, pleasant, pleasurable, agreeable, delightful, satisfying, gratifying, acceptable, to one’s liking, entertaining, amusing, diverting, marvellous, good.

1206. night 晚 ## 44

[naɪt]n.夜晚adj.夜晚的

  • The days are long and the nights are short. 日子长而夜晚短。
  • The days are short and the nights are long. 在昼短夜长。
  • At night, the children always do their homework. 晚上，孩子们总是做作业。

SEE> eve·ning 晚间, Sat·ur·day 星期六, af·ter·noon 下午

ODE> The period from sunset to sunrise in each twenty-four hours. – darkness, dark, hours of darkness, night-time, dead of night.

1207. nine 九 ## 5

[naɪn]num.九

  • It is nine o’clock. 现在是九点钟。
  • How did Pauline answer the telephone at nine o’clock? 波林是如何接听电话九点钟？
  • He telephoned at nine o’clock. 他打电话九点钟。

SEE> eight 八, sev·en 七, six 六

ODE> Equivalent to the product of three and three; one more than eight, or one less than ten; 9. – nonet.

1208. nine·teen 十九 ## 3

[ˌnaɪn’tiːn]十九

  • At nineteen minutes past eight. 在八时十九分。
  • At eight nineteen. 在8点19分。
  • We want to catch the eight nineteen to London. 我们要乘8点19分至伦敦。

SEE> sev·en·teen 十七, four·teen 十四, fif·teen 十五

ODE> One more than eighteen; nine more than ten; 19. –

1209. nine·teenth 第十九 ## 5

[ˌnaɪn’tiːnθ]num.第十九

  • Perhaps the most extraordinary building of the nineteenth century was the Crystal Palace, which was built in Hyde Park for the Great Exhibition of 1851. 也许是十九世纪最不寻常的建筑水晶宫，这是建在海德公园的1851年世界博览会。
  • One of the most famous monuments in the world, the Statue of Liberty, was presented to the United States of America in the nineteenth century by the people of France. 一个是世界上最有名的古迹，自由女神像，是由法国人民赠送给美国的美国在十九世纪。
  • One of the most famous sailing ships of the nineteenth century, the Cutty Sark, can still be seen at Greenwich. 其中最有名的帆船十九世纪的，卡蒂萨克，仍可在格林威治看到。

ODE> Constituting number nineteen in a sequence; 19th. –

1210. no 不 ## 173

[noʊ]adv.不adj.没有；不是；禁止n.否定的回答；投反对票者

  • No, it isn’t. 不，事实并非如此。
  • No, I am not. 不我不是。
  • No, I’m not. 不，我不是。

SEE> an·y 任何, there 那里, on·ly 只有

ODE> Not any. – no indeed, absolutely not, most certainly not, of course not, under no circumstances, by no means, not at all, negative, never, not really, no thanks.

1211. noise 噪声 ## 30

[nɔɪz]n.噪声；喧闹声；响声vt.谣传vi.大声说话；发出噪音

  • George heard the noise and came downstairs quickly. 乔治听到了响声，迅速地下了楼。
  • Over a hundred people must have been driven away from their homes by the noise. 百余人一定是从他们的家园被噪音赶走。
  • He told me that he could not go to sleep one night because he heard a strange noise coming from the bar. 他告诉我，他不能去睡了一晚，因为他听到了奇怪的声音酒吧里传来。

SEE> loud 响, sound 声音, when·ev·er 每当

ODE> A sound, especially one that is loud or unpleasant or that causes disturbance. – sound, loud sound, din, hubbub, clamour, racket, uproar, tumult, commotion, pandemonium, clangour.

1212. nois·y 吵 ## 2

[’nɔɪzi]adj.喧闹的；嘈杂的；吵闹的

  • Lawn mowers whining on a summer’s day, late-night parties in apartment blocks, noisy neighbours, vehicles of all kinds, especially large container trucks thundering through quiet villages, planes and helicopters flying overhead, large radios carried round in public places and played at maximum volume. 割草机呜呜作响的夏天的一天，深夜方在公寓楼，吵闹的邻居，各式各样的车辆，特别是大型集装箱卡车穿越寂静的村庄，飞机和直升机轰鸣飞过，大型收音机进行全面在公共场所和最大发挥体积。
  • What is needed in the case of noise is a study of large numbers of people living under noisy conditions, to discover whether they are mentally ill more often than other people are. 我们需要在噪音的情况下是大量的噪声条件下生活的人，的研究，发现他们是否是精神病患者往往比其他人。

SEE> loud 响, dem·on·stra·tion , cha·ot·ic

ODE> Making or given to making a lot of noise. – rowdy, rackety, clamorous, boisterous, roisterous, obstreperous, turbulent, brash, clattering, chattering, talkative, vociferous, shouting, screaming, shrieking, bawling.

1213. none 没有一个 ## 10

[nʌn]pron.没有人；没有任何东西，一个也没有，毫无adv.决不

  • I’ve got none. 我有没有。
  • None of our passengers can change this note. 我们的乘客中没人能换开这张钞票。
  • There’s none left. 有没有留下。

SEE> nei·ther 两者都不, though 虽然, in·deed 确实

ODE> Not any. – not one, not a one.

1214. nor 也不 ## 10

[nɔːr]conj.也不；也没有adv.也不；也没有abbr.诺曼人(=Norman)abbr.北方（=North）abbr.挪威（= Norway）abbr.挪威人（=Norwegian）

  • he answered me, but he spoke neither slowly nor clearly. 他回答了，但他讲得既不慢也不清楚。
  • Nor is the city without its moments of beauty. 城市也并非没有良辰美景。
  • Nor could he have foreseen how we could use the Internet to obtain information on every known subject, so we can read it on a screen in our homes and even print it as well if we want to. 他也能预见我们如何能够利用互联网获取有关任何已知专题的信息，所以我们可以在家里的屏幕上阅读，甚至将其打印，以及如果我们想。

SEE> nei·ther 两者都不, in·deed 确实, not 不

ODE> Used before the second or further of two or more alternatives (the first being introduced by a negative such as ‘neither’ or ‘not’) to indicate that they are each untrue or each do not happen. –

1215. nor·mal 正常 ## 5

[’nɔːrml]adj.正常的；正规的；精神健全的n.常态；标准

  • The normal price of a ticket is ￡2,000! 一张票的正常价格为£2000！
  • My wife was delighted that things had returned to normal once more. 我的妻子很高兴，因为一切又再次恢复正常。
  • It would never again be possible for them to lead normal lives. 它永远不会再有可能为他们过正常的生活。

SEE> u·su·al 通常, nor·mal·ly 通常, where·as 而

ODE> Conforming to a standard; usual, typical, or expected. – usual, standard, typical, stock, common, ordinary, customary, conventional, habitual, accustomed, expected, wonted, everyday, regular, routine, day-to-day, daily, established, settled, set, fixed, traditional, quotidian, prevailing.

1216. nor·mal·ly 通常 ## 4

[’nɔːrməli]adv.通常；正常地

  • This god which has the head of a cow was normally placed inside a mummy. 这个神其具有一头牛的头部通常被放在木乃伊内部。
  • On the other hand, your stomach would turn at the idea of frying potatoes in animal fat – the normally accepted practice in many northern countries. 在另一方面，你的胃会变成在动物脂肪油炸土豆的想法 - 在北方许多国家常接受的做法。
  • Insurance companies are normally willing to insure anything. 通常保险公司愿意承保一切东西。

SEE> u·su·al·ly 通常, typ·i·cal·ly 一般, gen·er·al·ly 通常

ODE> Under normal or usual conditions; as a rule. – usually, ordinarily, commonly, as a rule, as a general rule, generally, in general, in the general run of things, mostly, for the most part, by and large, mainly, most of the time, almost always, more often than not, on the whole.

1217. north 北 ## 5

[nɔːrθ]adj.北方的；北的adv.向北方n.北方；北

  • The weather’s often cold in the North and windy in the East. 天气经常是在北方寒冷多风的地区。
  • In 1929, three years after his flight over the North Pole, the American explorer, R.E. 1929年，他的飞越北极，美国探险家，R.E.后三年
  • Rescue workers are therefore drilling a hole on the north side of the mine. 因此，营救人员钻了矿井的北侧一个洞。

SEE> south 南方, north·east , east 东

ODE> The direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction. – northern, northerly, northwardly, Arctic, polar.

1218. north·ern 北方 ## 3

[’nɔːrðərn]adj.北部的；北方的；有北方特征的

  • On the other hand, your stomach would turn at the idea of frying potatoes in animal fat – the normally accepted practice in many northern countries. 在另一方面，你的胃会变成在动物脂肪油炸土豆的想法 - 在北方许多国家常接受的做法。
  • It tires not, nor does it boast of its power; but belongs to the air, travelling it may be six thousand miles to and from its northern nesting home, feeding its flown young as it flies, and slipping through a medium that seems to help its passage even when the wind is adverse. 它的轮胎没有，也不会夸耀它的力量;但属于空气，旅行也可能是6,000英里，距离北方做窝的家，喂养它的飞行年轻，因为它苍蝇，并通过似乎帮助其通过，即使风是不利的介质打滑。
  • King Gustavus Adolphus, ‘The Northern Hurricane’, then at the height of his military success in the Thirty Years’ War, had dictated her measurements and armament. 国王古斯塔夫·阿道夫，“北方飓风”，然后在他在三十年战争的军事成功的高度，他亲自规定了测量和军备。

SEE> south·ern 南部的, north·east , east·ern 东

ODE> Situated in the north, or directed towards or facing the north. – northern, northerly, northwardly, Arctic, polar.

1219. not 不 ## 535

[nɑːt]adv.不；没有；并非

  • This is not my umbrella. 这不是我的伞。
  • No, it isn’t. 不，事实并非如此。
  • No, I am not. 不我不是。

SEE> but 但是, should 应该, would 将

ODE> Used with an auxiliary verb or ‘be’ to form the negative. – disinclined, reluctant, averse, loath, indisposed, not in the mood, slow, not about.

1220. note 笔记 ## 17

[noʊt]n.笔记；便条；纸币；音符；票据；注解；音调vt.注意；记录；注解

  • I can’t change a ten-pound note. 我可以不开10英镑的钞票。
  • Can you change this ten-pound note, madam? 你能把这10英镑的钞票，夫人？
  • None of our passengers can change this note. 我们的乘客中没人能换开这张钞票。

SEE> in·stance 例子, in·deed 确实, ex·am·ple 例子

ODE> A brief record of points or ideas written down as an aid to memory. – record, account, entry, item, notation, minute, jotting, inscription.

1221. noth·ing 没有 ## 30

[’nʌθɪŋ]pron.没有什么n.没有；空；微不足道的事adv.毫不；一点也不

  • Nothing at all. 什么都没有。
  • ‘Nothing, Henry,’ George said and smiled. “没事，亨利。”乔治说，笑了。
  • We waited and waited, but nothing happened. 我们等了又等，却什么都没有发生。

SEE> an·y·thing 任何东西, some·thing 某物, cer·tain·ly 当然

ODE> Not anything; no single thing. – not a thing, not a single thing, not anything, nothing at all, nil, zero.

1222. no·tice 注意到 ## 26

[’noʊtɪs]vt.注意；留心；通知n.通知；注意；布告

  • They notice more. 他们观察到的更多。
  • After a time, we noticed a snake charmer with two large baskets at the other side of the square, so we went to have a look at him. 过了一段时间，我们注意到在广场的另一侧两个大筐的耍蛇人，所以我们去看看他。
  • He noticed the remains of a snake which was wound round the electric wires of a 16,000-volt power line. 他发现了缠绕在16,000伏的电源线的电线蛇的遗骸。

SEE> an·y·way 无论如何, in·deed 确实, im·me·di·ate·ly 立即

ODE> The fact of observing or paying attention to something. – attention, observation, awareness, consciousness, perception, cognizance, heed, note.

1223. nov·el 小说 ## 3

[’nɑːvl]n.小说adj.新奇的

  • We often read in novels how a seemingly respectable person or family has some terrible secret which has been concealed from strangers for years. 我们经常读到小说中一个看似受人尊重的人物或家庭，却已经从陌生人隐藏多年的一些可怕的秘密。
  • The reader’s hair stands on end when he reads in the final pages of the novel that the heroine, a dear old lady who had always been so kind to everybody, had, in her youth, poisoned every one of her five husbands. 读者的头发看台上结束的时候，他在小说的最后几页了解到书中女主人公，一个亲爱的老太太谁一直是这样善待每个人，曾在她的青春，她毒死五个丈夫的每一个读取。
  • They have a character, perhaps two; they are in that condition of eager discomfort which passes for inspiration; all admit radical changes of destination once the journey has begun; one, to my certain knowledge, spent nine months on a novel about Kashmir, then reset the whole thing in the Scottish Highlands. 他们有一个或两个角色;它们是其中通行证灵感急切不安的条件;无不承认，一旦旅程开始目的地急剧的变化。一个，据我所知，花了九个月一个有关克什米尔的小说，后来却把苏格兰高地整个事情。

SEE> book 书, ad·ap·ta·tion , fic·tion

ODE> A fictitious prose narrative of book length, typically representing character and action with some degree of realism. – book, paperback, hardback.

1224. now 现在 ## 80

[naʊ]adv.现在；立刻conj.既然(与that连用)n.现在；此刻adj.目前的；现存的abbr.全国妇女组织(=National Organization of Women)

  • Are you all right now? 你现在还好吗？
  • Are you all right now? 你现在还好吗？
  • What are you going to do now, George? 什么是你现在打算干什么，乔治？

SEE> still 仍然, but 但是, though 虽然

ODE> At the present time or moment. – at the moment, at present, just now, right now, at the present time, at the present moment, at this time, at this moment in time, currently, here and now.

1225. num·ber 数 ## 35

[’nʌmbə(r)]n.号码；数量；数字v.总计；编号；编号；把 … 算作

  • Number five. 是5号。
  • Can you remember the doctor’s telephone number? 你还记得医生的电话号码吗？
  • He was in car number fifteen. 他在第15号车里。

SEE> man·y 许多, ad·di·tion 加, these 这些

ODE> An arithmetical value, expressed by a word, symbol, or figure, representing a particular quantity and used in counting and making calculations. – numeral, integer, figure, digit.

1226. nurse 护士 ## 2

[nɜːrs]n.护士；保姆v.看护；护理；栽培

  • Good morning, nurse. 早上好，护士。
  • I must see the dentist now, nurse. 我必须现在就见牙科医生，护士。

SEE> doc·tor 医生, den·tist 牙医, phar·ma·cist

ODE> A person trained to care for the sick or infirm, especially in a hospital. – carer, caregiver, attendant.

1227. o·bey 服从 ## 2

[ə’beɪ]v.服从；遵守；顺从；听从

  • If you receive a request like this, you cannot fail to obey it! 如果你收到这样的恳求，你是不会不遵照执行的！
  • The bank must obey its customer’s instructions, and not those of anyone else. 银行必须服从客户的指示，而不是那些别人的。

SEE> ig·nore 忽视, com·ply , like·wise

ODE> Submit to the authority of (someone) or comply with (a law) – do what someone says, accept orders from, take orders from, carry follow the orders of, carry out the orders of, be dutiful to, heed.

1228. ob·ject 物体 ## 14

[’ɑːbdʒekt]n.物体；目标；对象；宾语v.反对；提出 … 作为反对的理由

  • Only one or two people have objected that the students will drive too fast! 只有一两个人提出反对意见，说学生们会把车开得太快！
  • He said that someone might be spying on the station and the pilot was ordered to keep track of the strange object. 他说可能有人对基地进行侦察，因此命令那个飞行员跟踪那个奇怪的飞行物。
  • Despite its immensity, it is both simple and elegant, fulfilling its designer’s dream to create ‘an enormous object drawn as faintly as possible’. 尽管很大，但它的结构简单，造型优美，实现了设计者的梦想，创造“为依稀描绘成可能一个巨大的物体”。

SEE> par·tic·u·lar 特定的, in·stance 例子, hence 因此

ODE> A material thing that can be seen and touched. – thing, article, item, piece, device, gadget, entity, body.

1229. ob·jec·tive 目标 ## 3

[əb’dʒektɪv]adj.客观的；真实的；宾语的n.目标；目的；[物]物镜；[语]宾语

  • I had expected to be near my objective by now, but everything still seemed alien to me. 我曾预计现在到接近我的目标，但一切仍然很陌生。
  • What was the main objective of early mountain climbers? 什么是早期的登山者的主要目标是什么？
  • But neither psychiatric interviews nor objective tests were able to show any effects upon these American sailors. 但无论是精神病学的调查访问，还是进行客观的测试，都不能显示对这些美国水兵有任何影响。

SEE> aim 瞄准, pur·pose 目的, a·chieve 实现

ODE> (of a person or their judgement) not influenced by personal feelings or opinions in considering and representing facts. – impartial, unbiased, unprejudiced, non-partisan, disinterested, non-discriminatory, neutral, uninvolved, even-handed, equitable, fair, fair-minded, just, open-minded, dispassionate, detached, impersonal, unemotional, clinical.

1230. ob·ser·va·tion 观察 ## 6

[ˌɑːbzər’veɪʃn]n.观察；观察力；注意；评论

  • A burst of activity associated with the laying of submarine cables soon confirmed the Challenger’s observation that many parts of the ocean were two to three miles deep, and the existence of underwater features of considerable magnitude. 海底电缆的铺设相关活动的热潮很快证实了挑战者的观察结果：海洋中很多地方两到三英里深，和幅度相当水下的存在特征。
  • His telescopic observations are justly immortal; they aroused great interest at the time, they had important theoretical consequences, and they provided a striking demonstration of the potentialities hidden in instruments and apparatus. 他的望远镜的观察结果当然是不朽;他们在当时引起了极大的兴趣，具有重要的理论意义，而且提供隐藏在仪表和仪器的潜在力量的示范。
  • If parents were prepared for this adolescent reaction, and realized that it was a sign that the child was growing up and developing valuable powers of observation and independent judgment, they would not be so hurt, and therefore would not drive the child into opposition by resenting and resisting it. 如果家长对青少年的这种反应准备，并且意识到这是一个迹象，表明孩子正在成长和发展的观察和独立判断有价值的权力，他们就不会感到如此伤心，所以也就不会由于怨恨而把孩子推到对立面和抵御它。

SEE> fur·ther·more , in·stance 例子, more·o·ver 此外

ODE> The action or process of closely observing or monitoring something or someone. – watching, monitoring, scrutiny, examination, inspection, scrutinization, viewing, survey, surveillance, surveying, attention, consideration, study, review.

1231. ob·serve 观察 ## 6

[əb’zɜːrv]v.观察；遵守；注意到；庆祝

  • In 1948, he went to Lake Kivu in the Congo to observe a new volcano which he later named Kituro. 1948年，他到基伍湖刚果观察一个新火山，后来他命名为基图罗。
  • The search proved difficult, for the puma was often observed at one place in the morning and at another place twenty miles away in the evening. 搜寻工作很困难，美洲狮在早上一个地方和另一个地方晚上却在20英里外经常观察。
  • As Daniel Goldin of NASA observed, ’Finding life elsewhere would change everything. 作为戈尔丁指出的“在其他地方发现生命会改变一切。

SEE> fol·low 跟随, re·gard 看待, like·wise

ODE> Notice or perceive (something) and register it as being significant. – notice, see, note, perceive, discern, remark, spot, detect, discover, distinguish, make out.

1232. ob·tain 获得 ## 10

[əb’teɪn]vt.获得；得到vi.流行；通用；存在

  • The journalist immediately set out to obtain these important facts, but he took a long time to send them. 记者立即出发去核实这些重要的事实，但他花了很长时间给他们。
  • Obtaining ‘protection money’ is not a modern crime. 榨取“保护金”并不是一个现代的罪恶行径。
  • Nor could he have foreseen how we could use the Internet to obtain information on every known subject, so we can read it on a screen in our homes and even print it as well if we want to. 他也能预见我们如何能够利用互联网获取有关任何已知专题的信息，所以我们可以在家里的屏幕上阅读，甚至将其打印，以及如果我们想。

SEE> per·mit 允许, seek 寻求, per·mis·sion 允许

ODE> Get, acquire, or secure (something) – get, acquire, come by, secure, procure, come into possession of, pick up, be given.

1233. ob·vi·ous 明显 ## 2

[’ɑːbviəs]adj.明显的；显然的

  • It was obvious that he was very embarrassed. 很明显，他感到很尴尬。
  • The rope had been cut, so it was obvious that the lamb had been stolen. 绳子被人割断，所以很明显小羔羊是被人偷走了。

SEE> ev·i·dent , rea·son 理由, fact 事实

ODE> Easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent. – clear, plain, plain to see, crystal clear, evident, apparent, manifest, patent, conspicuous, pronounced, transparent, clear-cut, palpable, prominent, marked, decided, salient, striking, distinct, bold, noticeable, perceptible, perceivable, visible, discernible, detectable, observable, tangible, recognizable.

1234. ob·vi·ous·ly 显然 ## 5

[’ɑːbviəsli]adv.显然地

  • It obviously could not tell the difference between Indian music and jazz! 显然，它分辨不出印度音乐和爵士乐的区别！
  • The man obviously wanted to talk. 那人显然是想聊天。
  • He was obviously very nervous and for some minutes stood awkwardly before the microphone. 他显然很紧张，有好几分钟麦克风前局促不安地站。

SEE> cer·tain·ly 当然, def·i·nite·ly 肯定, re·al·ly 真的

ODE> In a way that is easily perceived or understood; clearly. – clearly, evidently, plainly, patently, visibly, discernibly, manifestly, noticeably.

1235. oc·ca·sion 场合 ## 11

[ə’keɪʒn]n.场合；时机；理由；机会；盛大场面vt.引起；致使

  • It is always the same on these occasions. 它始终是在这些场合相同。
  • Once he landed on the roof of a block of flats and on another occasion, he landed in a deserted car park. 一次，他降落在单位，并在另一个场合块的屋顶，降落在了一个废弃的停车场上。
  • I am used to travelling by air and only on one occasion have I ever felt frightened. 我习惯了乘飞机，只在一个场合已经把我吓坏了旅行。

SEE> in·deed 确实, cel·e·brate 庆祝, nev·er·the·less 然而

ODE> A particular event, or the time at which it takes place. – instance, time, moment, juncture, point.

1236. oc·ca·sion·al·ly 偶尔 ## 5

[ə’keɪʒnəli]adv.偶尔地

  • He explained that his diet was so strict that he had to reward himself occasionally. 他解释说，他的饮食控制得太严格了，以致不得不偶尔奖赏自己。
  • Occasionally, unusual creatures are washed to the shore, but they are rarely caught out at sea. 偶尔，一些罕见的动物被冲到岸上来，但它们在海上很少能被捕捉到。
  • He may hunt, beg, or steal occasionally to keep himself alive; he may even, in times of real need, do a little work; but he will never sacrifice his freedom. 他可能会去打猎，乞讨，偶尔偷来保持自己活着;他甚至可能在确实需要的时候，做了一点工作;但他决不会牺牲自由。

SEE> fre·quent·ly 经常, some·times 有时, of·ten 经常

ODE> At infrequent or irregular intervals; now and then. – sometimes, from time to time, now and then, every now and then, now and again, every now and again, at times, every so often, once in a while, every once in a while, on occasion, on occasions, on the odd occasion, periodically, at intervals, irregularly, sporadically, spasmodically, infrequently, intermittently, on and off, off and on.

1237. oc·cu·py 占据 ## 4

[’ɑːkjupaɪ]vt.占用；占领；从事；使忙碌；专心

  • A little later, a man came along with a biscuit which occupied the whole boot of his car. 不一会儿，一个男子也把汽车的行李箱饼干走过来。
  • But even when such refinements are not available, there is plenty to keep you occupied. 但即使这样的改进不到位，有很多让你目不暇给。
  • Mainframe computers were very large indeed, often occupying whole air-conditioned rooms, employing full-time technicians and run on specially-written software. 计算机主机确实很大，常常占据了装有空调的房间，雇用专职技术人员和专门编写的软件运行。

SEE> like·wise , fur·ther·more , ad·ja·cent

ODE> Reside or have one’s place of business in (a building) – inhabited, lived-in, tenanted, settled.

1238. oc·cur 发生 ## 6

[ə’kɜːr]vi.发生；存在；出现；想到

  • It suddenly occurred to one of the workers to open up the box. 突然一个工人打开箱子之一。
  • It is all very well for such things to occur in fiction. 这是都不错的小说发生这样的事情。
  • The truth is that when mistakes occur, they are more likely to be ours than theirs. 事实是，错误发生时，他们更可能是咎由自取。

SEE> a·rise 产生, hap·pen 发生, u·su·al·ly 通常

ODE> Happen; take place. – happen, take place, come about, transpire, materialize, chance, arise, crop up, turn out, fall, come, fall out, pass off.

1239. o·cean 海洋 ## 18

[’oʊʃn]n.海洋；海量

  • The man wanted to fly to Rockall, a lonely island in the Atlantic Ocean, but Captain Fawcett did not take him because the trip was too dangerous. 这个人想要飞往罗卡尔，在大西洋上的一个孤岛，但福塞特上尉没有走他，因为行程太危险了。
  • Fish and chips has always been a favourite dish in Britain, but as the oceans have been overfished, fish has become more and more expensive. 鱼和炸土豆片一直是英国人喜爱的一道菜，但是随着海洋里的滥捕滥捞，鱼已经变得越来越昂贵。
  • The first of the two ships to reach Java after the race had begun was the Thermopylae, but on the Indian Ocean, the Cutty Sark took the lead. 第一个两船到达爪哇比赛开始后是温泉，但在印度洋上，卡蒂萨克取得了领先。

SEE> sea 海洋, coast 海岸, coast·line

ODE> A very large expanse of sea, in particular each of the main areas into which the sea is divided geographically. – sea, the sea.

1240. odd 奇怪的 ## 2

[ɑːd]adj.奇数的；古怪的；零散的；剩余的

  • At the time, this did not strike me as odd. 当时，这我并不感到奇怪。
  • Speculations about its nature have been going on for literally thousands of years, and one odd finding that makes the problem puzzling is that it looks very much as if sleeping is not simply a matter of giving the body a rest. 关于它的性质的猜测已经持续了成千上万的年，一个奇怪的发现，使得百思不得其解的问题是，它看起来非常仿佛睡也不只是为了使身体得到休息。

  • Are the children coming out of the park or going into it? 是孩子们走出园或进入呢？

1242. off 离开 ## 52

  • but I shaved it off when I came home. 但是我就把它刮了，当我回家。

1243. of·fer 提供 ## 22

[’ɔːfər]vt.提供；提出；（卖方）出价；贡献vi.提议；出现；求婚n.提议；出价

  • The one who offered you a job in Australia. 谁在澳大利亚给你工作的那个人。
  • I have been offered a large sum of money to go away, but I am determined to stay here. 我已经提供的一大笔钱让我搬走，但我决定留在这儿。

1244. of·fice 办公室 ## 26

[’ɔːfɪs]n.办公室；职务；事务；（政府部门的）部、 局、 厅；有特定用途的房间或建筑物

  • This was later confirmed by a naval official at the Ministry of Defence after the Elkor had returned home. 这是后来由国防部一位海军官员证实了Elkor回家后。

  • It’s often cold in November and it rains sometimes. 它通常在寒冷的十一月，而且有时下雨。

1250. oil 石油 ## 15

[ɔɪl]n.油；油画颜料；奉承话v.涂油；溶化；加油

  • So it comes as a surprise to learn that giant fish are terrifying the divers on North Sea oil rigs. 因此，它是一个意外地得知，巨型鱼类的恐吓，对北海石油钻井平台的潜水员。
  • Oil rigs have to be repaired frequently and divers, who often have to work in darkness a hundred feet under water, have been frightened out of their wits by giant fish bumping into them as they work. 钻井平台需要经常修理，潜水员，谁往往要在黑暗中工作的水下一百英尺的地方，已被巨鱼撞到他们，因为他们的工作受到惊吓魂飞魄散了。
  • Three factors have caused these fish to grow so large: the warm water round the hot oil pipes under the sea; the plentiful supply of food thrown overboard by the crews on the rigs; the total absence of fishing boats around the oil rigs. 3个因素造成这些鱼能长得这么大：温水轮海下热油管道;由钻井平台工作人员抛到海里食品的供应充足;完全没有钻井平台周围的渔船。

SEE> crude , gas 气体, gas·o·line 汽油

ODE> A viscous liquid derived from petroleum, especially for use as a fuel or lubricant. – lubricant, lubrication, grease.

  • It’s an old film, but it’s very good. 这是一个老电影，但它是非常好的。
  • He’s only forty-one years old, and he has already been to nearly every country in the world. 他只有41岁，他已是几乎每一个国家在世界上。

  • He calls at every house in the street once a month and always asks for a meal and a glass of beer. 他呼吁在街上每月一次每家，总是要一顿饭和一杯啤酒。

1255. on·ly 只有 ## 153

  • I only have large ones. 我只有路数。

  • He’s only forty-one years old, and he has already been to nearly every country in the world. 他只有41岁，他已是几乎每一个国家在世界上。

1256. o·pen 打开 ## 41

[’oʊpən]adj.开着的；开放的；公开的v.打开；张开；展开；摊开；开始(某事物)；开张；营业；以…开头；宣布启用n.户外；公开

  • Open the window and air the room. 打开窗户，给房间通通风。
