1659. side 侧 ## 34

[saɪd]n.边；侧；边缘；侧面；(多边形的)边；(立体的)面；一方；方面；旁边；家族adj.旁的；次要的v.站在…的一边；支持

  • After a time, we noticed a snake charmer with two large baskets at the other side of the square, so we went to have a look at him. 过了一段时间，我们注意到在广场的另一侧两个大筐的耍蛇人，所以我们去看看他。
  • A policeman approached Jimmy and told him he ought to have gone along a side street as Jumbo was holding up the traffic. 一个警察走过来告诉吉米，他应该走一条小街走了，因为江泊阻碍了交通。
  • Rescue workers are therefore drilling a hole on the north side of the mine. 因此，营救人员钻了矿井的北侧一个洞。

SEE> both 两者, but 但是, well 好

ODE> A position to the left or right of an object, place, or central point. – half, part.

1660. sight 视力 ## 11

[saɪt]n.视力；看见；视线；景物v.瞄准；看见；观测

  • I turned to look at the children, but there weren’t any in sight: they had all run away! 我转过头去看那些孩子，但没有发现任何迹象：他们全都跑了！
  • Byrd now knew that he would be able to reach the South Pole which was 300 miles away, for there were no more mountains in sight. 伯德这时知道他能够顺利到达南极了300英里以外的，因为当时在没有山。
  • The bull was busy with the matador at the time, but it suddenly caught sight of the drunk who was shouting rude remarks and waving a red cap. 公牛正忙着与当时的斗牛士，但突然它看见谁喊着粗鲁的话，挥舞顶红帽子的。

SEE> un·for·tu·nate·ly 不幸的是, in·deed 确实, for·tu·nate·ly

ODE> The faculty or power of seeing. – eyesight, vision, eyes, faculty of sight, power of sight, ability to see, visual perception, observation.

1661. sign 记号 ## 11

[saɪn]n.手势；招牌；符号；迹象；正负号v.签；签名；做手势；做标记

  • That’s why I didn’t see the sign. 这就是为什么我没有看到迹象。
  • What was so funny about the words on the sign? 什么好笑的牌子上的字？
  • Among the rubbish, I found a sign which said, ‘Anyone who leaves litter in these woods will be prosecuted!’ 在垃圾堆中我发现了一块牌子，上面写着：“凡谁在此树林里垃圾会被起诉！”

SEE> deal 交易, in·deed 确实, clear·ly 清楚地

ODE> An object, quality, or event whose presence or occurrence indicates the probable presence or occurrence of something else. – indication, signal, symptom, hint, pointer, suggestion, intimation, mark, manifestation, demonstration.

1662. sig·nal 信号 ## 4

[’sɪɡnəl]n.信号；标志v.(发信号)通知、表示adj.显著的

  • Early next morning, she heard planes passing overhead and wondered how she could send a signal. 第二天一大早，她听到头顶上有飞机，不知道怎样才能发出信号。
  • Fortunately, a pilot saw the signal and sent a message by radio to the nearest town. 幸运的是，一位飞行员看到这个信号，用无线电发送消息到最近的城镇。
  • Even a mighty express train can be held up by signals. 即便是特别快车也可能被信号拦住。

SEE> in·di·ca·tion 迹象, warn·ing 警告, in·deed 确实

ODE> A gesture, action, or sound that is used to convey information or instructions, typically by prearrangement between the parties concerned. – gesture, sign, wave, gesticulation, cue, prompt, indicator, indication, communication, message.

1663. sig·na·ture 签名 ## 4

[’sɪɡnətʃər]n.签署；书帖；有特征的符号；【计】签名

  • He gives the bank specimens of his signature, and there is a very firm rule that the bank has no right or authority to pay out a customer’s money on a cheque on which its customer’s signature has been forged. 他把自己签名的银行样本，并且有一个非常严格的规定，银行没有任何权利或授权支付客户的钱在其上的客户签名已被伪造的支票。
  • It makes no difference that the forgery may have been a very skilful one: the bank must recognize its customer’s signature. 这没有什么区别的是，伪造可能是一个非常巧妙之一：银行必须认识到其客户的签名。
  • Waves are the children of the struggle between ocean and atmosphere, the ongoing signatures of infinity. 波海洋和大气，无限的不间断的标志斗争的孩子。

SEE> in·stance 例子, ex·am·ple 例子, u·nique 独特

ODE> A person’s name written in a distinctive way as a form of identification in authorizing a cheque or document or concluding a letter. – signature, initials.

1664. sig·nif·i·cant 显著的 ## 2

[sɪɡ’nɪfɪkənt]adj.重要的；有意义的；意味深长的；显著的

  • But the significant thing is not the behaviour of the players but the attitude of the spectators: and, behind the spectators, of the nations who work themselves into furies over these absurd contests, and seriously believe – at any rate for short periods – that running, jumping and kicking a ball are tests of national virtue. 但显著的事情是不是运动员的行为，而是观众的态度：和自己的工作谁这些荒唐的比赛泼妇，甚至煞有介事地相信各国的观众身后 - 至少在短期内如此 - 跑跑，跳跳，踢踢球是对一个民族品德素质的检验。
  • The idea of colonising Mars – a world 160 times more distant than the Moon – will move decisively from the second phase to the third, when a significant number of people are living permanently in space. 征服火星的计划 - 一个160倍，比月球更远 - 将从第二阶段果断第三，当人显著数量在太空长期居住。

SEE> sub·stan·tial 大量的, re·sult 结果, im·por·tant 重要

ODE> Sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy. – notable, noteworthy, worthy of attention, remarkable, outstanding, important, of importance, of consequence, consequential.

1665. si·lence 寂静 ## 3

[’saɪləns]n.沉默；寂静vt.使安静；使沉默

  • The silence was suddenly broken when a large car, with its headlights on and its horn blaring, roared down the arcade. 宁静突然被打破，一辆大轿车亮着前灯，响着喇叭，呼啸着冲进了商场。
  • In the eerie silence of the cavern, the only sound that could be heard was made by water which dripped continuously from the high dome above them. 洞里有一种可怕的寂静，也可以听见的声响是由从高高的圆顶上不断滴下的水制成。
  • Whatever the source of noise, one thing is certain: silence, it seems, has become a golden memory. 不管噪声来自何方，有一点是肯定的：看来寂静，已经成为一种珍贵的回忆。

SEE> qui·et 安静, si·lent 沉默的, in·deed 确实

ODE> Complete absence of sound. – quietness, quiet, quietude, still, stillness, hush, tranquillity, noiselessness, soundlessness, peace, peacefulness, peace and quiet.

1666. si·lent 沉默的 ## 3

[’saɪlənt]adj.安静的；不吵闹的；沉默的；无言的

  • The big clock which used to strike the hours day and night was damaged many years ago and has been silent ever since. 它用来撞击小时昼夜的大钟在很多年前遭到毁坏，因为一直沉默永远。
  • Why was the village silent? 为什么村里的沉默？
  • When we later walked down the main street of the village, we were followed by a silent procession of children. 当我们后来下来村里的主要街道上走着，我们再接孩子的无声游行。

SEE> si·lence 寂静, like·wise , cu·ri·ous·ly 好奇地

ODE> Not making or accompanied by any sound. – completely quiet, still, hushed, inaudible, noiseless, soundless, peaceful, tranquil, so quiet you could hear a pin drop.

1667. sil·ly 愚蠢 ## 2

[’sɪli]adj.愚蠢的；琐屑的；可笑的；犯晕的n.（通常指小孩子）淘气鬼；傻孩子

  • He added that a student had dressed up as a policeman and was playing all sorts of silly jokes on people. 他补充说，有个学生常装扮成警察，并无聊地同别人开玩笑。
  • That sounds a silly suggestion, but that was precisely the idea adopted in some of the early instruments (seismometers) for recording earthquake waves. 这听起来愚蠢的想法，但正是在一些早期的仪器（地震）记录地震波所采用的想法。

SEE> stu·pid 笨, ri·dic·u·lous 荒谬, a·mus·ing 有趣的

ODE> Having or showing a lack of common sense or judgement; absurd and foolish. – foolish, stupid, unintelligent, idiotic, brainless, mindless, witless, imbecilic, imbecile, doltish.

1668. sil·ver 银 ## 3

[’sɪlvər]n.银币；银器；银；银灰色adj.银的；银色的vt.镀银于；使 … 成银色

  • One of the most handsome cars was a Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost. 最漂亮的汽车之一是劳斯莱斯银鬼。
  • It had a head like a horse, big blue eyes, shining silver skin, and a bright red tail. 它有一个头似马，蓝色的大眼睛，闪闪发光的银色皮肤，还有一条鲜红色的尾巴。
  • The parquet floors shone like mirrors; highly polished silver was displayed in gleaming glass cabinets; even my uncle’s huge collection of books was kept miraculously free from dust. 洁如镜的镶木地板;高度抛光的银陈列在明亮的玻璃橱柜;连姑夫的大量藏书保持奇迹般地一尘不染。

SEE> gold 黄金, bronze , med·al

ODE> A precious shiny greyish-white metal, the chemical element of atomic number 47. – silverware, plate, silver plate.

1669. sim·i·lar 类似 ## 8

[’sɪmələr]adj.类似的

  • However, as the evidence began to accumulate, experts from the Zoo felt obliged to investigate, for the descriptions given by people who claimed to have seen the puma were extraordinarily similar. 然而，随着证据越来越多，动物园的专家们感到有必要调查，通过谁声称见到过美洲狮的人们所描述的情况竟是出奇地相似。
  • It was impossible for the Ombudsman to take action, but when he received a similar complaint from another foreigner in the same village, he immediately sent one of his lawyers to investigate the matter. 这是不可能的监察员采取行动，但他在同村接到类似投诉的另一个外国人，他立即派出一位律师对此事进行调查。
  • Other experiments showed that her knees and shoulders had a similar sensitivity. 其他实验表明，她的膝盖和肩膀有类似的感觉。

SEE> same 相同, ex·am·ple 例子, in·stance 例子

ODE> Having a resemblance in appearance, character, or quantity, without being identical. – alike, the same, much the same, indistinguishable, close, near, almost identical, homogeneous, interchangeable.

1670. sim·ple 简单 ## 16

[’sɪmpl]adj.简单的；朴素的；单纯的；笨的

  • The explanation was simple but very unusual. 解释很简单，但非常不寻常的。
  • People who work in offices are frequently referred to as ‘white-collar workers’ for the simple reason that they usually wear a collar and tie to go to work. 人谁在办公室工作，常常被称作“白领”，原因很简单，他们通常是穿着硬领和领带去上班。
  • Life there is simple and good. 在那里，生活简单又美好。

SEE> straight·for·ward , ra·ther 相当, ex·am·ple 例子

ODE> Easily understood or done; presenting no difficulty. – straightforward, easy, uncomplicated, uninvolved, effortless, painless, manageable, undemanding, unexacting, elementary, child’s play, plain sailing, a five-finger exercise, nothing.

1671. sim·ply 只是 ## 16

[’sɪmpli]adv.简单地；仅仅；简直

  • Then the woman simply took the parcel and walked out of the shop without paying. 然后，那妇女拿过包就从商店出来，无需支付。
  • Though people have often laughed at stories told by seamen, it is now known that many of these ‘monsters’ which have at times been sighted are simply strange fish. 虽然人们海员所讲的故事常常嘲笑，现在已知许多这些“妖怪”具有有时被看见的不过是些奇怪的鱼。
  • He simply told her that he worked for the Corporation. 他只是告诉她，他任职于公司。

SEE> mere·ly 仅仅, ra·ther 相当, in·stead 代替

ODE> In a straightforward or plain manner. – straightforwardly, directly.

1672. since 从…以来 ## 30

[sɪns]conj.因为；既然；自从prep.自从adv.此后

  • Yes, I’ve been here since 1976. 是的，我一直在这里自1976年以来。
  • He has just bought a new house in the city, but ever since he moved in, he has had trouble with cars and their owners. 他刚在城里买下一所新房子，但自从搬进来，他就和汽车及车主们的麻烦。
  • Since then, Captain Fawcett has flown passengers to many unusual places. 自那时以来，福塞特上尉空运乘客到过许多不寻常的地方。

SEE> last 最后的, a·go 前, dec·ade 十年

ODE> In the intervening period between (the time mentioned) and the time under consideration, typically the present. – since, as, for the reason that, in view of the fact that, owing to the fact that, seeing as, seeing that.

1673. sing 唱 ## 4

[sɪŋ]v.唱；鸣叫；歌颂；称赞；告密n.合唱会abbr.单数的（=singular）

  • In return for this, the beggar stood on his head and sang songs. 作为回报，那乞丐站在他的头上还唱着歌。
  • At that moment, everybody began to laugh and sing. 在那一刻，每个人都开始笑和唱歌。
  • After a wonderful meal, they told stories and sang songs by the campfire. 美餐之后，他们讲起了故事，篝火，唱起了歌。

SEE> sing·ing 唱歌, tune 曲调, lis·ten 听

ODE> Make musical sounds with the voice, especially words with a set tune. – chant, intone, croon, carol, chorus, warble, trill, pipe, quaver.

1674. sing·er 歌手 ## 2

[’sɪŋər]n.歌手；鸣禽n.烧毛工；烧毛机Singer: 辛格(姓氏).

  • The Greenwood Boys are a group of pop singers. 绿林少年是一个流行歌曲演唱团。
  • The mummy is that of Shepenmut who was once a singer in the Temple of Thebes. 木乃伊是Shepenmut的谁是曾在底比斯神庙歌手。

SEE> mu·si·cian 音乐家, pop 流行, song 歌曲

ODE> A person who sings, especially professionally. – vocalist, soloist, songster, songstress.

1675. sin·gle 单个的 ## 10

[’sɪŋɡl]adj.单一的；单个的；特指某人或某物；单身的；单人的；单程的n.单程票；单曲；单人房间；单身者；一元纸币；(网球)单打比赛；(板球)一分打；(棒球)一垒打v.挑选(一个)

  • I spent the whole day in my room, but I did not write a single card! 我花了整整一天在我的房间，但我没有写单卡！
  • He earned enormous sums of money and was paid as much as ￡100 for a single appearance. 他赚了大笔大笔的钱，一次出场费就高达£100单的外观。
  • No matter how hard I tried, it was impossible to fill this beautiful pen with ink and to this day it has never written a single word! 无论怎么说我试过了，这是不可能填补这个漂亮的钢笔墨水，并到今天它也没写过一个字！

SEE> one 一, first 第一, on·ly 只有

ODE> Only one; not one of several. – one, one only, sole, lone, solitary, isolated, by itself.

1676. sink 下沉 ## 7

[sɪŋk]v.下沉；沉没；渗透；低落；变低；衰弱；（太阳）落下n.水槽；沟渠；散热器；接收端

  • Below, the captain realized to his horror that the Titanic was sinking rapidly, for five of her sixteen watertight compartments had already been flooded! 下面，实现了他惊恐的队长是泰坦尼克号正在急速下沉，16个密封舱已有5个进水。
  • During the journey, their boat began to sink. 途中，船开始下沉。
  • What they had in fact found was a ship which had been sunk many years before. 他们实际上已经发现这已经很多年以前沉没的船。

SEE> for·tu·nate·ly , like·wise , un·for·tu·nate·ly 不幸的是

ODE> Go down below the surface of something, especially of a liquid; become submerged. – become submerged, be engulfed, go down, drop, fall, descend.

1677. sir 先生 ## 19

[sɜːr]n. 先生； 阁下Sirn. （用于姓名前） … 爵士

  • Thank you, sir. 谢谢你，先生。
  • Sorry sir. 对不起，先生。
  • Perhaps it is, sir. 也许是的，先生。

SEE> grand·son 孙子, neph·ew 外甥, eld·est

ODE> Used as a polite or respectful way of addressing a man, especially one in a position of authority. –

1678. sis·ter 妹妹 ## 6

[’sɪstər]n.姐妹

  • But my sister bought this pair last month. 但是，我姐姐上个月买到了这样的一双。
  • I had a letter from my sister yesterday. 昨天我收到了姐姐的一封信。
  • Work on it had begun before my sister left. 房子在我姐姐离开之前就已经开始。

SEE> moth·er 母亲, daugh·ter 女儿, niece 侄女

ODE> A woman or girl in relation to other daughters and sons of her parents. – female sibling.

1679. sit 坐 ## 31

[sɪt]v.坐；栖息；使就座n.坐；栖息

  • Sit down here. 在这里坐下。
  • She’s sitting under the tree. 她坐在树下。
  • Then he sat there and looked at it for three hours! 然后他就坐在那里，看着3个小时！

SEE> wait 等待, stand 站立, let 让

ODE> Adopt or be in a position in which one’s weight is supported by one’s buttocks rather than one’s feet and one’s back is upright. – take a seat, seat oneself, settle down, be seated, take a chair.

1680. site 地点 ## 7

[saɪt]n.地点；位置；现场vt.使 … 位于

  • Before it could be transported to the United States, a site had to be found for it and a pedestal had to be built. 之前，它被运往美国，一个网站有它被发现和一个基座，同时必须建造。
  • The site chosen was an island at the entrance of New York Harbour. 场地选在了纽约港入口处的一个岛上。
  • We are lucky in that only the lower fields, which make up a very small proportion of our farm, are affected by flooding, but other farms are less favourably sited, and flooding can sometimes spell disaster for their owners. 我们是只有较低的领域，从而弥补了我们农场比例很小幸运，是由洪水的影响，但其他农场地势欠佳，和洪水有时会给农场主带来灾难。

SEE> web 卷筒纸, lo·ca·tion 位置, which 哪一个

ODE> An area of ground on which a town, building, or monument is constructed. – plot, lot, area.

1681. sit·u·a·tion 情况 ## 9

[ˌsɪtʃu’eɪʃn]n.形势；局面；位置；职位；处境；状况

  • This can give rise to curious situations, as it did in the case of Alfred Bloggs who worked as a dustman for the Ellesmere Corporation. 这种种奇怪的现象引起的，因为它在艾尔弗雷德布洛斯的谁作为埃尔斯米尔公司一个清洁工的工作的情况下做到了。
  • She tried to explain the situation, saying ‘It’s only me’, but it was too late. 她试图解释情况，说“这只是我”，但为时已晚。
  • He described it as ‘a very agreeable situation located within two small hills in the midst of which flowed a great river.’ 他将其形容为“一家位于其中的流入一条大河中间的两个小山头一个非常愉快的局面。”

SEE> con·cerned 关心的, ob·vi·ous·ly 显然, dif·fi·cult 困难的

ODE> A set of circumstances in which one finds oneself; a state of affairs. – circumstances, set of circumstances, state of affairs, affairs, state, condition, case.

1682. six 六 ## 17

[sɪks]num.六

  • It is six o’clock. 这是六点钟。
  • Then I arrived home at six o’clock yesterday evening. 然后，我回到家里昨晚6点钟。
  • I said I would be at your house at six o’clock, but the boss wants me to do some extra work. 我说，我会在你的房子在六点钟，但老板要我做一些额外的工作。

SEE> five 五, eight 八, four 四

ODE> Equivalent to the product of two and three; one more than five, or four less than ten; 6. – sextet, sextuplets.

1683. six·teen 十六 ## 6

[ˌsɪks’tiːn]num.十六

  • I could answer sixteen of the questions. 我能回答的16道题。
  • As it is, they have been drilling for sixteen hours and they still have a long way to go. 正因为如此，他们已经钻了16个小时，他们还有很长的路要走。
  • What would have happened if only two of the sixteen water-tight compartments had been flooded? 如果只有两个十六个水密舱已被洪水淹没，将会发生什么？

SEE> four·teen 十四, fif·teen 十五, sev·en·teen 十七

ODE> Equivalent to the product of four and four; one more than fifteen, or six more than ten; 16. –

1684. sixth 第六 ## 3

[sɪksθ]n.六分之一；六度音num.第六

  • He’ll be her sixth husband! 他将是她的第6个丈夫！
  • They were expecting their sixth child and were faced with even more pressing economic problems. 他们正期待他们的第六个孩子，并面临着更为严峻的经济问题。
  • Because the gravity on the Moon’s surface is only a sixth of Earth’s (remember how easily the Apollo astronauts bounded along), it takes much less energy to accelerate to that 1.5 miles per second than it does on Earth. 由于月球表面的引力只有地球的（还记得阿波罗宇航员累松地跳跃沿）的第六，它需要少得多的能量加速到每秒比它在地球上有150英里。

SEE> sev·enth 第七, fifth 第五, eighth 第八

ODE> Constituting number six in a sequence; 6th. –

1685. six·ty 六十 ## 3

[’sɪksti]n.六十adj.六十的；六十个的

  • The day after the birth of the five children, an aeroplane arrived in Aberdeen bringing sixty reporters and photographers. 五胞胎出生后的第二天，一架飞机飞抵香港仔，随机带来60名记者与摄影师。
  • This figure rises to a staggering 60% of men in their sixties. 这个数字上升到男性60岁了惊人的60％。
  • The modern weather models work with a grid of points of the order of sixty miles apart, and even so, some starting data has to be guessed, since ground stations and satellites cannot see everywhere. 现代气象模型以60英里。为了点的网格工作分开，即使如此，有些开始时的资料也不得不猜测，因为地面工作站和卫星不可能看到无处不在。

SEE> eight·y 八十, for·ty 四十, thir·ty 三十

ODE> The number equivalent to the product of six and ten; ten more than fifty; 60. –

1686. size 尺寸 ## 19

[saɪz]n.大小；规模；尺寸；尺码；浆料；胶料v.按大小排列(或分类)；给…上胶adj.（用于复合词）…大小的

  • Do you want the large size or the small size? 你要大号还是小号的？
  • The large size, please. 大尺寸，请。
  • What size? 什么尺寸？

SEE> large 大, small 小, same 相同

ODE> The relative extent of something; a thing’s overall dimensions or magnitude; how big something is. – dimensions, measurements, proportions, magnitude, largeness, bigness, bulk, area, expanse, square footage, footage, acreage.

1687. skin 皮肤 ## 7

[skɪn]n.皮肤；外皮；皮囊n.惊讶；生气vt.剥皮；削皮；贴皮；蹭破皮；击败

  • The operation, which lasted for over four hours, proved to be very difficult because of the hard resin which covered the skin. 操作，这持续了4个小时，证明是因为其覆盖的皮肤硬质树脂的非常困难。
  • It had a head like a horse, big blue eyes, shining silver skin, and a bright red tail. 它有一个头似马，蓝色的大眼睛，闪闪发光的银色皮肤，还有一条鲜红色的尾巴。
  • If you expressed doubt or surprise, he would immediately invite you to smell it and then to rub some into your skin. 如果你表示怀疑或惊奇，他会立即请你闻一闻，然后取出一些抹在你的皮肤。

SEE> flesh 肉, tis·sue , hair 头发

ODE> The thin layer of tissue forming the natural outer covering of the body of a person or animal. – epidermis, dermis.

1688. skirt 短裙 ## 2

[skɜːrt]n.裙子；下摆；边缘；郊区；挡板v.装边于；位于(边缘)；绕开

  • Short skirts are in fashion now. 短裙现在很流行。
  • She was wearing a full-length skirt which swept the ground. 她穿着一件拖地全长裙子。

SEE> blouse , trou·sers 长裤, dress 连衣裙

ODE> A woman’s outer garment fastened around the waist and hanging down around the legs. – go round, move round, walk round, circle, circumnavigate.

1689. sky 天空 ## 6

[skaɪ]n.天空；天气；天国v.把…投向空中；将…高挂

  • There are some clouds in the sky, but the sun is shining. 还有在天空中飘着几朵云，但阳光灿烂。
  • If the landscape is hidden from view, you can enjoy the extraordinary sight of unbroken cloud plains that stretch out for miles before you, while the sun shines brilliantly in a clear sky. 如果景色被遮住了，你可以观赏一下展现在伸出你之前英里完整的云平原，而太阳在晴朗的天空灿烂。
  • Even under a clear blue sky, the village looked forbidding, as all the houses were built of grey mud bricks. 即使在晴朗的蓝天，村庄看上去可怕的，因为所有的房子建造的泥灰色的砖块。

SEE> bright 明亮的, ho·ri·zon , dark·ness

ODE> The region of the atmosphere and outer space seen from the earth. – the atmosphere, the stratosphere, the skies, airspace.

1690. sleep 睡觉 ## 26

[sliːp]v.睡觉n.睡眠；睡觉

  • ‘Go back to sleep.’ ‘回去睡觉。’
  • Their sleeping bags were warm and comfortable, so they all slept soundly. 睡袋既暖和又舒服，所以，他们都睡得很香。
  • They all leapt out of their sleeping bags and hurried outside. 他们全都跳出自己的睡袋，跑到外面。

SEE> a·sleep 睡着, bed 床, an·y·way 无论如何

ODE> A condition of body and mind which typically recurs for several hours every night, in which the nervous system is inactive, the eyes closed, the postural muscles relaxed, and consciousness practically suspended. – nap, doze, rest, siesta, drowse, catnap.

1691. sleeve 袖子 ## 2

[sliːv]n.套管；袖子

  • George took off his jacket, rolled up his sleeves and pushed his right arm through the drain cover. 乔治脱掉外套，挽起袖子，并通过排盖推开他的右臂。
  • Men in shirt sleeves stood outside their houses and glared at us. 穿着衬衣的男人站在外面自己的房子，并瞪着我们。

SEE> jack·et 夹克, shirt 衬衫, pants 裤子

ODE> The part of a garment that wholly or partly covers a person’s arm. – sleeve.

1692. slide 滑动 ## 3

[slaɪd]vi.滑动；下滑；滑入；悄悄地溜走vt.使滑动n.幻灯片；滑坡；滑动；雪崩

  • The lorry was loaded with empty beer bottles and hundreds of them slid off the back of the vehicle and on to the road. 卡车上装着空啤酒瓶，成百只滑出车的后面，落在马路上。
  • For one agonizing moment, the dish was perched precariously on the bank of the canal, but it suddenly overbalanced and slid back into the water. 在令人忐忑不安的瞬间，盘子晃晃悠悠地上了了岸，但它突然失去了平衡，又跌回水中。
  • Then the sound of rumbling thunder reached the watchers on the shore, as cargo, ballast, ammunition and 400 people went sliding and crashing down to the port side of the steeply listing ship. 随后雷声隆隆的声音传到上，岸上的观众，为货物，压舱物，弹药以及400人的滑动和崩塌下来的急剧倾斜的船体左舷。

SEE> plunge , drop 掉落, fall 下落

ODE> Move smoothly along a surface while maintaining continuous contact with it. – glide, move smoothly, slip, slither, skim, skate, glissade, coast, plane.

1693. slight·ly 略微 ## 3

[’slaɪtli]adv.些微地；稍微；瘦小地

  • The sudden movement of the door made it sway slightly and it gave me the impression that it was about to leap out at me. 门的突然运动使它稍微摇摆，它给我的印象是，它是关于我扑过来。
  • Carbonated drinks are acidic, and slightly safer. 碳酸饮料是酸性的，就更安全。
  • It will be found that the weight moves but slightly or not at all. 将发现的重量移动，但在所有的轻微或没有。

SEE> some·what 有些, con·sid·er·a·bly 相当大地, noticeably

ODE> To a small degree; not considerably. – a little, a bit, somewhat, rather, moderately, to some degree, to a certain extent, to a slight extent, faintly, vaguely, obscurely.

1694. slip 滑倒 ## 5

[slɪp]v.滑倒；滑脱；疏忽；溜走n.疏忽；滑倒；溜走；失误

  • I slipped and fell downstairs. 我滑倒了楼下。
  • He was still mumbling something about hospitals at the end of the party when he slipped on a piece of ice and broke his left leg. 他仍然在晚会结束喃喃自语着医院的事时，他滑倒一块冰上了，摔断了左腿。
  • We also make the fundamental error of announcing our resolutions to everybody so that we look even more foolish when we slip back into our bad old ways. 我们也做宣布我们决心向大家一个根本性的错误，使我们，当我们重新陷入我们的那些老习惯看起来更加愚蠢。

SEE> catch 抓住, slide 滑动, fall 下落

ODE> Lose one’s footing and slide unintentionally for a short distance. – slide, skid, slither, glide.

1695. slope 斜坡 ## 4

[sloʊp]n.倾斜；斜坡；斜面；斜率；斜线vt.使倾斜vi.倾斜；有坡度

  • From the shore line, out to a distance which may be anywhere from a few miles to a few hundred miles, runs the gentle slope of the continental shelf, geologically part of the continents. 从岸上行，出这可能是几百英里几英里的任何地方的距离，运行大陆架的缓坡，大陆的地质一部分。
  • The real dividing line between continents and oceans occurs at the foot of a steeper slope. 大陆和海洋之间的真实划分线发生在更陡的斜率的脚下。
  • This continental slope usually starts at a place somewhere near the 100-fathom mark and in the course of a few hundred miles reaches the true ocean floor at 2,500-3,500 fathoms. 这陆坡通常开始于近100揣摸标记的某处，并在几百英里的过程中到达2500-3500噚真正的海底。

SEE> steep 陡峭的, slip·per·y , curve 曲线

ODE> A surface of which one end or side is at a higher level than another; a rising or falling surface. – gradient, incline, angle, slant, inclination, pitch, decline, ascent, declivity, acclivity, rise, fall, downward, upward, downslope, upslope, ramp, rake, tilt, tip, dip, camber, cant, bevel.

1696. slow 慢 ## 6

[sloʊ]adj.慢的adv.慢慢地v.放慢；减速

  • That clock’s ten minutes slow. 那时钟的慢了10分钟。
  • A painter who had been working on the tower hung a pot of paint on one of the hands and slowed it down! 谁一直工作在塔架上的画家挂漆一壶在手之一，慢了！
  • On this occasion, however, it had slowed down considerably. 在此之际，但是，它已经大大放缓。

SEE> pa·ce 步伐, fast 快速, ac·cel·er·ate

ODE> Moving or operating, or designed to do so, only at a low speed; not quick or fast. – unhurried, leisurely, measured, moderate, deliberate, steady, sedate, slow-moving, slow-going, easy, relaxed, unrushed, gentle, undemanding, comfortable.

1697. slow·ly 慢慢地 ## 17

[’sloʊli]adv.缓慢地

  • He read the phrase slowly. 他缓慢地读着短语。
  • I was telling him to drive slowly. 我告诉他开慢点。
  • I told you to drive slowly, Gary. 我跟你开慢点，加里。

SEE> grad·u·al·ly 逐渐地, rap·id·ly 迅速地, stead·i·ly 稳步地

ODE> At a slow speed; not quickly. – unhurriedly, without hurrying, at a leisurely pace, at a slow pace, leisurely, steadily, taking one’s time, in one’s own good time.

1698. small 小 ## 68

[smɔːl]adj.小的；年幼的；少的；不重要的；小气的adv.小地；小块地；小声地n.狭小部分；(pl.)零星物品；(pl.)小件衣服

  • Mrs. Smith’s kitchen is small. 史密斯夫人的厨房很小。
  • Do you want the large size or the small size? 你要大号还是小号的？
  • I don’t have any small pads. 我没有小本的信纸。

SEE> large 大, ti·ny 极小的, few 少数

ODE> Of a size that is less than normal or usual. – little, small-scale, compact, bijou.

1699. smart 聪明 ## 4

[smɑːrt]adj.时髦的；漂亮的；聪明的；敏捷的；整洁的；厉害的vi.刺痛；难过；烦恼n.刺痛；苦恼adv.（=smartly）

  • It’s very smart. 这是非常聪明的。
  • It’s very smart. 这是非常聪明的。
  • Every morning, he left home dressed in a smart black suit. 每天早晨，他离开家漂亮的黑色西装打扮。

SEE> in·tel·li·gent 智能的, clev·er 聪明, kind 种类

ODE> (of a person) clean, tidy, and well dressed. – well dressed, well turned out, fashionably dressed, fashionable, stylish, chic, modish, elegant, neat, besuited, spruce, trim, dapper, debonair.

1700. smash 打碎 ## 3

[smæʃ]v.打碎；粉碎；猛撞n.破碎；撞击；轰动的演出；[网球]高压扣球adj.极为成功的

  • Although the bed was smashed to pieces, the man was miraculously unhurt. 尽管床摔成了碎片，但年轻人却奇迹般地没有受伤。
  • One man stayed at the wheel while two others with black stockings over their faces jumped out and smashed the window of the shop with iron bars. 一人留在驾驶座上，另外两个用黑色长筒丝袜他们的脸跳了出来，砸坏用铁棒在商店的橱窗。
  • While you are on the phone, the baby pulls the tablecloth off the table, smashing half your best crockery and cutting himself in the process. 当你接电话时，孩子把桌布从桌子上半数摔碎，最好的陶器和切割自己的过程。

SEE> break 打破, luck·i·ly , grab 抓住

ODE> Violently break (something) into pieces. – break, break to pieces, smash to smithereens, shatter.

1701. smell 闻 ## 3

[smel]n.气味；嗅觉；嗅v.嗅；闻；散发气味；有臭味；察觉

  • They were all hungry and the food smelled good. 他们都饿了，饭菜散发出阵阵香味。
  • He was greeted by an unpleasant smell which convinced him that I was telling the truth. 他被这让他相信我说的是真话难闻的气味招呼。
  • If you expressed doubt or surprise, he would immediately invite you to smell it and then to rub some into your skin. 如果你表示怀疑或惊奇，他会立即请你闻一闻，然后取出一些抹在你的皮肤。

SEE> o·dor , scent , taste 味道

ODE> The faculty or power of perceiving odours or scents by means of the organs in the nose. – odour, whiff.

1702. smile 微笑 ## 13

[smaɪl]n.微笑；笑容v.微笑；露出笑容

  • The man smiled pleasantly. 这人友好地笑了笑。
  • ‘Nothing, Henry,’ George said and smiled. “没事，亨利。”乔治说，笑了。
  • She put away her compact and smiled kindly. 她放好了粉盒，慈祥地微笑着。

SEE> grin , laugh 笑, cheer·ful 欢快的

ODE> Form one’s features into a pleased, kind, or amused expression, typically with the corners of the mouth turned up and the front teeth exposed. – grin, beam, grin like a Cheshire cat, grin from ear to ear, twinkle.

1703. smoke 抽烟 ## 6

[smoʊk]n.烟；抽烟；无常的事物v.吸烟；以烟熏；冒烟

  • Eat more and smoke less! 多吃点，少抽点！
  • Now, smoke still rose up from the warm ground over the desolate hills. 现在，浓烟仍从发热的地面上荒凉的山丘上。
  • I smoked with concentration and pleasure as I was sure that this would be my last cigarette. 我聚精会神而又愉快地吸着，因为我相信这将是我最后一根烟。

SEE> fumes , burn·ing , smo·king 抽烟

ODE> A visible suspension of carbon or other particles in air, typically one emitted from a burning substance. – fumes, exhaust, gas, vapour.

1704. smo·king 抽烟 ## 5

[’smoʊkɪŋ]adj.抽烟的；熏制的n.吸烟；吸烟区动词smoke的现在分词.

  • For how long did the writer give up smoking? 多久没作家放弃吸烟？
  • After reading an article entitled ‘Cigarette Smoking and Your Health’ I lit a cigarette to calm my nerves. 阅读一篇文章，题为“吸烟与健康”后，我点了一支烟，镇静一下紧张情绪。
  • I had all the usual symptoms of someone giving up smoking: a bad temper and an enormous appetite. 我只好一个人戒烟的所有常见的症状：脾气暴躁和食欲旺盛。

SEE> to·bac·co , cig·a·rette 香烟, smoke 抽烟

ODE> The action or habit of inhaling and exhaling the smoke of tobacco by sucking on the end of a lit cigarette, cigar, pipe, etc. –

1705. smooth 光滑的 ## 2

[smuːð]adj.光滑的；平稳的；流畅的；圆滑的；可口的；安祥的；均匀的v.使光滑；消除；安慰；理顺(羽毛)

  • The sides of the dish were so smooth that it was almost impossible to attach hawsers and chains to the rim without damaging it. 培养皿的四边十分光滑，这是几乎不可能拴上绳索或链条到轮辋而不损坏它。
  • The journey is so smooth that there is nothing to prevent you from reading or sleeping. 在旅途平稳，没有什么阻止你阅读或睡眠。

SEE> tran·si·tion , smooth·ly 顺利地, shape 形状

ODE> Having an even and regular surface; free from perceptible projections, lumps, or indentations. – even, level, flat, as flat as a pancake, plane, flush, unwrinkled, featureless.

1706. smooth·ly 顺利地 ## 2

[’smuːðli]adv.平滑地；流畅地

  • They have been told that rescue operations are progressing smoothly. 他们被告知营救工作进行得非常顺利。
  • Later it crossed the Channel, riding smoothly over the waves, which presented no problem. 后来，它跨越英吉利海峡，顺利地骑在汹涌的，没有出现问题。

SEE> pro·ceed 继续, fair·ly 相当地, slow·ly 慢慢地

ODE> In a smooth way. – evenly, level, flat, flush, as flat as a pancake, horizontally.

1707. snake 蛇 ## 17

[sneɪk]n.蛇；狡诈的人v.蜿蜒；拖曳

  • What happened when the snake charmer began to play jazz? 发生了什么事时，耍蛇人开始演奏爵士乐吗？
  • After a time, we noticed a snake charmer with two large baskets at the other side of the square, so we went to have a look at him. 过了一段时间，我们注意到在广场的另一侧两个大筐的耍蛇人，所以我们去看看他。
  • When he began to play a tune, we had our first glimpse of the snake. 当他开始吹奏一支曲子时，我们才蛇的第一印象。

SEE> crea·ture 生物, rat , mon·key

ODE> A long limbless reptile which has no eyelids, a short tail, and jaws that are capable of considerable extension. Some snakes have a venomous bite. – serpent.

1708. snow 雪 ## 5

[snoʊ]n.雪；积雪；下雪vi.下雪vt.使变白；雪覆盖

  • Does it ever snow in Greece? 下过雪在希腊？
  • It snows sometimes. 有时还下雪。
  • The most surprising thing about it, however, is that it can land anywhere: on snow, water, or even on a ploughed field. 它最令人惊奇的事情，但问题在于，它可以在任何地方降落：雪地上，水面上，甚至耕过的田里。

SEE> rain 下雨, fog , win·ter 冬季

ODE> Atmospheric water vapour frozen into ice crystals and falling in light white flakes or lying on the ground as a white layer. – snowflakes, flakes, snowdrift, snowfield, snowpack.

1709. so 所以 ## 172

[soʊ]adv.那么；这样；如此adj.真的；非常pron.这样conj.因此；所以；以便

  • He has a bad cold, Mr. Williams, so he must stay in bed for a week. 他得了重感冒，威廉斯先生，因此他必须卧床一周。
  • I can’t get home so early, Dad! 我不能回家，所以早，爸爸！
  • On the way home, my wife said to me, ’Don’t drive so quickly! 在回家的路上，我的妻子对我说，“不要这么快开车！

SEE> but 但是, be·cause 因为, too 太

ODE> To such a great extent. – extremely, very, exceedingly, exceptionally, especially, extraordinarily, tremendously, vastly, hugely, abundantly, intensely, acutely, singularly, significantly, distinctly, outstandingly, uncommonly, unusually, decidedly, particularly, eminently, supremely, highly, remarkably, really, truly, mightily, thoroughly, to a fault, in the extreme, extra.

1710. soap 肥皂 ## 3

[soʊp]n.肥皂；肥皂剧vt.用肥皂洗；阿谀奉承

  • A bar of soap. 一块肥皂。
  • A crowd of people gathered round him and a lady rubbed his arm with soap and butter, but George was firmly stuck. 一大群人围拢过来，一位女士胳膊上抹了肥皂，黄油，但乔治是牢牢卡住。
  • Gifts poured in not only from unknown people, but from baby food and soap manufacturers who wished to advertise their products. 礼品不但素昧平生的人，但婴儿食品，婴儿肥皂制造商谁希望自己的产品做广告浇英寸

SEE> day·time , sham·poo , TV 电视

ODE> A substance used with water for washing and cleaning, made of a compound of natural oils or fats with sodium hydroxide or another strong alkali, and typically having perfume and colouring added. – wash, soak, dip, shower, douche, soaping, sponging, toilet.

1711. so·cial 社会的 ## 7

[’soʊʃl]adj.社会的；社会阶层的；群居的；社交的；好交际的；合群的n.社交聚会；社会保障

  • They disregard social conventions without being conscious that they are doing anything extraordinary. 他们不顾社会习俗，意识不到自己所作所为有什么特殊之处。
  • The Scandinavian countries are much admired all over the world for their enlightened social policies. 斯堪的纳维亚国家都非常敬佩全世界为他们开明的社会政策。
  • They are not anxious social climbers, and they have no devotion to material things. 他们不是焦虑的向上爬的人，他们没有奉献给物质性的东西。

SEE> wel·fare , con·text 上下文, ed·u·ca·tion 教育

ODE> Relating to society or its organization. – communal, community, community-based, collective, group, general, popular, civil, civic, public, societal.

1712. so·ci·e·ty 社会 ## 12

[sə’saɪəti]n.社会；(共同遵守一定的习俗、法律等的）特定群体；社团；协会；上层社会；社交圈；交往

  • The conditions of society are such that skills have to be paid for in the same way that goods are paid for at a shop. 社会上的情况就是如此，技术在同样的方式，货物支付在店支付。
  • He investigates complaints large and small that come to him from all levels of society. 他研究大，小抱怨，来找他从社会的各个层面。
  • Knowing that the industrious ant lives in a highly organized society does nothing to prevent us from being filled with revulsion when we find hordes of them crawling over a carefully prepared picnic lunch. 即使知道勤奋的蚂蚁生活具有高度组织性的社会无助于阻止我们充满反感，当我们发现他们成群爬了精心准备的野餐。

SEE> fur·ther·more , more·o·ver 此外, in·deed 确实

ODE> The aggregate of people living together in a more or less ordered community. – the community, the public, the general public, the people, the population.

1713. soil 泥土 ## 4

[sɔɪl]n.土地；土壤；污物，粪便v.弄污

  • The leader of the party was examining the soil near the entrance to the cave when the machine showed that there was gold under the ground. 党的队长正在检查附近的洞口土壤时，机器显示有地下金。
  • Winter was coming on and the hills threatened the surrounding villages with destruction, for heavy rain would not only wash away the soil but would cause serious floods as well. 冬季即将来临，这些山丘威胁周围村庄具有毁灭性的，因为大雨不仅会冲走土壤，而且还会引起严重的水灾。
  • In place of the great trees which had been growing there for centuries, patches of green had begun to appear in the blackened soil. 上，代替了多少世纪以来一直生长在那里的参天大树，片的绿草开始出现在这片烧焦的土壤。

SEE> sur·face 表面, ground 地面, fur·ther·more

ODE> The upper layer of earth in which plants grow, a black or dark brown material typically consisting of a mixture of organic remains, clay, and rock particles. – earth, loam, sod, ground, dirt, clay, turf, topsoil, mould, humus, marl, dust.

1714. sol·dier 士兵 ## 3

[’soʊldʒər]n.士兵；军人vi.当兵；坚持做

  • Six hundred years ago, Sir John Hawkwood arrived in Italy with a band of soldiers and settled near Florence. 六百年前，约翰。霍克伍德就有来到意大利，在一队士兵佛罗伦萨附近驻扎下来。
  • Whenever the Italian city-states were at war with each other, Hawkwood used to hire his soldiers to princes who were willing to pay the high price he demanded. 每当意大利城邦在战争与对方，霍克沃德用于雇佣他的士兵诸侯谁愿意付出高昂的代价，他的要求。
  • When he died at the age of eighty, the Florentines gave him a state funeral and had a picture painted which was dedicated to the memory of ‘the most valiant soldier and most notable leader, Signor Giovanni Haukodue’. 当他80岁那年死去时，佛罗伦萨人为他举行了国葬，并曾画了一幅画这是献给“最英勇的战士，最显着的领先地位，贝卢斯科尼乔瓦尼Haukodue”的记忆。

SEE> po·lice·man , ar·my 军队, man 男人

ODE> A person who serves in an army. – fighter, serviceman, servicewoman, fighting man, fighting woman, comrade-in-arms, warrior, trooper.

1715. sol·id 固体 ## 9

[’sɑːlɪd]adj.固体的；实心的；结实的；可靠的n.固体；立体图形adv.一致地

  • She will have something to drink but she will not eat any solid food. 她将喝些饮料，但她不会吃任何固体食物。
  • Several cases have been reported in Russia recently of people who can read and detect colours with their fingers, and even see through solid doors and walls. 几个事例，据报道，在俄罗斯最近的人谁可以读取并用他们的手指和辨认颜色，甚至能透过厚实的门和墙看到。
  • One case concerns an eleven-year-old schoolgirl, Vera Petrova, who has normal vision but who can also perceive things with different parts of her skin, and through solid walls. 有一起案件涉及一个11岁的女学生，维拉佩特洛娃，谁拥有正常视力，但谁也能感知的东西和她皮肤的不同部位，并通过坚实的墙壁。

SEE> con·sist·ent , good 好, strong 强大

ODE> Firm and stable in shape; not liquid or fluid. – hard, rock-hard, rigid, firm, solidified, set, frozen, jellied, congealed, concrete.

1716. so·lu·tion 解决办法 ## 4

[sə’luːʃn]n.解决办法；解答；溶液；溶解；设计

  • Modern readers would find such naive solutions totally unacceptable. 现代读者会觉得这种天真的结局完全无法接受。
  • Reading is only a partial solution, for the monotonous rhythm of the wheels clicking on the rails soon lulls you to sleep. 看书只能解决部分问题。车轮点击轨道不久的间歇，你睡觉的单调的节奏。
  • As a shipbuilder, Cockerell was trying to find a solution to the problem of the wave resistance which wastes a good deal of a surface ship’s power and limits its speed. 作为一个船舶技师，科克雷尔正在试图找到一个解决的浪费水面舰艇的力量的一个很好的协议，并限制其速度的兴波阻力的问题。

SEE> solve 解决, means 手段, prob·lem 问题

ODE> A means of solving a problem or dealing with a difficult situation. – answer, result, resolution, way out, panacea.

1717. solve 解决 ## 3

[sɑːlv]v.解决；解答

  • In this way, he was able to solve the mystery. 就这样，他才能够解开这个谜。
  • This would solve the problem of ventilation, for if a train entered this tunnel, it would draw in fresh air behind it. 这样就解决了通风问题，因为如果有列火车开进这条隧道，它会在它背后新鲜空气借鉴。
  • Perhaps it will solve my problem, but I just haven’t had time to read it! 也许这将解决我的问题，但我还没有来得及看呢！

SEE> re·solve 决心, prob·lem 问题, so·lu·tion 解决办法

ODE> Find an answer to, explanation for, or means of effectively dealing with (a problem or mystery) – find an answer to, find the answer to, find a solution to, find the solution to, answer, resolve, work out, puzzle out, fathom, find the key to, decipher, decode, break, clear up, interpret, translate, straighten out, get to the bottom of, make head or tail of, unravel, disentangle, untangle, unfold, piece together, explain, expound, elucidate.

1718. some 一些 ## 115

[səm]adj.一些；若干adv.大约；非常pron.一些(人、物)

  • Give me some glasses please, Jane. 给我一些眼镜请，简。
  • There are some magazines on the television. 有在电视上一些杂志。
  • There are some newspapers on the table. 有上表中的一些报纸。

SEE> man·y 许多, few 少数, those 那些

ODE> An unspecified amount or number of. – some, a piece of, a part of, a bit of.

1719. some·how 不知何故 ## 3

[’sʌmhaʊ]adv.以某种方式；不知怎么地

  • As no pumas had been reported missing from any zoo in the country, this one must have been in the possession of a private collector and somehow managed to escape. 由于没有美洲狮被报道曾从全国动物园失踪，这一次一定是属于一位私人收藏家的，不知怎么设法逃出来了。
  • Even he still lives under the illusion that country life is somehow superior to town life. 即使他也仍存有幻觉，好像乡村生活是某种比城市生活优越。
  • When lights fuse, furniture gets rickety, pipes get clogged, or vacuum cleaners fail to operate, some women assume that their husbands will somehow put things right. 当电灯保险丝烧断，家具榫头松动，管道堵塞，吸尘器不动时，有些妻子认为丈夫总会设法修好的。

SEE> in·deed 确实, un·for·tu·nate·ly 不幸的是, sure·ly 一定

ODE> In some way; by some means. – by some means, by any means, by any means whatsoever, in some way, one way or another, in one way or another, no matter how, somehow or other, by fair means or foul, by hook or by crook, come what may, come hell or high water.

1720. some·one 有人 ## 16

[’sʌmwʌn]pron.某人；有人

  • someone called. 有人叫。
  • A few hours earlier, someone had told the police that thieves would try to steal the diamonds. 几个小时前，有人曾告诉警方，盗贼会去抢钻石。
  • Suddenly someone shouted, ’It’s two minutes past twelve! 突然有人喊道：“这是十二时二！

SEE> some·bod·y 某人, else 其他, an·y·one 任何人

ODE> An unknown or unspecified person; some person. – person, individual, human being, somebody, someone.

1721. some·thing 某物 ## 39

[’sʌmθɪŋ]pron.某事物；有价值或重要的人或事物；大致；左右adv.有点；非常

  • Come and have something to drink. 快来喝点东西。
  • I’m sure we’ll win something this week. 我敢肯定，我们将在本周赢得一些东西。
  • Then he said something and I understood it. 接着，他说了些什么，我听懂了。

SEE> an·y·thing 任何东西, thing 事情, re·al·ly 真的

ODE> A thing that is unspecified or unknown. –

1722. some·times 有时 ## 31

[’sʌmtaɪmz]adv.有时；间或

  • It’s always warm in April and May, but it rains sometimes. 它总是温暖的四月和五月，但有时下雨。
  • It’s often cold in November and it rains sometimes. 它通常在寒冷的十一月，而且有时下雨。
  • It snows sometimes. 有时还下雪。

SEE> of·ten 经常, oc·ca·sion·al·ly 偶尔, fre·quent·ly 经常

ODE> Occasionally, rather than all of the time. – occasionally, from time to time, now and again, now and then, every now and again, every now and then, every so often, once in a while, every once in a while, on occasion, on occasions, on the odd occasion, at times, off and on, at intervals, periodically, sporadically, spasmodically, erratically, irregularly, intermittently, by fits and starts, in fits and starts, fitfully, discontinuously, piecemeal.

1723. some·what 有些 ## 2

[’sʌmwʌt]adv.稍微；有些；多少；几分pron.某物；一些

  • But in an old man who has known human joys and sorrows, and has achieved whatever work it was in him to do, the fear of death is somewhat abject and ignoble. 但是，在一个老人谁知道人的悲欢离合，并都经历过了，自己做的，死亡的恐惧是有些可怜且可耻。
  • At the same time our sympathy for Galileo’s opponents has grown somewhat. 与此同时，我们对伽利略的反对派的同情也有所增加。

SEE> sim·i·lar·ly 同样, al·be·it , though 虽然

ODE> To a moderate extent or by a moderate amount; rather. – a little, a bit, a little bit, to a limited degree, to a limited extent, to a certain degree, to some extent, to some degree, to a point, up to a point, in some measure, rather, quite, within limits.

1724. some·where 某处 ## 5

[’sʌmwer]adv.在某处；到某种程度；大约n.某处

  • He hitchhiked to Dover and, towards evening, went into a boat to find somewhere to sleep. 他搭便车到了多佛，天快黑时钻进了一条船，想找个地方睡觉。
  • Buried somewhere in deep grass there is a rusting lawn mower which I have promised to repair one day. 在深草埋某处有我曾答应某日要修理一个生锈的割草机。
  • I decided that I must have taken a wrong turning somewhere. 我决定，我一定是拐错了弯的地方。

SEE> else 其他, an·y·where 任何地方, no·where 无处

ODE> In or to some place. –

1725. son 儿子 ## 3

[sʌn]n.儿子；孩子（长者对后辈的称呼）

  • Following in his father’s footsteps many years later, Sir Malcolm’s son, Donald, also set up a world record. 在很多年后，他的父亲的脚步，马尔科姆爵士的儿子唐纳德，还设立了一个世界纪录。
  • Eric had been the eldest son of the family, very much older than his two brothers. 埃里克是家中的长子，比他的两个弟弟大很多。
  • my son’, or ’ho! 我的儿子“或”嗬！

SEE> fa·ther 父亲, broth·er 哥哥, grand·son 孙子

ODE> A boy or man in relation to either or both of his parents. – male child, boy, son and heir.

1726. song 歌曲 ## 3

[sɔːŋ]n.歌曲；歌唱；(鸟等)鸣声

  • In return for this, the beggar stood on his head and sang songs. 作为回报，那乞丐站在他的头上还唱着歌。
  • After a wonderful meal, they told stories and sang songs by the campfire. 美餐之后，他们讲起了故事，篝火，唱起了歌。
  • We were very much surprised when the snake charmer suddenly began to play jazz and modern pop songs. 当耍蛇人突然又吹奏起爵士乐和现代流行乐曲，我们感到非常惊奇。

SEE> al·bum , lyrics , tune 曲调

ODE> A short poem or other set of words set to music or meant to be sung. – air, strain, ditty, melody, tune, popular song, pop song, number, track.

1727. soon 不久 ## 61

[suːn]adv.不久；很快；早；快

  • ’I’ll write a letter soon. “我很快会写信的。
  • He says he’ll write a letter soon. 他说他很快会写信的。
  • He will soon visit Darwin. 他不久还将到达达尔文。

SEE> e·ven·tu·al·ly 终于, fi·nal·ly 终于, quick·ly 很快

ODE> In or after a short time. – in a short time, shortly, presently, in the near future, before long, in a little while, in a minute, in a moment, in an instant, in a twinkling, in the twinkling of an eye, before you know it, any minute, any minute now, any day, any day now, any time, any time now, by and by.

1728. sor·ry 抱歉 ## 15

[’sɑːri]adj.对不起的；抱歉的；难过的；遗憾的int.对不起

  • Sorry sir. 对不起，先生。
  • ‘I am sorry,’ he said. “很抱歉，”他说。
  • I’m sorry. 对不起。

SEE> a·shamed 羞愧, ob·vi·ous·ly 显然, embarrassed 尴尬

ODE> Feeling sad or distressed through sympathy with someone else’s misfortune. – sad, unhappy, sorrowful, distressed, upset, depressed, downcast, miserable, downhearted, disheartened, dejected, down, despondent, despairing, disconsolate, broken-hearted, heartbroken, inconsolable, grief-stricken.

1729. sort 种类 ## 18

[sɔːrt]n.种类；某一种人v.整理；分类；处理；安排妥当

  • This is the sort of thing that Jeremy loves. 这是诸如此类的事情正是杰里米喜欢。
  • He should have known that the police would never allow this sort of thing. 他应该知道，警察绝不会允许这样的事情。
  • We sometimes imagine a desert island to be a sort of paradise where the sun always shines. 我们有时想象荒岛是一个乐园，那里终日阳光普照。

SEE> kind 种类, some·thing 某物, in·deed 确实

ODE> A category of things or people with a common feature; a type. – type, kind, variety, class, category, classification, style.

1730. sound 声音 ## 14

[saʊnd]n.声音；嘈杂声；音乐风格；曲调；印象；感觉；海峡；鱼鳔；探针v.听起来；感觉起来；发出声音；发音；探测深度；探询adj.有效的；合理的；可靠的；全面的；健康的；完好的；酣睡的；严厉的adv.酣畅地

  • Though the sound could be heard clearly, it took me a long time to react. 虽然声音清晰可闻，我花了很长的时间作出反应。
  • Suddenly, there was a slight trembling sound from below, and the captain went down to see what had happened. 突然，从下面传来一声微颤音，船长下楼看看发生了什么事。
  • In this part of the cave, they could hear an insistent booming sound which they found was caused by a small waterspout shooting down into a pool from the roof of the cave. 在洞穴的这一部分，他们可以听见一种连续不断的轰鸣声，他们发现这是由一个小的水龙卷从洞顶击落成池造成的。

SEE> in·deed 确实, ac·tu·al·ly 其实, well 好

ODE> Vibrations that travel through the air or another medium and can be heard when they reach a person’s or animal’s ear. – noise, note, din, racket, row, bang, report, hubbub, resonance, reverberation.

1731. source 来源 ## 12

[sɔːrs]n.来源；发源地；原始资料v.从…获得

  • He has pointed out that the tree is a useful source of income, as tourists have been coming from all parts of the country to see it. 他指出，这棵树是收入的有效来源，游客已经从全国各地来看望它。
  • Mum or dad, of course, provide a regular supply of pocket money, but uncles and aunts are always a source of extra income. 爸爸妈妈，当然，提供的零花钱正常供应，但叔叔和婶婶总是额外收入来源。
  • What does the writer describe as an ‘amusing old-fashioned source of noise’? 什么是作家描述为“噪声有趣的老式源”？

SEE> in·stance 例子, how·ev·er 然而, fur·ther·more

ODE> A place, person, or thing from which something originates or can be obtained. – origin, place of origin.

1732. south 南方 ## 3

[saʊθ]n.南；南方adj.南方的adv.在南方；向南方；自南方

  • After I had left a small village in the south of France, I drove on to the next town. 我曾在法国南部留下一个小村庄后，我继续驶往下一个城镇。
  • When reports came into London Zoo that a wild puma had been spotted forty-five miles south of London, they were not taken seriously. 当报告来到伦敦动物园，一只野生的美洲狮已经发现伦敦的45英里南部，他们并没有受到重视。
  • One authority on spiders made a census of the spiders in a grass field in the south of England, and he estimated that there were more than 2,250,000 in one acre; that is something like 6,000,000 spiders of different kinds on a football pitch. 研究蜘蛛的权威提出在英国南部一块草坪上的蜘蛛作了一次调查，他估计，目前每英亩均超过2,250,000;这就是说，在一个足球场上不同种类6,000,000蜘蛛。

SEE> north 北, south·ern 南部的, east 东

ODE> The direction towards the point of the horizon 90° clockwise from east, or the point on the horizon itself. – southern, southerly, southwardly, meridional, Antarctic, polar.

1733. space 空间 ## 13

[speɪs]n.空间；处所；太空；空地；空闲；空格；间隙v.留间隔；分隔；走神；忘记

  • At the moment, they cover every inch of floor space and I actually have to walk on them to get in or out of the room. 目前，它们覆盖的地面每一寸空间，我实际上是踩着这些书进出房间的获得。
  • What is the special importance of a telescope in space? 什么是太空望远镜的特殊重要性？
  • The Hubble telescope was launched into space by NASA on April 20, 1990 at a cost of over a billion dollars. 哈勃望远镜于超过十亿美元的价格于1990年4月20日发射升空的美国宇航局。

SEE> launch 发射, earth 地球, ad·di·tion 加

ODE> A continuous area or expanse which is free, available, or unoccupied. – room, expanse, extent, capacity, area, volume, spaciousness, scope, latitude, expansion, margin, leeway, play, clearance.

1734. spare 备用的 ## 5

[sper]adj.备用的；多余的；闲置的v.抽出；饶恕；赦免；节约n.备用品；剩余

  • Up to now, Mr.Scott has sent a great many requests for spare parts and other urgent messages from one garage to the other. 截至目前，Mr.Scott已派出备件的信件和其他紧急了大量索取从一个汽车到另一个。
  • In his twenties Frank used to make spare parts for aeroplanes. 在他二十多岁的弗兰克曾生产飞机零配件。
  • You can sit here in your spare time and read the carpet!’ 你可以坐在这儿你的业余时间读地毯！”

SEE> in·stead 代替, be·sides , like·wise

ODE> Additional to what is required for ordinary use. – extra, supplementary, additional, second, another, alternative, emergency, reserve, backup, relief, fallback, substitute, fresh, auxiliary, ancillary.

1735. speak 讲 ## 22

[spiːk]v.讲；说话；演说；发言

  • She can’t speak to you now!’ 她不能给你讲，现在！”
  • He spoke German. 他说德语。
  • ‘I do not speak English.’ ‘我不会说英语。’

SEE> tell 告诉, un·der·stand 懂, lis·ten 听

ODE> Say something in order to convey information or to express a feeling. – talk, say, say anything, say something.

1736. spe·cial 特别 ## 21

[’speʃl]adj.特别的；特殊的；专门的n.特别的东西；特刊；特色菜；特价

  • Why is the new house special? 为什么新房子特别的吗？
  • They will also be building new roads and a special railway line. 他们还将兴建新的公路和一条铁路专用线。
  • What is the special importance of a telescope in space? 什么是太空望远镜的特殊重要性？

ODE> Better, greater, or otherwise different from what is usual. – exceptional, particular, extra special, unusual, marked, singular, uncommon, notable, noteworthy, remarkable, outstanding, unique.

1737. speech 讲话 ## 6

[spiːtʃ]n.演说；演讲；言语；语言能力

  • Recently, one of Jeremy’s closest friends asked him to make a speech at a wedding reception. 最近，杰里米的最亲密的朋友请他在一个婚礼的招待会上发表讲话。
  • He prepared the speech carefully and went to the wedding with Jenny. 他认真准备了讲稿，去与珍妮的婚礼。
  • He had included a large number of funny stories in the speech and, of course, it was a great success. 他收录了大量在讲话中有趣的故事，当然的，这是一个巨大的成功。

SEE> ad·dress 地址, pres·en·ta·tion 介绍, mes·sage 消息

ODE> The expression of or the ability to express thoughts and feelings by articulate sounds. – speaking, talking, verbal communication, verbal expression, articulation.

1738. speed 速度 ## 22

[spiːd]n.速度；迅速v.加速；急行

  • Didn’t you see the speed limit? 难道你没看见限速牌吗？
  • The winning car reached a speed of forty miles an hour – much faster than any of its rivals. 获胜的那辆车达到了每小时四十英里的速度 - 比任何竞争对手的要快得多。
  • It sped downhill at the end of the race and its driver had a lot of trouble trying to stop it. 它下坡加速在比赛结束及其驱动程序有很多试图阻止它的麻烦。

SEE> fast 快速, slow 慢, track 小道

ODE> The rate at which someone or something moves or operates or is able to move or operate. – rate, pace, tempo, momentum.

1739. spell 拼写 ## 2

[spel]v.拼写；拼成；导致；暂时代替n.咒语；魔力；一段时间；一阵发作；轮班

  • How do you spell ‘intelligent’? 你怎么拼写“智能”？
  • We are lucky in that only the lower fields, which make up a very small proportion of our farm, are affected by flooding, but other farms are less favourably sited, and flooding can sometimes spell disaster for their owners. 我们是只有较低的领域，从而弥补了我们农场比例很小幸运，是由洪水的影响，但其他农场地势欠佳，和洪水有时会给农场主带来灾难。

SEE> i·ron·i·cal·ly , un·for·tu·nate·ly 不幸的是, in·deed 确实

ODE> Write or name the letters that form (a word) in correct sequence. – lead to, result in, bring about, bring on, cause, be the cause of.

1740. spend 花费 ## 29

[spend]n.预算；花销v.花费；浪费；度过；用尽（气力等）

  • We’re going to spend three days in the country! 我们将花三天的国家！
  • Where are you going to spend your holidays this year, Gary? 你要去哪里今年度过你的假期，加里？
  • But if we spend all that money we’ll be poor again. 但是，如果我们把所有钱都花光了，我们又很差。

SEE> spend·ing , in·stead 代替, a·lone 单独地

ODE> Give (money) to pay for goods, services, or so as to benefit someone or something. – pay out, lay out, expend, disburse.

1741. spi·der 蜘蛛 ## 14

[’spaɪdər]n.蜘蛛；十字叉；三脚架；长柄平底锅

  • We live in dread not only of unpleasant insects like spiders or wasps, but of quite harmless ones like moths. 我们生活在一个既类令人讨厌的昆虫如蜘蛛，黄蜂恐惧，但并无大害的飞蛾等。
  • Who has not stood in awe at the sight of a spider pouncing on a fly, or a column of ants triumphantly bearing home an enormous dead beetle? 谁没有在看到蜘蛛猛扑过来的敬畏站在一只苍蝇，蚂蚁的列轴承扬扬家巨大的死甲虫？
  • How much of each year do spiders spend killing insects? 多少钱，每年做蜘蛛花杀虫？

SEE> mon·key , crea·ture 生物, snake 蛇

ODE> An eight-legged predatory arachnid with an unsegmented body consisting of a fused head and thorax and a rounded abdomen. Spiders have fangs which inject poison into their prey, and most kinds spin webs in which to capture insects. –

1742. spir·it·u·al 精神 ## 2

[’spɪrɪtʃuəl]adj.精神的；心灵的；与上帝有关的n.(尤指美国南部黑人的)圣歌

  • In the light of this statement, teachers live by selling knowledge, philosophers by selling wisdom and priests by selling spiritual comfort. 根据这种说法的光，教师靠靠卖精神安慰卖知识，哲学家靠卖智慧和教士。
  • So much is certain: that we would have doctors and preachers, lawyers and defendants, marriages and births – but our spiritual outlook would be different. 所以是可以肯定的：虽然我们还会有医生和牧师，律师和被告，婚姻和生育 - 但我们的精神面貌将是不同的。

SEE> re·li·gious 宗教, faith 信仰, in·spi·ra·tion

ODE> Relating to or affecting the human spirit or soul as opposed to material or physical things. – non-material, inner, psychic, psychical, psychological.

1743. spite 尽管 ## 6

[spaɪt]n.恶意；怨恨v.刁难；惹怒；冒犯

  • In spite of this, she often appears on the stage as a young girl. 尽管如此，她经常出现在舞台上作为一个年轻的女孩。
  • In spite of this, many people are confident that ‘The Revealer’ may reveal something of value fairly soon. 尽管如此，很多人仍然相信“探宝器”很快就会探出值钱的东西。
  • In spite of all that has been said, the tourists have been picking leaves and cutting their names on the tree-trunk. 尽管所有的已经说了，但游客们还是照常摘树叶和切割的树干他们的名字。

SEE> de·spite 尽管, nev·er·the·less 然而, not·with·stand·ing

ODE> A desire to hurt, annoy, or offend someone. – malice, maliciousness, ill will, ill feeling, spitefulness, bitterness, animosity, hostility, antagonism, enmity, resentment, resentfulness, rancour, malevolence, venom, spleen, gall, malignance, malignity, evil intentions, envy, hate, hatred, vengeance, vengefulness, vindictiveness.

1744. spoil 弄糟 ## 2

[spɔɪl]v.宠坏；溺爱；破坏；腐坏；使索然无味n.战利品；奖品

  • Postcards always spoil my holidays. 明信片总是破坏我的假日。
  • What particular anxiety spoils the country dweller’s visit to the theatre? 什么特别的焦虑败坏了农村居民的剧院访问？

SEE> un·doubt·ed·ly , sure·ly 一定, ru·in 废墟

ODE> Diminish or destroy the value or quality of. – mar, damage, impair, blemish, disfigure, blight, flaw, deface, scar, injure, harm.

1745. sport 运动 ## 12

[spɔːrt]n.运动；体育vi.嬉戏；炫耀；戏弄adj.运动的；户外穿戴的

  • Why is fishing the writer’s favourite sport? 为什么钓鱼笔者最喜欢的运动？
  • Fishing is my favourite sport. 钓鱼是我最喜欢的运动。
  • Though he was technically a prizefighter, Mendoza did much to change crude prizefighting into a sport, for he brought science to the game. 虽然他是个职业拳击手，门多萨做了很多改变粗野的拳击变成一种体育运动方面，他作出了重大的比赛。

SEE> sports , com·pete 竞争, well 好

ODE> An activity involving physical exertion and skill in which an individual or team competes against another or others for entertainment. – (competitive) game(s), physical recreation, physical activity, physical exercise.

1746. spot 斑点 ## 8

[spɑːt]n.地点；场所；职位；污点；斑点；少量；聚光灯；插播节目adj.现场的；现货的；插播的v.（使）产生污渍；玷污；认出；用灯光照射

  • It is a famous beauty spot. 这是一个著名的风景胜地。
  • Meanwhile, two other actors, Rockwall Slinger and Merlin Greeves, had carried two large food baskets to a shady spot under some trees. 与此同时，另外两位演员，罗克沃尔。斯林格和默林。格里夫斯，已经树下两个大食品篮子荫凉的地方。
  • Four days after setting out, while the Titanic was sailing across the icy waters of the North Atlantic, a huge iceberg was suddenly spotted by a lookout. 列明，而泰坦尼克号在北大西洋冰冷的海域航行四天后，一个巨大的冰山突然，了望员发现。

SEE> place 地方, an·oth·er 另一个, one 一

ODE> A small round or roundish mark, differing in colour or texture from the surface around it. – mark, patch, pop, dot, speck, speckle, fleck, smudge, smear, stain, blotch, blot, splash, daub.

1747. spray 喷雾 ## 2

[spreɪ]v.喷雾；喷射；扫射n.喷雾；喷雾器；水沫

  • The seed was sprayed over the ground in huge quantities by aeroplanes. 种子是由飞机撒在地面巨大的数量。
  • But even the mosquito has been subdued by attention to drainage and by chemical sprays. 然而即使蚊子，已经被注意排水和化学喷雾制服。

SEE> paint 涂料, mist , brush 刷子

ODE> Liquid that is blown or driven through the air in the form of tiny drops. – shower, sprinkling, sprinkle, spritz, jet, mist, drizzle, droplets.

1748. spread 传播 ## 6

[spred]v.传播；展开；散布；铺开；伸展；涂撒n.范围；传播；差额；幅度；盛宴

  • What factor helped to spread the disease of myxomatosis? 什么因素帮助传播粘液瘤的病？
  • It effectively spread the disease all over the continent and drastically reduced the rabbit population. 它有效地传播本病遍布大陆，大大降低了兔子的人口。
  • It spread through France, where wild rabbits are not generally regarded as a pest but as a sport and a useful food supply, and it spread to Britain where wild rabbits are regarded as a pest but where domesticated rabbits, equally susceptible to the disease, are the basis of a profitable fur industry. 它蔓延至法国，在那里的野生兔子一般不被当作有害动物，而作为体育和有用的食物来源，并蔓延到英国，野兔被当作有害的，但在那里驯化的野兔，同样易患本病，是赚钱的毛皮工业的基础。

SEE> a·cross 横过, through·out 始终, rap·id·ly 迅速地

ODE> Open out (something) so as to extend its surface area, width, or length. – lay out, open out, unfurl, unroll, roll out, shake out.

1749. spring 春天 ## 10

[sprɪŋ]n.春天；春季；弹簧；弹力；跳；泉水；源头v.跳；弹；快速站起；突然提出；触发捕捉器；(使)裂开；爆炸；释放；涌出；生长；出现；耸立；(风)开始吹

  • What’s the weather like in spring? 怎么样在春天的天气如何？
  • I like spring and summer. 我喜欢春天和夏天。
  • ‘Paris in the Spring’. “巴黎春天”。

SEE> sum·mer 夏天, be·gin·ning 开始, fall 下落

ODE> Move or jump suddenly or rapidly upwards or forwards. – leap, jump, bound, vault, hop.

1750. square 广场 ## 4

[skwer]n.正方形；广场；街区；平方；直角尺；古板的人adj.正方形的；规矩的；结实的；公正的；断然的v.一致；结清；收买；使 … 成方形；使成平方；调整adv.成直角；直接的；正方形地

  • Trafalgar Square, please. 特拉法加广场，请。
  • As we had had a long walk through one of the markets of old Delhi, we stopped at a square to have a rest. 正如我们所穿过旧德里的市场之一的长走，我们停在一个广场上休息。
  • After a time, we noticed a snake charmer with two large baskets at the other side of the square, so we went to have a look at him. 过了一段时间，我们注意到在广场的另一侧两个大筐的耍蛇人，所以我们去看看他。

SEE> down·town , ad·ja·cent , ar·e·a 区域

ODE> A plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles. – mortar board, academic cap.

1751. staff 职员 ## 4

[stæf]n.员工；全体人员；全体职员；拐杖；杆；棒；五线谱vt.配备员工

  • He and his staff began throwing furniture out of the window. 他和他的工作人员开始投掷家具窗外。
  • Though my aunt pursued what was, in those days, an enlightened policy, in that she never allowed her domestic staff to work more than eight hours a day, she was extremely difficult to please. 姑妈追求的是什么，在那些日子里，开明的政策，她从来不让佣人的工作人员每天工作超过八小时，她是极难讨好。
  • During that time she so gained my aunt’s confidence, that she was put in charge of the domestic staff. 在此期间，她赢得了姑母的赏识，甚至当上了大管家的。

SEE> per·son·nel , ad·di·tion 加, work·ing 工作

ODE> All the people employed by a particular organization. – employees, workers, workforce, personnel, hands, hired hands, labourers, human resources, manpower, labour.

1752. stage 舞台 ## 10

[steɪdʒ]n.舞台；戏剧；阶段；步骤；行程v.上演；举行；组织；筹划；使出现

  • In spite of this, she often appears on the stage as a young girl. 尽管如此，她经常出现在舞台上作为一个年轻的女孩。
  • In the last act, a gaoler would always come on to the stage with a letter which he would hand to the prisoner. 在最后一幕中，一个看守总是要带着一封信，他会交给犯人的阶段。
  • With this, he hurried off the stage. 有了这个，他匆匆离开了舞台。

SEE> next 下一个, first 第一, same 相同

ODE> A point, period, or step in a process or development. – phase, period, juncture, step, point, time, moment, instant, division, level.

1753. stair 楼梯 ## 3

[ster]n.楼梯

  • A short while ago, my sister helped me to carry one of my old bookcases up the stairs. 前一阵子，我妹妹帮我把我的旧书橱上楼之一。
  • What did the man expect to find under the stairs? 什么男人想到的楼梯下找到？
  • Not wanting to frighten the poor man, Mrs. Richards quickly hid in the small storeroom under the stairs. 不想吓唬这个可怜人，理查兹夫人便赶紧躲到了楼梯下的小储藏室里。

ODE> A set of steps leading from one floor of a building to another, typically inside the building. – stair, tread, tread board.

1754. stamp 邮票 ## 2

[stæmp]n.邮票；图章；印；跺脚v.跺脚；盖章

  • She stamped out the letters ‘SOS’ in the snow. 她在雪地上踩出了字母“SOS”。
  • Whatever it consists of, stamps, records, first editions of books, china, glass, antique furniture, pictures, model cars, stuffed birds, toy animals, there is always something to do in connection with it, from finding the right place for the latest addition, to verifying facts in reference books. 无论它的组成邮票，唱片，书籍，瓷器，玻璃，古董家具，绘画，模型汽车，鸟类标本，玩具动物初版，总有一些东西与它连接的事，找到可以在正确的地方最新加入，以核对参考书中的事实。

SEE> sig·na·ture 签名, like·wise , in·stance 例子

ODE> Bring down (one’s foot) heavily on the ground or on something on the ground. – trample, step, tread, tramp.

1755. stand 站立 ## 27

[stænd]v.站立；忍受；位于；停滞n.站立；货摊；停顿；看台

  • We are standing on the left. 我们站在左边。
  • Try and stand up. 试着站起来。
  • Can you stand up? 你能站起来吗？

SEE> should 应该, a·lone 单独地, put 放

ODE> Have or maintain an upright position, supported by one’s feet. – be on one’s feet, be upright, be erect, be vertical.

1756. stand·ard 标准 ## 7

[’stændərd]n.标准；规格；水准；军旗adj.标准的；普通的；规范的；权威的

  • Even by modern standards, the 46,000 ton Titanic was a colossal ship. 即使按照现代的标准，46000吨的泰坦尼克号是一艘巨轮。
  • Insuring public or private property is a standard practice in most countries in the world. 承办公共或私人财产是大多数国家在世界上的标准做法。
  • Not only was the meal well below the usual standard, but Bessie seemed unable to walk steadily. 不仅是饭菜远不如平时的标准，而且贝西走起路来似乎东倒西歪。

SEE> ex·am·ple 例子, in·stance 例子, same 相同

ODE> A level of quality or attainment. – quality, level, grade, degree, worth, calibre, merit, excellence.

1757. star 星 ## 10

[stɑːr]n.星；明星v.以星状物装饰；变成演员

  • Of course, the Hubble is above the earth’s atmosphere, so it will soon be sending us the clearest pictures of the stars and distant galaxies that we have ever seen. 当然，哈勃位于地球的大气层之外，因此，它很快就会给我们发送的行星和远距离星系的最清晰的照片，我们已经见过。
  • Whether a planet can support life depends on the size and brightness of its star, that is its ‘sun’. 一颗行星是否能够维持生命取决于它的恒星的大小和亮度，也就是它的“太阳”。
  • Imagine a star up to twenty times larger, brighter and hotter than our own sun. 想象一下，一颗恒星较大的二十倍，更亮，更热比我们自己的太阳。

SEE> once 一次, a·long·side 在旁边, vet·er·an

ODE> A fixed luminous point in the night sky which is a large, remote incandescent body like the sun. – celestial body, heavenly body, sun.

1758. stare 盯着看 ## 3

[ster]v.盯着看；凝视n.凝视

  • The noble stared at the blank sheet of paper for a few seconds. 在纸几秒钟的白纸贵族盯着。
  • If you are lucky enough to get a sleeper, you spend half the night staring at the small blue light in the ceiling, or fumbling to find your ticket for inspection. 如果你幸运地得到一个卧铺，你花一半的晚上在天花板上蓝色的小光盯着，或摸索着找到自己的检查车票。
  • We enjoy staring at them, entranced as they go about their business, unaware (we hope) of our presence. 我们喜欢盯着他们，迷住了，因为他们去他们的生意，不知道（但愿如此）我们的存在。

SEE> gaze , si·lent·ly , cu·ri·ous·ly 好奇地

ODE> Look fixedly or vacantly at someone or something with one’s eyes wide open. – gaze, gape, goggle, gawk, glare, ogle, leer, peer, look fixedly, look vacantly.

1759. start 开始 ## 21

[stɑːrt]v.开始；出发；震惊n.开始；震动；领先优势；起推动作用的外力

  • He started to complain about this wicked world but was interrupted by a knock at the door. 他开始抱怨世道不好，但却被敲门声打断了。
  • In the struggle, the strap broke and, with the bag in their possession, both men started running through the trees. 在斗争中，带子断了，在他们身上的袋子，两人开始跑进了树林。
  • They were also quite sure that a cigarette end did not start the fire. 他们还相当肯定，一个烟头没有启动火。

SEE> be·gin 开始, be·gin·ning 开始, next 下一个

ODE> Begin or be reckoned from a particular point in time or space; come into being. – begin, get under way, go ahead, get going.

1760. state 状态 ## 12

[steɪt]n.情形；状态；国家；州；政府adj.国家的；州的；国事礼仪的v.陈述；声明；说明；规定

  • The busmen have stated that the strike will continue until general agreement is reached about pay and working conditions. 司机们声称罢工将持续到就工资和工作条件达成全面协议。
  • He looked pale and his clothes were in a frightful state. 他面色苍白，衣服也搞得不成样子。
  • When he died at the age of eighty, the Florentines gave him a state funeral and had a picture painted which was dedicated to the memory of ‘the most valiant soldier and most notable leader, Signor Giovanni Haukodue’. 当他80岁那年死去时，佛罗伦萨人为他举行了国葬，并曾画了一幅画这是献给“最英勇的战士，最显着的领先地位，贝卢斯科尼乔瓦尼Haukodue”的记忆。

SEE> fed·er·al 联邦, gov·ern·ment 政府, pub·lic 公众

ODE> The particular condition that someone or something is in at a specific time. – condition, shape, situation, circumstances, state of affairs, position.

1761. state·ment 声明 ## 2

[’steɪtmənt]n.陈述；声明；【计】语句

  • In the light of this statement, teachers live by selling knowledge, philosophers by selling wisdom and priests by selling spiritual comfort. 根据这种说法的光，教师靠靠卖精神安慰卖知识，哲学家靠卖智慧和教士。
  • Another patient might equally well complain that her neighbours were combining to slander her and persecute her, and yet one might be cautious about believing this statement. 另有一位病人可能同样有理由抱怨说，她的邻居们正在联合起来对她的诽谤和迫害她，不过，人们不会轻信这种说法。

SEE> say·ing , an·nounce·ment , stressed 强调

ODE> A definite or clear expression of something in speech or writing. – declaration, expression of facts, expression of views, affirmation, assertion, announcement, utterance, communication.

1762. sta·tion 车站 ## 36

[’steɪʃn]n.站；火车站；电视台；社会地位；牧羊场；驻地；岗位v.驻扎；安置

  • There’s a bar next door to the station. 有一个酒吧隔壁的站。
  • We had better go back to the station now, Ken. 我们最好现在回到车站，肯。
  • After the train had left the station, the lady opened her handbag and took out her powder compact. 火车开出车站后，那位妇女打开了手提包，拿出了粉盒。

SEE> ra·di·o 无线电, train 火车, near·by 附近

ODE> A place on a railway line where trains regularly stop so that passengers can get on or off. – stopping place, stop, halt, station stop, stage.

1763. stat·ue 雕像 ## 9

[’stætʃuː]n.雕像；塑像

  • Where was the Statue of Liberty made? 凡在自由女神像做？
  • One of the most famous monuments in the world, the Statue of Liberty, was presented to the United States of America in the nineteenth century by the people of France. 一个是世界上最有名的古迹，自由女神像，是由法国人民赠送给美国的美国在十九世纪。
  • The great statue, which was designed by the sculptor Auguste Bartholdi, took ten years to complete. 伟大的雕像，这是由雕塑家奥古斯特·巴托尔迪设计，花了10年时间。

SEE> mon·u·ment , sculp·ture , be·side 在旁边

ODE> A carved or cast figure of a person or animal, especially one that is life-size or larger. – sculpture, figure, effigy, statuette, figurine, idol.

1764. stay 停留 ## 38

[steɪ]v.停留；逗留；保持n.停留；逗留

  • Mrs. Sawyer stays at home every day. 索耶夫人每天呆在家里。
  • Mrs. Sawyer usually stays at home in the morning, but this morning, she is going to the shops. 索耶夫人通常是呆在家里的早晨，但今天上午，她正去商店买东西。
  • He has a bad cold, Mr. Williams, so he must stay in bed for a week. 他得了重感冒，威廉斯先生，因此他必须卧床一周。

SEE> leave 离开, keep 保持, go 去

ODE> Remain in the same place. – remain, remain behind, stay behind, stay put.

1765. stead·i·ly 稳步地 ## 2

[’stedəlɪ]adv.稳定地；稳固地；逐步地

  • They will hardly know which facts to select from the great mass of evidence that steadily accumulates. 他们几乎不知道对于逐渐积累起来的庞大选取哪些。
  • Not only was the meal well below the usual standard, but Bessie seemed unable to walk steadily. 不仅是饭菜远不如平时的标准，而且贝西走起路来似乎东倒西歪。

SEE> rap·id·ly 迅速地, slow·ly 慢慢地, grad·u·al·ly 逐渐地

ODE> In a regular and even manner. –

1766. steal 偷 ## 9

[stiːl]v.偷；窃取n.偷窃；便宜货；(欺诈的)政治交易

  • A few hours earlier, someone had told the police that thieves would try to steal the diamonds. 几个小时前，有人曾告诉警方，盗贼会去抢钻石。
  • Had the writer’s money been stolen? 有作家的钱被偷了？
  • The temptation to steal is greater than ever before – especially in large shops. 偷窃的诱惑力比以往任何时候都更强烈 - 特别在大的商店。

SEE> grab 抓住, an·y·way 无论如何, pre·sum·a·bly 想必

ODE> Take (another person’s property) without permission or legal right and without intending to return it. – theft, thieving, thievery, robbery, larceny, burglary, shoplifting, pilfering, pilferage, looting, appropriation, misappropriation.

1767. steam 蒸汽 ## 2

[stiːm]n.蒸汽；水汽；蒸汽动力；轮船v.蒸；冒热气；行驶；发怒

  • The most wonderful piece of machinery on show was Nasmyth’s steam hammer. 其中最奇妙的上是内史密斯的蒸汽锤。
  • Though in those days, travelling was not as easy as it is today, steam boats carried thousands of visitors across the Channel from Europe. 尽管在当时旅行今天并不容易，因为它是汽船从欧洲携带成千上万的游客横渡英吉利海峡。

SEE> die·sel , pump , en·gine 发动机

ODE> The vapour into which water is converted when heated, forming a white mist of minute water droplets in the air. – water vapour, condensation, mist, haze, fog, exhalation, moisture, dampness.

1768. steep 陡峭的 ## 4

[stiːp]adj.险峻的；陡峭的；急剧的、大起大落的v.浸泡，浸透，湿透；沉浸，笼罩

  • After entering the narrow gap on the plateau, they climbed down the steep sides of the cave until they came to a narrow corridor. 进入高原上的窄缝进去，他们爬下陡峭的洞穴，直到他们来到一条狭窄的走廊。
  • The path led to a tiny village perched on the steep sides of a mountain. 导致一个小村庄栖息在山的陡峭的路径。
  • The slope averages about 1 in 30, but contains steep, probably vertical, cliffs, and gentle sediment-covered terraces, and near its lower reaches there is a long tailing-off which is almost certainly the result of material transported out to deep water after being eroded from the continental masses. 大约在30 1坡度平均，但其中包括陡峭的，乃至垂直的峭壁，温柔沉积物覆盖的露台，并接近其下游还有很长的拖尾过这几乎肯定是材料后运出深水结果从大陆块体被侵蚀。

SEE> climb 爬, slope 斜坡, drop 掉落

ODE> (of a slope, flight of stairs, or angle) rising or falling sharply; almost perpendicular. – precipitous, sheer, abrupt, sharp, perpendicular, vertical, bluff, vertiginous, dizzy.

1769. steer 驾驶 ## 3

[stɪr]v.操纵；驾驶；掌舵；引导

  • As the man tried to swing the speedboat round, the steering wheel came away in his hands. 由于该男子试图使快艇轮，方向盘在手里离开时。
  • The Cutty Sark rolled from side to side and it became impossible to steer her. 卡蒂萨克从一边到另一边卷起并成为无法驾驭她。
  • It has been found that certain bats emit squeaks and by receiving the echoes, they can locate and steer clear of obstacles – or locate flying insects on which they feed. 人们已经发现，某些蝙蝠发出尖叫声并靠接受回响来锁定和避免障碍物 - 或者找到它们赖以飞虫。

SEE> turn 转动, push 推, like·wise

ODE> Guide or control the movement of (a vehicle, vessel, or aircraft), for example by turning a wheel or operating a rudder. – guide, direct, manoeuvre.

1770. step 脚步 ## 6

[step]n.步骤；台阶；舞步；步伐v.踏；以步测量

  • When the bull got close to him, he clumsily stepped aside to let it pass. 当公牛逼近他时，他笨拙地向一旁让了过去。
  • The article began: ‘Hundreds of steps lead to the high wall which surrounds the president’s palace.’ 文章的开头是：“几百级台阶通向环绕总统的高墙。”
  • The editor at once sent the journalist a fax instructing him to find out the exact number of steps and the height of the wall. 立即给那位记者发去传真，要求他的编辑器来找出台阶的确切数字和围墙的高度。

SEE> move 移动, take 拿取, way 方式

ODE> An act or movement of putting one leg in front of the other in walking or running. – pace, footstep, stride.

1771. stick 粘住 ## 6

[stɪk]n.手杖；枝；杆vt.刺入；插于；竖起vi.钉住；坚持，遵守；粘贴；生效，起作用

  • A crowd of people gathered round him and a lady rubbed his arm with soap and butter, but George was firmly stuck. 一大群人围拢过来，一位女士胳膊上抹了肥皂，黄油，但乔治是牢牢卡住。
  • The sad truth is that most of us have been brought up to eat certain foods and we stick to them all our lives. 可悲的事实是，我们大多数人已经长大吃某些食物，我们坚持给他们所有我们的生活。
  • The sorry-looking, blackened figure that emerged, admitted at once that he had tried to break into the shop during the night but had got stuck in the chimney. 惋惜的前瞻性，熏黑的数字一出来，一旦他曾试图在夜间闯入店铺，但已经陷入了烟囱录取。

SEE> in·stead 代替, hand 手, stuck

ODE> A thin piece of wood that has fallen or been cut off a tree. – piece of wood, twig, small branch.

1772. stick·y 黏的 ## 5

[’stɪki]adj.粘的；闷热的；困难的；令人不满意的

  • In a short time I was busy mixing butter and flour and my hands were soon covered with sticky pastry. 在很短的时间，我就忙着调拌黄油和面粉，我的手很快就沾满面粉。
  • I picked up the receiver between two sticky fingers and was dismayed when I recognized the voice of Helen Bates. 我用两个沾满面糊的手指拿起听筒，当我听出是海伦·贝茨的声音感到沮丧。
  • I bound the base of the tree with sticky tape, making it impossible for the ants to reach the aphids. 我绑定的树的根部用胶带，使它不可能为蚂蚁接近蚜虫。

SEE> stuck , prob·lem·at·ic , slip·per·y

ODE> Tending or designed to stick to things on contact. – adhesive, adherent, gummed.

1773. still 仍然 ## 60

[stɪl]adj.静止的；不动的；静寂的adv.更；仍然；静止地v.使…平静下来n.蒸馏器；寂静；定格照

  • No, they’re still working on it. 没有，他们还在修呢。
  • He’s still here. 他还在这里。
  • But George’s parrot, Henry, was still there. 但乔治的鹦鹉亨利仍在那里。

SEE> now 现在, though 虽然, but 但是

ODE> Not moving or making a sound. – motionless, unmoving, without moving, without moving a muscle, stock-still, immobile, like a statue, as if turned to stone, as if rooted to the spot, unstirring, stationary.

1774. sting 蜇 ## 2

[stɪŋ]vt.刺痛；使苦恼；欺诈vi.叮；刺痛n.刺；刺痛；讽刺

  • They sting or bite without provocation; they fly uninvited into our rooms on summer nights, or beat against our lighted windows. 他们又叮又咬不挑衅;它们未经邀请便飞到我们的房间在夏天夜晚，或者对着露出亮光的窗户。
  • No matter how much we like honey, or how much we have read about the uncanny sense of direction which bees possess, we have a horror of being stung. 无论多少，我们似蜜，或有多少我们如何阅读方向的不可思议感，这蜜蜂具有，我们有害怕被蜂蜇。

ODE> A small sharp-pointed organ at the end of the abdomen of bees, wasps, ants, and scorpions, capable of inflicting a painful or dangerous wound by injecting poison. – prick, wound, injury.

1775. stock 股票 ## 4

[stɑːk]n.存货；储备；树干；股票；股份；家畜；血统；汤汁；声望v.采购；储存；供给；发新芽adj.惯用的；存货的

  • He loved to be told that one of his imaginary products was temporarily out of stock and he would faithfully promise to call again at some future date, but of course he never did. 他爱听售货员说他想像的那种东西暂时脱销，于是他就煞有介事地许诺改天再来打电话，当然，他从来没有。
  • But exactly how does a newcomer to the stock market go about achieving that? 但究竟如何做一个初来乍到股市去实现呢？
  • Well, if you go to five reputable stock brokers and ask them what you should do with your money, you’re likely to get five different answers, – even if you give all the relevant information about your age, family, finances and what you want from your investments. 好吧，如果你去到五个信誉的股票经纪人咨询，询问你应该如何使用你的资金，你可能得到5个不同的答案， - 即使你提供了有关于你的年龄，家庭，财源和什么相关信息你想从投资。

SEE> mar·ket 市场, ex·change 交换, share 分享

ODE> The goods or merchandise kept on the premises of a shop or warehouse and available for sale or distribution. – merchandise, goods, wares, articles for sale, items for sale, commodities.

1776. stone 石头 ## 9

[stoʊn]n.【U】石料n.【C】石头；宝石；(水果的)硬核n.英石(重量单位；合14磅)vt.向 … 扔石头；去掉(水果的)核

  • To their surprise, the precious parcel was full of stones and sand! 令他们吃惊的是，珍贵的包裹里面装的全是石头和沙子！
  • Now he has put an ugly stone head over the gate. 现在他把一个丑陋的石雕头像放在了大门。
  • Jasper hopes that she will turn cars and their owners to stone. 贾斯珀希望她把汽车和车主们都变成石头。

SEE> brick 砖块, wood 树木, ad·di·tion 加

ODE> Hard solid non-metallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material. – rock, pebble, boulder.

1777. stop 停止 ## 30

[stɑːp]v.停止；阻止；停留n.停止；逗留；车站

  • Suddenly, she saw a man near a bus stop. 突然，她看到附近的一个公共汽车站一个人。
  • He wants you to stop. 他要你停下来。
  • Fifteen minutes passed and then, at five to twelve, the clock stopped. 十五分钟过去了，而就在11点55分时，大钟停了下来。

SEE> in·stead 代替, pre·vent 防止, sim·ply 只是

ODE> (of an event, action, or process) come to an end; cease to happen. – come to an end, come to a stop, cease, end, finish, draw to a close, be over, conclude, terminate, come to a standstill.

1778. store 商店 ## 3

[stɔːr]n.商店；贮藏；充裕vt.储存；贮藏；保存

  • A detective recently watched a well-dressed woman who always went into a large store on Monday mornings. 一名侦探最近看了一个衣冠楚楚的女人谁总是进入一家大商店在星期一上午。
  • When a thief was caught on the premises of a large jewellery store one morning, the shop assistants must have found it impossible to resist the temptation to say ‘it serves him right’. 当一个小偷在一家大型珠宝店里一上午被人抓住时，店员一定会发现无法抗拒的诱惑，说“他罪有应得”。
  • With the invention of writing, a great advance was made, for knowledge could then be not only communicated but also stored. 随着书写的发明，一大进步作出，知识然后可以不仅能交流，而且能储存了。

SEE> shop 店, su·per·mar·ket 超市, ware·house

ODE> A quantity or supply of something kept for use as needed. – supply, stock, stockpile, reserve, cache, hoard, accumulation, cumulation, quantity, pile, heap, load.

1779. storm 风暴 ## 4

[stɔːrm]n.暴风雨v.起风暴；猛攻；暴怒；捣毁

  • One afternoon she set out from the coast in a small boat and was caught in a storm. 一天下午，她从海岸出发的小船，遇上了风暴。
  • He slept very well for the first two nights, but on the third night, a storm blew up. 他睡得非常好。前两个晚上，但在第三天晚上，起了风暴。
  • In August, she was struck by a very heavy storm during which her rudder was torn away. 在8月，她被一场特大风暴，在此期间她舵撕掉袭击。

SEE> trop·i·cal 热带, wind 风, rain 下雨

ODE> A violent disturbance of the atmosphere with strong winds and usually rain, thunder, lightning, or snow. – tempest, squall.

1780. sto·ry 故事 ## 18

[’stɔːri]n.故事；传说；谎言；叙述；新闻报道；情节n.楼层(=storey)v.以历史事件为图案装饰

  • Do you like stories? 你喜欢听故事吗？
  • I want to tell you a true story. 我要告诉你一个真实的故事。
  • After a wonderful meal, they told stories and sang songs by the campfire. 美餐之后，他们讲起了故事，篝火，唱起了歌。

SEE> tale , nov·el 小说, book 书

ODE> An account of imaginary or real people and events told for entertainment. – tale, narrative, account, recital.

1781. straight 直的 ## 9

[streɪt]adj.直的；坦率的；正直的；准的；连续的；异性恋的adv.笔直地；直接；坦率地；连续不断地n.直的东西；传统的人；异性恋者

  • Why didn’t Caroline recognize the customer straight away? 为什么卡罗琳没有认识到客户马上？
  • Roy acted quickly and drove the bus straight at the thieves. 罗伊行动迅速，开车直冲窃贼。
  • When she caught up with them, she saw that they had sat down and were going through the contents of the bag, so she ran straight at them. 当她赶上他们，她发现他们已经坐了下来，正翻着包里的内容，于是她直冲过去。

SEE> con·sec·u·tive , fourth 第四, fifth 第五

ODE> Extending or moving uniformly in one direction only; without a curve or bend. – unswerving, undeviating, linear, direct, as straight as an arrow, uncurving, unbending.

1782. strange 奇怪 ## 12

[streɪndʒ]adj.奇怪的；陌生的；生疏或不自在的

  • It is a very modern house, so it looks strange to some people. 这是一个非常现代化的住宅，所以它看起来奇怪，一些人。
  • Captain Fawcett has just refused a strange request from a businessman. 弗西特机长刚刚拒绝了一位商人的奇怪要求。
  • He told me that he could not go to sleep one night because he heard a strange noise coming from the bar. 他告诉我，他不能去睡了一晚，因为他听到了奇怪的声音酒吧里传来。

SEE> weird , bi·zarre , odd 奇怪的

ODE> Unusual or surprising; difficult to understand or explain. – unusual, odd, curious, peculiar, funny, bizarre, weird, uncanny, queer, unexpected, unfamiliar, abnormal, atypical, anomalous, untypical, different, out of the ordinary, out of the way, extraordinary, remarkable, puzzling, mystifying, mysterious, perplexing, baffling, unaccountable, inexplicable, incongruous, uncommon, irregular, singular, deviant, aberrant, freak, freakish, surreal.

1783. stran·ger 陌生人 ## 5

[’streɪndʒər]n.陌生人；外地人；新手

  • How did Jane receive a letter from a stranger? 简是如何接收来自陌生人的来信？
  • When they had all made themselves comfortable, a stranger appeared. 当他们都已安排舒适时，一个陌生人出现了。
  • We often read in novels how a seemingly respectable person or family has some terrible secret which has been concealed from strangers for years. 我们经常读到小说中一个看似受人尊重的人物或家庭，却已经从陌生人隐藏多年的一些可怕的秘密。

SEE> strange 奇怪, sort 种类, in·deed 确实

ODE> A person whom one does not know or with whom one is not familiar. – unknown person.

1784. stream 溪流 ## 11

[striːm]n.(小)河；水流；(人；车；气)流；组v.流动；流出；飘动；将(学生)按能力分组

  • It was raining heavily and they found that a stream had formed in the field. 雨下得很大，他们发现，甲流已在该领域形成。
  • The stream wound its way across the field and then flowed right under their tent! 那小溪弯弯曲曲穿过田野，然后右键他们的帐篷底下流！
  • This immense chasm has been formed by an underground stream which has tunnelled a course through a flaw in the rocks. 这巨大的鸿沟已被已通过在岩石中的缺陷隧道课程地下流形成的。

SEE> flow 流动, a·long 沿着, like·wise

ODE> A small, narrow river. – brook, rivulet, rill, runnel, streamlet, freshet.

1785. street 街 ## 21

[striːt]n.街道；马路adj.街道的

  • The Sawyers live at 87 King Street. 该索耶斯住在国王街87号。
  • ‘Can you tell me the way to King Street, please?’ “你能告诉我到国王街，好吗？”
  • David Hall, 83, Bridge Street. 大卫·霍尔，83，大桥街。

SEE> wall 墙壁, av·e·nue , down·town

ODE> A public road in a city, town, or village, typically with houses and buildings on one or both sides. – road, thoroughfare, way.

1786. strength 力气 ## 4

[streŋθ]n.力气；强度；力量；长处

  • However, size and strength are not the only important things about this bridge. 然而，规模和实力都没有这个桥是唯一重要的事情。
  • Next came a horse, swimming bravely, but we were afraid that the strength of the current would prevent its landing anywhere before it became exhausted. 接下来是一匹马，勇敢地游着，但我们担心的是，当前的力量将使它在任何地方降落前就筋疲力尽了。
  • It has yet to reach its full size and strength, and its owner his or her full intelligence; but at this age the likelihood of death is least. 这还没有充分发挥其规模和实力，和它的主人他或她的全智能;但在这个年龄死亡的可能性最小。

SEE> a·bil·i·ty 能力, strong 强大, stam·i·na

ODE> The quality or state of being physically strong. – power, brawn, brawniness, muscle, muscularity, burliness, sturdiness, robustness, toughness, hardiness, lustiness.

1787. stress 强调 ## 2

[stres]n.压力；强调；重音vt.强调；重读

  • The shop assistant looked puzzled and Harry repeated the word, slowly stressing each syllable. 看着店员不解哈利重复道字，慢慢地一字一顿。
  • We would lay less stress on ‘facts and figures’ and more on a good memory, on applied psychology, and on the capacity of a man to get along with his fellow-citizens. 我们不会重视“资料和数据”，而靠好记性，实用心理学，并在一个人的能力与他的同胞相处。

SEE> anx·i·e·ty 焦虑, more·o·ver 此外, fur·ther·more

ODE> Pressure or tension exerted on a material object. – pressure, tension, strain, tightness, tautness.

1788. stretch 伸展 ## 4

[stretʃ]v.伸展；延伸；张开；夸大n.伸展；张开；弹性；一段时间；刑期adj.可伸缩的

  • They stretch out their legs like flying squirrels. 它们伸展四肢，就像飞行的松鼠。
  • What a relief it was when the boulders suddenly disappeared, giving way to a stretch of plain where the only obstacles were clumps of bushes. 什么救济是突然大石块不见了，让位给平淡的舒展，唯一的障碍是灌木丛的团块。
  • You can stretch your legs on the spacious decks, play games, meet interesting people and enjoy good food – always assuming, of course, that the sea is calm. 您可以舒展上宽敞的甲板，玩游戏，满足有趣的人你的双腿，享受美味佳肴 - 总是假设，当然，海上风平浪静。

SEE> rest 休息, a·long 沿着, be·yond 超出

ODE> (of something soft or elastic) be made or be capable of being made longer or wider without tearing or breaking. – be elastic, be stretchy, be stretchable, be tensile.

1789. strike 撞击 ## 20

[straɪk]n.罢工；打击；殴打v.打；撞；罢工；划燃

  • It would strike twelve in twenty minutes’ time. 将敲响12二十分钟的时间。
